urn:contentItem:5W9Y-5J41-DY0W-4496-00000-00Tax Reform Push; Dunkin ADJ EPS Miss Estimates: $0.61 (ACT) VS $0.63 (EST); Big Tech Earnings; WSJ: House GOP Still Considering 401K Changes in2017-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisTax Reform Push; Dunkin ADJ EPS Miss Estimates: $0.61 (ACT) VS $0.63 (EST); Big Tech Earnings; WSJ: House GOP Still Considering 401K Changes inLanhamFULL TEXT

ANNOUNCER (voice-over): Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of "Mornings With Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Thursday morning everybody. It is Thursday, October 26th. Thanks so much for joining us, happy Thursday. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

An earnings extravaganza today in business, among the top names reporting before the bell, Twitter, Ford Motor, UPS, and Comcast. It does not stop there, we got a big night tonight. We are expected to hear from Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet parent of Google.

Of course tech stocks have been trading down ahead of these numbers, we will have all of the numbers and analysis as they hit the tapes. Stay with us on this, that will likely set the tone for markets.

Take a look at Futures right now ahead of all of that, unchanged on the DOW Jones Industrial Average, very fractional moves for the S&P500 down not even a point. Nasdaq Composite up not even a point.

Checking the action in Europe this morning, stocks are higher in the European zone. FTSE100 up a third of a percent as the CAC Krones is in Paris and the DAX Index in Germany as well up about 38 points in Germany.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher, take a look at the indices there with the exception of Hong Kong and Korea. The Shanghai Composite was up a third of a percent, Nikkei Average also squeaking out a gain.

Meanwhile, back in the U.S., budget battle is brewing. The House expected to vote on the Senate's version of the fiscal 2018 budget later today. This move is critical as you know for the party as they move forward what the White House's call to get tax reform passed this year.

President Trump telling Lou Dobbs last night he expects the GOP to come together to get this passed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well I think we're going to get it. I think the senators are going to come together, I think the House is looking really good. They're passing this bill along very rapidly.

In fact, that's going to happen hopefully today and I did make a couple of calls. I said, "Fellows, please no changes. Just pass it along."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It may not be all smooth sailing though after all the growing controversy as lawmakers leave the door open to making changes to 401K retirement plans included in the tax bill. We're also taking a look at the deductions and the fight going on there.

President Trump blasting the democrats meanwhile, the commander-in-chief calling the funding of a dirty dossier by the Clinton campaign and DNC "disgraceful." Why he says the tables have now turned on the dems.

Meanwhile, "NBC News" analyst and author Mark Halperin is apologizing this morning after sexual assault accusations. The details after five women have come forward with harassment claims against him.

Travelers take notice, a new airport security measure is insight on all U.S. bound flight that's going into effect. One airline is making it a little easier though for you to fly. What you need to know before headed to the terminal coming up this morning.

I'm live here once again at day three of the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia this morning. We got a big panel coming up. I will be sitting down with Peter Thiel, founder of Palantier, the technology firm.

We're going to ask Peter Thiel about AI, about technology. It's another big day of exclusive news making interviews right here on the program. Among the big names I'll be speaking with, Venture Capitalist as I mentioned, Peter Thiel.

Plus, DOW Chemical CEO, Andrew Liveris is with us this morning. Bechtel Group CEO, Brendan Bechtel is here. And the CEO and President of Evercore, Ralph Schlosstein is with us. And the New York Stock Exchange President, Tom Farley as we all look to that Saudi Aramco deal with so many Wall Street want a piece of that action.

We'll talk about all of that coming up. Joining me from New York this morning, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Rosecliff CEO Managing Partner, Mike Murphy. And "The Wall Street Journal's Telecom" Reporter this morning, Ryan Knutson with us. Good morning everybody.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Maria.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER: Good morning. Nice to see you. How's the weather over there?

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, look, I want to talk about tech. The weather is gorgeous, it feels like it's all -- it's summer all the time actually. So it's pretty warm here.

But technology has not been warm, you know that. These stocks have been trading down going into this earnings period Mike. What do you think about the fact that Amazon has rolled over, Google parent Alphabet, are the expectations coming down for these tech names?

MURPHY: I don't really think so Maria. So I see it more as a basing pattern. They had these huge run ups in the first six to nine months of the year where they were up 30 percent roughly a lot of the names.

So they've had this kind of basing or even a pullback of five percent. I'm really looking forward to these earnings because I think if they continue the momentum they had these stocks are going to move to new highs.

RYAN KNUTSON, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL'S TELECOM REPORTER: There's also a little bit more concern --

BARTIROMO: What do you think Ryan?

KNUTSON: There's also a little bit more regulatory concern.

BARTIROMO: Yes, sorry.

KNUTSON: I mean we've got an administration now that is being a lot tougher on Amazon and all the pressure that they're under from a lot of the fake accounts and Russia's ability to buy ads on these platforms and there's a lot of scrutiny in Washington over these companies that might create some long-term pressure for them.

MCDOWELL: May I add one thing Maria?

BARTIROMO: Actually yes. Yes, please.

MCDOWELL: In terms of pressure from Washington, again, Kevin Brady Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, they're writing this tax bill trying to put it together.

Front page of "The Wall Street Journal" today that House republicans are still considering 401K plan changes in this tax overhaul despite what President Trump said on Twitter on Monday. I just think that this is one of the most moronic things as an investor, as a saver, as an American taxpayer that I've ever heard come out of Washington and that's saying a lot.

BARTIROMO: What's the point Dagen? I mean is it significant money that they're trying to save? I know every penny counts here given the $20 trillion debt that we're talking about and getting our arms around spending.

What is the point of making changes to 401K at the time that most Americans have no savings?

MCDOWELL: I think that it's raising -- it's a way to raise revenue in this tax overhaul. I think that some of these republicans believe that it will go unnoticed. Well I think the financial markets will not ignore it and it could cause a market crash, that's my thinking on this.

But there's a lot of data on how many people actually if they cut that $18,000 limit which is this year to say $2,400 maximum contribution of 401K plan, more than half of employees making more than $50,000 a year would be affected by that $2,400 cutoff, more than half.

BARTIROMO: People are not going to save as much, they won't be able to. And obviously they're not getting the match from their company. And we know that very -- I mean, a small percentage of people actually have the appropriate money saved for retirement which is one of the earliest lessons learned in business and investments that you have to have a nest egg for retirement.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. I know that you're hot on this because you are a saver, saver, saver.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So --

BARTIROMO: I am. And 401K included. But so are you. The two of us have that same mentality. Yes. We'll see how this plays out and we'll talk about it today with all of our guests because this is really important and it affects a lot of people.

It's also obviously the busiest day yet for third quarter earnings, let's get into that Dagen because we're waiting to hear from Comcast any moment. Expectations for the third quarter, $0.51 a share, revenue expected at $21 billion.

As we also await Twitter, the company is expected to report its third quarter earnings in the next hour as soon as these numbers come out. Obviously we're going to bring them to you. Analyst expect the social media company to report earnings of $0.06 a share on revenue of $586.7 million.

So Ryan, let's get into this here, what are you expecting when Twitter reports what should we be looking at in terms of what's most important here?

KNUTSON: Well subscriber growth is always a really key metric for Twitter. They had a huge bump after the election. There was nine million subscribers were added in the first quarter and then it was flat the quarter after that.

So -- and there's various expectations about whether there's going to be a million or maybe four million subscribers on Twitter. But one of the things here is that they haven't really been able to prove that they can make money.

If they come in at what analysts are expecting for revenue, that would be the third straight year-over-year decline in revenue for this company. They have huge engagement on the platform, it's obviously hugely important in American Fabric of Society.

You've got the president making huge re-important statements on here and that they haven't really been able to figure out how to turn a significant profit. One thing that's sort of interesting is that Square, the other company that Twitter CEO, Jack Dorsey is the CEO of is on pace to surpass Twitter in market value especially if Twitter has a rough day.

BARTIROMO: That's interesting. Meanwhile Microsoft -- I mean probably going to see a bigger impact on markets from Microsoft and from Alphabet, right?

I mean, Mike Murphy, do you expect that that's going to impact the broader markets, what we see from Microsoft and Google?

MURPHY: For sure.

BARTIROMO: And Amazon obviously.

MURPHY: Absolutely. These are the names where you've been able to invest for growth and this is where all of the big funds are heavily invested in these names.

So highly unlikely a Twitter could come in and surprise the markets for the downside. I see that's highly unlikely Amazon or Google or Microsoft disappoints the market in a big way. I think these guys are hitting on all cylinders right now.

So I expect strong quarters from all of the big tech and I think as I said earlier, I think they start to move to new highs.

BARTIROMO: And, of course, these stocks are trading up fractionally this morning. In the premarket, those companies reporting after the bell tonight.

Back in Washington Dagen, House republicans have these tax reform squarely in their sight. The Chamber set to vote today on that $4 trillion budget measure. That, of course, paves the way for tax reform but the House's top tax writer, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady says he's leaving the door open to making those changes to the 401K retirement plan.

Listen to what the president has to say about this at the White House. We've got to continue this conversation, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: 401Ks to me very important and they're important because that's one of the great benefits to the middle class. I didn't want that to go too far that's why I ended it very quickly.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Kevin Brady who was the Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said this morning it could be on the table.

TRUMP: Well, maybe it is and maybe we'll use that as negotiating but I trust -- trust me, that's one of the great things. You know, there are certain elements of deals you don't want to negotiate with.

401Ks and Kevin knows it and I think Kevin Brady is fantastic but he knows how important 401Ks are.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, is it on the table or off the table Dagen? I mean he said it was on -- off the table and then he said well maybe it's on the table.

MCDOWELL: It's still up for discussion because it said -- "The Wall Street Journal" has a great story on this that President Trump seem to surprise lawmakers on Monday by ruling out 401K changes that were discussed in the news over the weekend.

We've hammered this since it was even floated on Friday afternoon. But it is still up for discussion. But I'm just baffled by this because, again, it's an easy way to raise money right now because these are pre-taxed contributions.

Essentially, it opens the pool to more money to be taxed by the federal government by limiting the amount you can contribute to a 401K plan. But I want to remind everybody, we still pay tax on that 401K money when it comes out at retirement.

It's not like this money is untaxed. And I think that we -- the financial industry and even personal finance journalists have spent decades encouraging people to use their 401K plans and it's already difficult enough to use an IRA.

The rules are exceedingly complicated. So when you now limit how much somebody can contribute to their define contribution plan, you are really giving them the stick in a very uncomfortable place if you will.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And how much money are we really talking about in terms of savings? I mean, there's this debate of the state and local tax deduction and they're talking about a compromise here.

Are they going to put a cap on it at a certain salary level whereas you won't be able to deduct that. Maybe they are looking for more money and they're figuring maybe there's more money in the 401K part of the story because they're going to be losing some revenue if they put a cap on that and they can't overall eliminate the entire deduction.

So how much money are we really talking about in terms of 401Ks?

MCDOWELL: Right. It's --

BARTIROMO: Because the state and local deduction is $1.3 trillion, I get that. If they can't eliminate that deduction altogether, that's cutting into the $1.3 trillion in revenue. So what are we talking about in terms of 401K, in terms of revenue?

MCDOWELL: And one thing I'll add Maria, the one -- again, as -- again, this is supposed to be tax reform, it's supposed to make filing our taxes easier.

One idea up for discussion, replace the state and local tax deduction with the tax credit worth between eight and twenty percent of household property tax payment with caps for married couples starting between $250,000 and $400,000, that's an idea. Way to reform the tax code, way to reform it. Genius.

BARTIROMO: Well there goes the complications. All right. We'll keep talking about that. But first, coming up, disgraceful, that is what the president is calling the reports that Hillary Clinton and the DNC funded that dossier that claimed Donald Trump had links to Russia during the election, that's next. We're back in a moment.

Plus, upping the ante in the air, United app now gives you boarding passes for all your connecting flights even if they are on other airlines, we'll tell you all about it. Back in a moment right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Officials have hit another major roadblock in the Las Vegas shooting investigation. Cheryl Casone in New York right now with details and headlines. Cheryl, over to you.

CASONE: That's right Maria and good morning. "ABC News" is reporting that a laptop found in Stephen Paddock's hotel room was missing the hard drive depriving police of possible clues on why he unleashed that attack.

According to the report, investigators discover that Paddock had bought software that's used to erase files from a hard drive. Meanwhile, Mandalay Bay security guard, Jesus Campos reportedly, get this, left the country days after the shooting and he went to Mexico. He did though appear on the Ellen DeGeneres Show for an interview.

All right. President Trump slamming Hillary Clinton and the Democratic National Committee over the Russian dossier they built against him. The president appeared on "Lou Dobbs Tonight" in an exclusive interview.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Don't forget, Hillary Clinton totally denied this. She didn't know anything, she knew nothing. All of a sudden they found out. What I was amazed that it's almost $6 million that they paid and it's totally discredited, it's a total phony, I call it fake news, it's disgraceful. It's disgraceful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well the Clinton campaign and the DNC hired researched firm Fusion GPS to produce the infamous dossier alleging ties between President Trump and Russia.

A washout group now filing a complaint accusing them of breaking a campaign finance laws by failing to disclose the money that they spent on the dossier.

Well, travelers on U.S. bound flights facing tougher security measure due to terrorism concerns and that starts today. Those measures could include questioning and increased screening of electronic devices.

Also, United Airlines telling its passengers they need to get to the airport three hours before their flight.

And then speaking of United, the carrier says its app now allows flyers to get their boarding passes on their smartphone when they have connections on another airline. United says it's the only U.S.-based carrier that currently offers that feature.

And it was a Hollywood thriller for game two of the World Series. The House Astros were three outs away from falling behind 2-0 to the Dodgers but several heroes stepped up and the Astros outlasted the Dodgers 76, and get this, 11 innings to even the series at one game a piece.

It was a night of dramatic swings and a World Series record, eight home runs, five of which were in the extra innings. That series now shifts to Houston, Maria. And those are your headlines coming out of New York, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. An exciting World Series so far, thank you Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Meanwhile, "NBC" analyst and author Mark Halperin is now apologizing this morning. He is facing accusations of sexual harassment allegedly going back several years and at multiple TV networks. We'll tell you about it when we come right back.

And then the World Series now all nodded up, the Astros win game two of the series in dramatic fashion as you just heard. We've got more on what went on behind the game, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo. I'm coming to you live this morning from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh.

President Trump is getting tough on trade meanwhile, the president saying that changes to the North American Free Trade Agreement are necessary, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: NAFTA is a horrible agreement, one of the worst trade deals ever. Right now Mexico and Canada have such a great deal, it's so good that it's very hard for them to get used to the fact that it can't be that way anymore.

We're being very tough and we're being very fair but we have to get back a lot. What's happened to this country with NAFTA is unbelievable. The jobs that have been taken, the factories that are moving out of our -- out of Michigan, out of Ohio, out of Pennsylvania, out of our states is incredible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me now with the first on FOX Business interview with DOW Chemical CEO, Executive Chairman of DOW DuPont, Andrew Liveris. Andrew, it's great to see you.

ANDREW LIVERIS, CEO, DOW CHEMICAL: Nice to be with you Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. So we heard the president talking about trade there, we want to talk about that with you but also talk about where you are in terms of this deal and the splitting of the three companies.

DOW Chemical based in Michigan first, talk to us about trade and where you see the challenges and opportunities.

LIVERIS: Well as you know with the president's agenda free trade versus pay trade and when I wrote the book, "Making it in America" I talked about fair trade and I do believe that as the United States does its trade agenda in the world refreshing our trade agreement.

So there's fairness both sides. We're a consumption economy in the United States therefore by definition an importer. But we need to become an investment economy as a consequence become an exporter.

The chemical industry is the number two exporter off of aerospace in the United States, we're a big part of this trade conversation whether it be NAFTA, Canada, Looms Lodge (ph), Vodal (ph), and what we up in Canada, but China Looms Lodge (ph). And I'll be part of the visit to China here in a couple weeks --

BARTIROMO: Terrific.

LIVERIS: -- where we'll be talking a lot about trade as well. So I'm all for calibrating trades so it's fair.

BARTIROMO: Why haven't they been fair so far? I mean do you agree with what the president is saying in terms of Canada and Mexico having this great deal that the U.S. is at a disadvantage?

LIVERIS: I do. I do think it's because of our mindset. We've spent six decades since the martial plan the consumer. I would tell you over and over we haven't given much thought to being an investor now in economy in things like manufacturing and industrial competitiveness.

We haven't had an industrial policy and we barely have an energy policy. So the president is putting emphasis on what can I do to create jobs in America as an exporter of manufactured goods and I'm all for that.

And I do believe we haven't attended to it very well and therefore we allow these free trade agreements where people can export to us and when they export to us they're exporting goods but they have the jobs over there.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. And that sort of became the template when we did the NAFTA deal. Companies now said, "Okay, no problem. I will have all my jobs in Mexico and then I'll just sell to the U.S."

LIVERIS: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: You're the former head of the president's manufacturing council, you're obviously working with the president closely on this, how do you want to see NAFTA change?

LIVERIS: Well it does need to be refreshed for the modern era. I think the 21st Century is a digital century. I do think automation and factories are changing in competitiveness, and I don't think our labor arbitrage is the reason we should be investing in factories.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LIVERIS: We should be investing in factories for all the things that go with it including human capital. So I am pro a reset on NAFTA.

Now, of course, fair trade is going to take give and take but I do think it's an agenda and I'm all for what's going on with NAFTA. Secretary Ross is incredibly good at this.

BARTIROMO: Great.

LIVERIS: We've known him for a long time --

BARTIROMO: Of course you have. Sure. Yes.

LIVERIS: And we know -- he knows business. So I really think a sit at the table for business to help recalibrate manufacturing whether it be NAFTA or China is very necessary.

BARTIROMO: DOW Chemical, DuPont did a merger in August, you're planning on splitting into three companies, how is that going? What can you tell us in terms of the status?

LIVERIS: Well great stock. We took a little while to close the deal but we did it as you said in the timeframe you did. So now we're furiously putting together all the synergies and soon we'll have a lot to say about the timing of the spins and we'll have our earnings call next week, and looked the company's storied companies, 300 years of history.

BARTIROMO: Incredible. I know that, yes.

LIVERIS: Can you imagine what we're doing to rearrange the assets and the cultures of these three dynamic growth companies. But look, a great start and Ed (INAUDIBLE) and I working close, basically twins right now to put this together.

BARTIROMO: And the growth is really in the chemicals business.

LIVERIS: Well it's all three. I'd say the agricultural company we're creating will be a category winner. The materials, chemicals company category winner, and this new special company we're creating, all four divisions in their own right a number one or number of in their businesses.

So all three will be growth companies and frankly, come the time we spin we'll have an amazing investor stories. But we're at all stock price high right now. So --

BARTIROMO: Right. Obviously investors have reacted in it. Yes.

LIVERIS: Investors have seen as a positive move. And this deal took 10 years in the making Maria. You and I probably talked about this 10 years ago.

BARTIROMO: You're right. You're right.

LIVERIS: And here we are, it can be done to refresh corporations at scale, not easy but it can be done.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I didn't realize that chemicals was the second largest expert. That's incredible actually.

LIVERIS: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Real quick, you're here in Saudi, you've been here for a long time, you've been coming back and you see opportunities to sell here.

LIVERIS: I'm a big fan of the crowned prince and what he's doing. We're an early adapted to his vision, vision 2030. We have finished the $22 billion industrial complex based on advance materials and chemicals with Saudi Aramco.

It's starting up. The quality of the Saudi workforce, best in class around the world. The talent here, we have 4,000 young Saudis, very impressed. When we train them around the world, our people who train them didn't want to let them come back, they were that great.

And this complex is a harbinger what's to come here. I believe beyond oil and what they're doing here to diversify and to really what he said on your panel the other day to really bring to world a new form of Islam and how he's going to do it.

I'm a big fan. I come here three to five times a year and I would tell you that we are investors here.

BARTIROMO: It's pretty incredible what they're trying to do here. I mean it feels seismic. Andrew, it's great to see you.

LIVERIS: Thank you. Great to see you Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us this morning.

LIVERIS: Nice to be with you.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching the developments. Andrew Liveris there.

Coming up, hitting the gas for the President's infrastructure plan. There are reports of a gas tax hike to fund the trillion-dollar tax package. We will tell you about that. And then the earnings keep on rolling this morning when the busiest days of the quarter. New equipment, bigger jets, will change at UPS help the bottom line ahead of the holiday busy season. We will tell you about that, earnings on tax. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. It is Thursday, October 26th, your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Earnings split on Wall Street today, one of the top companies reporting before the opening bell this morning, Twitter, Ford Motor, UPS, and Comcast. We are all (INAUDIBLE) as soon as the numbers hit the tape. We will bring them to you. Duncan brand just reporting hitting the tape earlier this hour.

Revenue tops expectations at Duncan but earnings per share, a slight miss, as you can see that stock has done well in the last three months. The earnings news does not stop there. We've got a big night tonight after the closing bell. We will hear from Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet, of course, these stocks have been lightning rods in terms of money moving into them, although they haven't been trading down going into these numbers. We'll have those numbers for you and analysis as soon as they hit the tape as well.

Futures this morning, searching for some direction, take a look at markets right now, where we see the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the NASDAQ and the S&P 500 all higher but just by a fraction. In Europe, stocks are higher as well. Take a look at the European indices right here, which are off by about a third of a percent on average, FT 100 up 25 points, CAC Quarante up a half of a percent, that's 27 points higher, and the DAX Index in Germany, up 45.

In Asia overnight, markets closed mostly higher, with the exception of the Hang Seng and KOSPI. Shanghai composite in China up a third of a percent, the Nikkei Average in Japan, also higher. Rebuilding America, White House Chief Economic Adviser, Gary Cohn, reportedly telling lawmakers that a gas tax could be in play next year when the administration unveils its infrastructure package. What that means for your wallet, coming up. Walgreens, meanwhile, battling the opioid crisis in America, the drugstore is now stocking the lifesaving nasal spray, Narcan. President Trump weighed in on the opioid crisis while speaking with Lou Dobbs last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The opioid is a tremendous emergency, what's going on there? The drugs pouring into the country have gotten -- and I tell you what, we've made a big impact, but still, we need the wall, you know, part of the reason we need the wall is the drugs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The very latest, coming up this morning, as the President prepares to officially declare the opioid epidemic, a public health emergency. Meanwhile, there's this, NBC News Analyst and Author, Mark Halperin is apologizing this morning after sexual assault accusations. The details after five women have come forward with harassment claims against him. Uber goes further to target millennials' money. We're breaking down the perks that come with the ride-sharing services' first credit card, yes, an Uber credit card. We'll tell you about it.

But first, our live all-day today at day three of the Future Investment Initiatives, here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia this morning. It's another big day of exclusive news-making interviews among the big names that I'll be speaking with today, the CEO and President of Evercore, Ralph Schlosstein is with us, Venture Capitalist, Peter Thiel. I'll be on stage with him later to talk about technology, in particular, A.I., and the President of the New York Stock Exchange, Tom Farley is here, as we watch so many Wall Streeters and investment professionals wanting in, on that Saudi Aramco, huge IPO, coming to market we're expecting next year.

First though, let's turn to the President's ambitious agenda on infrastructure, Economic Adviser Gary Cohn reportedly told House lawmakers in a private meeting yesterday, that they will get a chance to vote on a gas tax early next year, when Congress considers Trump's $1 trillion infrastructure package, that's according to Politico. Other reports suggest that it could be a 0.07-cent increase on gas taxes. I want to bring in the Head of America's Largest Construction and Civil Engineering Company, Bechtel Group, the CEO and Chairman, Brendan Bechtel is with us, Brendan, great to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

BRENDAN BECHTEL, CEO & CHAIRMAN OF BECHTEL GROUP: Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: What do you think about a gas tax -- gas tax increase? What does that say about the demand for infrastructure and how -- what kind of an impact might that have?

BECHTEL: Well, I think to quantify the challenge -- the demand for infrastructure globally is about $3 trillion a year (INAUDIBLE) within the U.S. alone, we expected about $2 trillion dollars required over the next 10 years in the United States. So, there has been political consensus, I would say, really, throughout the election season and lately around the need for infrastructure, the challenge, the debate is around how to pay for it. The gas tax is one way that we might solve that challenge. It's not been even an inflation-adjusted for many, many years now and it has traditionally been one of the biggest revenue screens that's funded public infrastructure in the United States.

BARTIROMO: Do think we will see an infrastructure plan from this administration?

BECHTEL: I think there's a very clear focus on tax reform as the first priority. What I'm hearing is that infrastructures in the landing pattern after that, but it's all about tax reform in the short-term.

BARTIROMO: And I want to ask you about the economy, because I know you're watching Copper, obviously, and that's going to tell us something. But let me get your take on this, the Crown Prince, the future king of Saudi Arabia, Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman, told me about his plans for this new city NEOM, a futuristic city set to debut in 2030. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PRINCE MOHAMMAD BIN SALMAN, CROWN PRINCE OF SAUDI ARABIA: The city will be built on the newest technologies of today. The opportunity is unimaginable. A region that is almost vacant. There are many dreams from the Saudi leadership, many of the Saudis and many our partners and of the large companies or individuals, thousands of dreams that will be established in NEOM.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It sounds like an incredible opportunity. Bechtel has a long- standing partnership, 75 years. You go back in Saudi Arabia?

BECHTEL: Yes, next year will be our 75th anniversary. I think this is so exciting. The Crown Prince's speech on your panel, and there are a lot of subtle messages in there too.

BARTIROMO: There were.

BECHTEL: For those of us that have been around a while, are very significant milestones. But specifically, the example of NEOM, I think it's demonstrative of the vision, that's laid out in vision 2030. It's a bold, ambitious but achievable plan. I think an interesting way to talk about this is to reflect on Bechtel's history in Saudi Arabia's. When we got started 74 years ago in the 40s and 50s, we are working on oil pipelines (INAUDIBLE) on basic civil infrastructure like railways. In the 1970s, we started on Jubail, which at the time, was a fishing village. Today, 40 years later, we are still working there.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

BECHTEL: And it is the largest industrial city in the Middle East and it accounts for somewhere between four and five percent of Saudi Arabia's non- oil GDP. So, well, I've been here at the conference, people have been coming up and asking me, do you think this is achievable? All the projects that are laid out in vision 2030, do you think it's possible? And I said, again, remember this example of Jubail, 40 years ago, it was a fishing village, today, it's the largest industrial city in the region. I think the difference is, I don't think the Crown Prince is going to give us 40 years to go.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BECHTEL: This is -- he is -- he is -- he is really driving everyone to keep up, which I think, is incredible.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible, the vision that he's ha and really pushing to change some of the historic cultures here, opening it up to foreign investment, allowing women to drive. We've talked about that on the panel. Let me ask you about Copper. I mean, if you look at a chart of Copper, it's had a tough 10 years, obviously, but now we're seeing money moved back into Copper. What does that tell you?

BECHTEL: Well, so I think, with respect to growth, it's one of the things we're most excited about. So we felt roughly about a third of all the Copper concentrators on earth. I'm particularly focused in Chile and the Indies. And based on the study work that we are doing which is a pretty good predictor of big project investment decisions over the next few years, we are seeing things start to pick back up and that is driven predominantly by the Copper price.

BARTIROMO: And do you think that Copper, at this point, is indicative of the fact that we are seeing a pickup in housing and Copper, obviously, goes in everything from cars to your house. So is it indicative --

BECHTEL: Electrical wires.

BARTIROMO: Electrical wires, so is it indicative of construction?

BECHTEL: Yes, I think it's a good -- it has to be a pretty good leading indicator of an interest in construction activity broadly. So I do think it's a good indicator of that, but I also think the mining sectors, so Cepacol and Boom-Bust in terms of oversupply, undersupply, and the way they approach CAPEX investments. And so, you know, 10 years ago, it appeared with a lot of big projects going on to meet the demand and then it got a little overbuilt and then, I would say, demands have been building, building, building and it's time to start doing projects again.

BARTIROMO: So, how would you characterize the economy right now from that standpoint in terms of construction and what you're seeing in commodities?

BECHTEL: I would say, so, we still continue in the oil and gas market, it's still across most the mining sector, low cost is king. It's all about low cost. And so it's all about who can work their way down the cost supply curve. Growth markets for us within that year, you're looking at Niche Play so anything that benefits from cheap Shell gas in the U.S. is a winner, so Petrochemicals, combined cycle natural gas power plants. I would say more broadly, you've got for us, the big growth opportunity in the U.S. and I would say around the world right now is infrastructure. It's public works. It's anything that benefits from the lower cost of rock commodities which are key inputs to the global economy.

BARTIROMO: Really, fascinating stuff, Brendan, great to have you on the program.

BECHTEL: Thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching the developments, literally, Brendan Bechtel joining us there. Coming up, as the President is previewing his plan to declare a public health emergency for the opiate epidemic today, Walgreens is revealing it will stock the nasal spray that reverses opioid overdoses. We'll tell you about that. Then, Uber is thinking about a credit card, the ride-sharing service teaming up with Visa, for a branded car that offers some unexpected perks, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, everybody. Markets are flat right now, but it's all about earnings today. We are watching the earnings hitting the tape; that will drive markets. Things have turned around. We're looking at a market that is going to be opening fractionally higher on the session. Dow Industrials up about 10 points right now.

UPS, certainly a name to watch today. The company is set to report its third-quarter earnings before the opening bell this morning. Analysts expect earnings of a $1.45 a share. The stock of UPS up over 10 percent in the last year.

We're also watching shares of Mattel. The toymaker is set to report its third-quarter earnings after the bell tonight. Analysts looking for earnings there, $0.58 a share. And shares of Mattel, it's had a tough year, it's down more than 40 percent this year alone.

Sexual harassment charges against an NBC news analyst and a former NBC news political director. Cheryl Casone with the details right now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: Well, Maria, a number of women have accused Author, Mark Halperin, of Senior Political Analyst and frequent contributor for NBC News and MSNBC of sexual harassment. The women talked to CNN about the alleged lewd behavior from Halperin who co-authored the book "Game Change," and who also stars in the hit Showtime series "The Circus." In a statement, Halperin admits he pursued relationships with younger women and he has apologized for any inappropriate behavior.

Well, President Trump telling Fox Business he's going to declare a public health emergency on the opioid crisis. In an interview with Lou Dobbs, Trump says the border wall will help the war on drugs as well.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The opioid is a tremendous emergency. What's going on there? The drugs pouring into the country have gotten -- and I'll tell you what, we've made a big impact, but still we need the wall, you know, part of the reason we need the wall is for drugs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, Trump is expected to give a preview of his plans for tackling the opioid crisis later on today.

Meanwhile, Walgreens says that all of its pharmacies nationwide will now stock Narcan in the battle against opioids. The nasal spray can reverse the effects of an overdose on those drugs, which includes some prescription painkillers and heroin. Shares of Walgreens parent company are down by more than 18 percent so far, this year. Walgreen Boots Alliance, a stock to watch today.

And this may not come as a surprise to fans of Uber: they're launching a credit card in partnership with Barclays and Visa. Besides being convenient for the customers, the card will also give Uber valuable information about its riders, because they like that. The card has no fee and offers a number of benefits, cash bonuses, especially based on how much you charge for it. But again, Maria, how much information are you willing to give to Uber?

BARTIROMO: That's incredible. Well, there you go. They have the data. They're going to share it. Thank you, Cheryl. Coming up, robots officially living among us, at least right here in Saudi Arabia. A robot has been granted citizenship in the Saudi Kingdom. We will tell you about that when we come right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back! I am live this morning on day three of the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. For the first time ever, a robot here was granted citizenship yesterday. It all happened right here in Saudi Arabia. Joining us right now is Uptake Technologies CEO and Co-Founder, Brad Keywell. Brad, it is nice to have you on the program.

BRAD KEYWELL, CEO & CO-FOUNDER, UPTAKE TECHNOLOGIES: Pleasure to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes, great to see you. Here we are in Saudi. You co-founded and sit on the board of a number of manufacturing and technology companies, and you founded a ton of companies including Groupon, we should say.

KEYWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Talk to us about artificial intelligence. I feel like, if you're not using A.I., you're going to be left behind.

KEYWELL: I do think that the next -- the fourth industrial revolution about unleashing not just people's best, but the best of what data and the machines around us can tell us to make people even better. And so, this is core to what's happening in technology, and so we are one of the -- one of the leaders that's taking this idea and making it actionable.

A quick example is in the world of Locomotives. We actually give the operators of Locomotives a health score, so they know before they deploy that Locomotive to go from one city to the next, they'd know that it won't break. So, the philosophy is that things shouldn't break, and in this emerging industrial revolution, we will all be better off because our assets, our industries will be more productive and more reliable, and really safer which is a big part of our value proposition as well.

BARTIROMO: I can totally see that because you've had sensors basically checking the safety and the health of whatever it is. And that even applies to human beings, by the way.

KEYWELL: Absolutely. We can all be better. So, what's the operating system to make us better, and as it relates to our personal lives? There's an operating system on our phones. As it relates to our industries and business, especially manufacturing and some of the utility that runs our world, the operating system has to start with sensors, sensor-generated data, and then be deployed and that's what -- Uptake is exclusively focused on turning that possibility into action.

BARTIROMO: So, Uptake Technology is used in a range of products, and industries we know from energy to aviation; employing 800 people; $200 billion valuations there. Let's talk about the bad news, OK, and that is robots are probably going to replace humans, aren't they?

KEYWELL: I disagree.

BARTIROMO: OK.

(LAUGHTER)

KEYWELL: You know, my idea is -- and what we are proving out is that people are -- humans are made superhuman through the intelligence that can be derived from these sensors. And there is a clear argument that gets -- that gets made about the possibility that there'd be no humans, that there'd be autonomous everything. But these are, you know, the art of extracting minerals from the ground, and the art of producing oil and the rest. This is something that has historically involved humans, and I just don't see that changing.

I do see humans and the people that are part of these industries elevating their skills; I do see technology like we make it uptake, making them even better at what they do. And I also see a new philosophy that there's going to be winners and losers, and that's part of admiration to crown prince and kingdom, which is there's a commitment to being at the forefront and leadership role as it relates to deploying predictive analytics into industry and smart cities -- which we talked about as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right. I mean, that's something that he's committed to, I know; he said that the other day on the panel. And this is going to be probably one of most innovative cities we've ever seen, by the way.

KEYWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: But Masa, from Softbank, also was on the panel on Tuesday, and he said at some point there will be more robots than humans, you don't think so? Even if it's the same amount, it's amazing.

KEYWELL: I don't envision the city with robots -- with more robots moving around the street than people. I do envision cities that have operating systems like Uptake that are optimizing every aspect of that city, that are more environmentally responsible.

BARTIROMO: That makes sense.

KEYWELL: That is more -- the traffic moves more fluidly, that everybody's life has improved based upon people being smarter deriving data from all the ambient activities.

BARTIROMO: Is it more cost-effective, Brad, with technology, yes?

KEYWELL: What we're seeing in actual deployments in some of these industries like aviation, and rail, and construction is that the return of investment when you buy uptake's products, you're talking three, five, seven, ten returns if you're the company buying our software. So, it's an extraordinary time in the world of technology. And as an entrepreneur, to find an ability to impact real industries the way we have, that's -- that's extraordinary.

BARTIROMO: Fascinating stuff, Brad, you'll have to come back and tell us all about it.

KEYWELL: Happy to.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

KEYWELL: OK. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Brad Keywell from Uptake. We'll be right back. Stay with us live from Riyadh this morning.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

BARTIROMO: Good Thursday morning, everybody!

END

urn:contentItem:5W46-K6K1-DY0W-41RB-00000-00Tax Reform Push; Dunkin ADJ EPS Miss Estimates: $0.61 (ACT) VS $0.63 (EST); Big Tech Earnings; WSJ: House GOP Still Considering 401K Changes in2017-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisTax Reform Push; Dunkin ADJ EPS Miss Estimates: $0.61 (ACT) VS $0.63 (EST); Big Tech Earnings; WSJ: House GOP Still Considering 401K Changes inLanhamFULL TEXT

ANNOUNCER (voice-over): Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of "Mornings With Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Thursday morning everybody. It is Thursday, October 26th. Thanks so much for joining us, happy Thursday. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

An earnings extravaganza today in business, among the top names reporting before the bell, Twitter, Ford Motor, UPS, and Comcast. It does not stop there, we got a big night tonight. We are expected to hear from Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet parent of Google.

Of course tech stocks have been trading down ahead of these numbers, we will have all of the numbers and analysis as they hit the tapes. Stay with us on this, that will likely set the tone for markets.

Take a look at Futures right now ahead of all of that, unchanged on the DOW Jones Industrial Average, very fractional moves for the S&P500 down not even a point. Nasdaq Composite up not even a point.

Checking the action in Europe this morning, stocks are higher in the European zone. FTSE100 up a third of a percent as the CAC Krones is in Paris and the DAX Index in Germany as well up about 38 points in Germany.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher, take a look at the indices there with the exception of Hong Kong and Korea. The Shanghai Composite was up a third of a percent, Nikkei Average also squeaking out a gain.

Meanwhile, back in the U.S., budget battle is brewing. The House expected to vote on the Senate's version of the fiscal 2018 budget later today. This move is critical as you know for the party as they move forward what the White House's call to get tax reform passed this year.

President Trump telling Lou Dobbs last night he expects the GOP to come together to get this passed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well I think we're going to get it. I think the senators are going to come together, I think the House is looking really good. They're passing this bill along very rapidly.

In fact, that's going to happen hopefully today and I did make a couple of calls. I said, "Fellows, please no changes. Just pass it along."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It may not be all smooth sailing though after all the growing controversy as lawmakers leave the door open to making changes to 401K retirement plans included in the tax bill. We're also taking a look at the deductions and the fight going on there.

President Trump blasting the democrats meanwhile, the commander-in-chief calling the funding of a dirty dossier by the Clinton campaign and DNC "disgraceful." Why he says the tables have now turned on the dems.

You don't actually need to use to make payments and it's been, you know, there's about $70 billion worth of Bitcoin in the world, there's nine trillion worth of gold. And if Bitcoin ends up being the cyberequivalent of gold, it has a -- it has a -- it has a great potential left. So that's -- and it's a very different kind of thing from what people in -- people in Silicon Valley normally focus on companies, not, you know, algorithms or protocols but to -- this may be -- this may be one exception that's very underestimated.

BARTIROMO: Will people question it and I know there has been much debate about Bitcoin but they question it because what is it based on. I mean, you see that the dollar is based on, you know, the trust of the treasury, the trust of U.S. government. What is Bitcoin based on?

THEIL: Well, you know, it's based on the security of the math which tells you that it can never be -- it can never be diluted by government. It can never -- it can never be -- it can't be hacked and it's a form of money that's absolutely -- that's secure in an absolute way. And, of course, you could ask the same question about gold. That's why I use the gold analogy, say, what is gold based on, why is gold valuable?

BARTIROMO: That's true. Yes. Well, it's a tangible asset, gold.

THEIL: It's a tangible asset, but it's also hard to mine. If it was easy to mine gold then it wouldn't be that valuable, so you would just have way more gold. So, Bitcoin is also it's mineable like gold, it's hard to mine, it's actually harder to mine than gold, and so in that sense, it's more constrained, and so, yes, there are a number of things that I think make it somewhat similar to gold, and then the question is just, does this become - - does this become more widely -- more widely used.

BARTIROMO: And it's anonymous, right? I mean, that's one of the beauties of it. You can be anonymous using Bitcoin.

THEIL: Yes, it's half anonymous, half not. So, it's -- again, this intermediate thing is a question whether that's right or not but it's a bearer instrument, so if you -- if you have the Bitcoin, if you know the key, you can -- you can go anywhere most of the time most securities are registered, not bearer security, so it's a very unusual kind of a security.

BARTIROMO: Peter Theil, thanks so much for your insights today.

THEIL: Awesome. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you, Peter Thiel. Thank you, ladies and gentlemen.

MCDOWELL: That was our very own Maria Bartiromo at the Future Investment Initiative interviewing Peter Thiel Bitcoin more constrained than gold is one comment from Peter Thiel in Saudi Arabia.

Earlier this morning, Maria interviewed SoftBank's investment adviser CEO, Rajeev Misra, and discussed the company's current dealings with Uber.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What's happening with Uber right now? I know they wanted $10 billion from you?

RAJEEV MISRA, INVESTMENT ADVISER, SOFTBANK: No, Uber is not looking to take 10 billion from us. They will get 1 billion or 1-1/2 billion as primary investment. There is potentially an opportunity to provide liquidity to shareholder and employees who are early investors to sell secondary shares to SoftBank, and we are in late-stage discussions to potentially buy some secondary shares from early investors.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Maria also got his take on Alibaba and finding value in these markets. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Obviously, Alibaba has been an incredible performer for you. But when you look elsewhere, is there another Alibaba out there?

MISRA: They may not be Alibabas but we make thousand times the return, but we invested in Nvidia nine months ago. We bought five percent of Nvidia, it was close to $3 billion. It's worth 6 billion in nine months. So, you don't have to find just Alibabas to make good investments.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Mike Murphy, I want to get your reaction to both of those comments from Rajeev.

MURPHY: So, the Uber is really interesting, because, you know, so many people are talking about when is Uber going to go public? They have to go public. Well, he talks about giving the company 1 billion to 1-1/2 billion, and taking existing shareholders and employees out of their stocks, so tendering stock from people who currently own it. Sounds like kind of a public-type transaction where without going public. So, I think that's really interesting and could be the future for Unicorns. If you have these large like SoftBank raising another $100 billion funds now. If they're looking to go out to Unicorns, provide liquidity to people, that will 100 percent give Unicorns less reasons to go public.

KNUTSON: And it will take a lot of pressure off of those companies, too, because as you see when they have an IPO, suddenly they're out in the open, you can see how much money they're losing like we've seen with Snap. It might, in Uber's case, take a lot of pressure off of them so they can try to turn the company around and get their culture in place without having to have the spotlight of the public markets.

MCDOWELL: And they've got a -- they still have a fairly long road to go on that. Meantime, pretty busy morning for earnings, but is Washington really driving the market? Joining me now is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Mr. Stuart Varney. What say you, Mr. Varney?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: What say I? I'd be intrigued to hear Mike Murphy's Unicorn hunting stories. I wonder if he's ever come across a stock that he invest 3 billion into and nine months later, it's worth 6 billion. Just asking, Mike. Just asking.

MURPHY: I haven't yet, but if I do, Stuart, I'm calling you first.

VARNEY: You're a good man. I don't care what they say. All right. Onward and upward, I've been watching these earnings reports that's coming out this morning. Overall, they look pretty good, in line, with the pretty good report that we've seen so far. That's why this market is up 61 points, the Dow is going higher first thing this morning. I'm paying attention more closely to the budget vote. I expect it to be a "yes". If it's a "no," catastrophe. I'm paying attention to tonight, Amazon, Google, Microsoft, 4:00, they get their results out there. I think that's absolutely crucial to the future of the market because if any of them disappoints significantly, I think we've got a real problem here. So, it's a real high-stakes game today with the budget and the big techs, but so far, so good, we open higher.

MCDOWELL: Make it happen, Stuart.

VARNEY: Moi?

MCDOWELL: Yes. Yes.

VARNEY: Talk to Murphy. He's the one who makes things happen.

MCDOWELL: Oui, oui, Stuart, toi.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Stuart, "VARNEY & COMPANY," Monday through Friday. You can't miss him, not one minute of it in less than 10 minutes. 9:00 a.m. Eastern, "VARNEY & COMPANY." We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A well-known political analyst at NBC accused of sexual harassment. Cheryl Casone has more on this. Cheryl?

CASONE: And there's been some new developments in the story, Dagen. NBC has now suspended political analyst Mark Halperin, following accusations of sexual harassment. A number of women talked to CNN about alleged lewd behave from Halperin who co-authored the book, "Game Change." In a statement, Halperin says he pursued relationships with younger woman and he apologizes. Here is the statement, this is what he said, "During this period, I did pursue relationships with women that I worked with, including some junior to me. I now understand from these accounts that my behavior was inappropriate and caused others pain." So, we're just getting that statement in, and he continues to say, "For that, I am deeply sorry and I apologize under the circumstance, I'm going to take a step back from my day-to-day work while I properly deal with this situation." So, again, Mark Halperin has been suspended from NBC and MSNBC as well.

Well, talks between the Weinstein Company, Colony Capital have stumbled and the troubled studio may seek some other bidders. The Wall Street Journal reporting price is the main issue now despite its value falling sharply in the wake of the scandal, the board of the company is seeking more than Colony is willing to pay right now, Dagen. So those are a couple headlines we're following for you this morning. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl. And let's get right back to Maria Bartiromo at The Future Investment Initiative in Saudi Arabia. There's so much to cover from what you experienced in the last few days, Maria.

BARTIROMO: You're right, Dagen. And you know, I guess my big -- sort of, my big feeling or thought here is the fact that there is something going on here that it feels like seismic. I mean, there's a change in culture, the Crown Prince, who of course, is the future king has drawn line in the sand and basically said, look, we want to open this country, we want -- we want to live normal lives. You know, he was talking the other day onstage basically saying, we used to live normal lines before 1979 when Iran really took over. And I think that's why the Saudis and the U.S. have become friendly, and are aligned because their common enemy is Iran.

And so, I think that the Crown Prince recognizes that the world is looking at Saudi Arabia differently than he sees it, and skeptically, frankly, obviously. And so, he's trying to change that perception. We'll see if it works. There is some pushback to his plans. They're saying, look, he's moving way you too fast, some people don't want to change, they want to have women covered up, they want this -- their history to continue, he doesn't. He's 32 years old, he's the future king, and he's trying to make tremendous change. That was one thought here.

The other thought is the fact that they are using technology in incredible ways, they want autonomous cars, they want machine learning, they are putting all of the things that we talked about every day into practice here. So, we'll see, it's an experiment. We'll obviously be watching it, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: It really -- and I think the attendance there and the biggest names in investing, the heaviest hitters from around the globe, the fact that they are there kind of also spotlights on change that's happening.

BARTIROMO: For sure. And, of course, there's Saudi Aramco deal. It's going to be the largest IPO ever. It's going to be a $100-billion deal. Just to put that in perspective, Alibaba was the biggest, that was 25 billion. Saudi Aramco is going to be 100 billion, so that's why you see all of these private equity guys and investors. They want a piece of that action. We'll take a short break. When we come back, live from Riyadh and New York. Stay with Fox Business.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: That'll do it for us from Saudi Arabia. My thanks to Mike Murphy, Ryan Knutson, Dagen McDowell, we'll see you tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: Yes, come back soon, Maria, we miss you. (INAUDIBLE) were here. All right. Now --

BARTIROMO: I'm on my way. Thanks, Stu.

END

urn:contentItem:5W46-K6K1-DY0W-41RC-00000-00Tax Reform Push; Dunkin ADJ EPS Miss Estimates: $0.61 (ACT) VS $0.63 (EST); Big Tech Earnings; WSJ: House GOP Still Considering 401K Changes in2017-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:10ZLexisNexisTax Reform Push; Dunkin ADJ EPS Miss Estimates: $0.61 (ACT) VS $0.63 (EST); Big Tech Earnings; WSJ: House GOP Still Considering 401K Changes inLanhamFULL TEXT

ANNOUNCER (voice-over): Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of "Mornings With Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Thursday morning everybody. It is Thursday, October 26th. Thanks so much for joining us, happy Thursday. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

An earnings extravaganza today in business, among the top names reporting before the bell, Twitter, Ford Motor, UPS, and Comcast. It does not stop there, we got a big night tonight. We are expected to hear from Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet parent of Google.

Of course tech stocks have been trading down ahead of these numbers, we will have all of the numbers and analysis as they hit the tapes. Stay with us on this, that will likely set the tone for markets.

Take a look at Futures right now ahead of all of that, unchanged on the DOW Jones Industrial Average, very fractional moves for the S&P500 down not even a point. Nasdaq Composite up not even a point.

Checking the action in Europe this morning, stocks are higher in the European zone. FTSE100 up a third of a percent as the CAC Krones is in Paris and the DAX Index in Germany as well up about 38 points in Germany.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher, take a look at the indices there with the exception of Hong Kong and Korea. The Shanghai Composite was up a third of a percent, Nikkei Average also squeaking out a gain.

Meanwhile, back in the U.S., budget battle is brewing. The House expected to vote on the Senate's version of the fiscal 2018 budget later today. This move is critical as you know for the party as they move forward what the White House's call to get tax reform passed this year.

President Trump telling Lou Dobbs last night he expects the GOP to come together to get this passed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well I think we're going to get it. I think the senators are going to come together, I think the House is looking really good. They're passing this bill along very rapidly.

In fact, that's going to happen hopefully today and I did make a couple of calls. I said, "Fellows, please no changes. Just pass it along."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It may not be all smooth sailing though after all the growing controversy as lawmakers leave the door open to making changes to 401K retirement plans included in the tax bill. We're also taking a look at the deductions and the fight going on there.

President Trump blasting the democrats meanwhile, the commander-in-chief calling the funding of a dirty dossier by the Clinton campaign and DNC "disgraceful." Why he says the tables have now turned on the dems.

Meanwhile, "NBC News" analyst and author Mark Halperin is apologizing this morning after sexual assault accusations. The details after five women have come forward with harassment claims against him.

Travelers take notice, a new airport security measure is insight on all U.S. bound flight that's going into effect. One airline is making it a little easier though for you to fly. What you need to know before headed to the terminal coming up this morning.

I'm live here once again at day three of the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia this morning. We got a big panel coming up. I will be sitting down with Peter Thiel, founder of Palantier, the technology firm.

We're going to ask Peter Thiel about AI, about technology. It's another big day of exclusive news making interviews right here on the program. Among the big names I'll be speaking with, Venture Capitalist as I mentioned, Peter Thiel.

Plus, DOW Chemical CEO, Andrew Liveris is with us this morning. Bechtel Group CEO, Brendan Bechtel is here. And the CEO and President of Evercore, Ralph Schlosstein is with us. And the New York Stock Exchange President, Tom Farley as we all look to that Saudi Aramco deal with so many Wall Street want a piece of that action.

We'll talk about all of that coming up. Joining me from New York this morning, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Rosecliff CEO Managing Partner, Mike Murphy. And "The Wall Street Journal's Telecom" Reporter this morning, Ryan Knutson with us. Good morning everybody.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Maria.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER: Good morning. Nice to see you. How's the weather over there?

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, look, I want to talk about tech. The weather is gorgeous, it feels like it's all -- it's summer all the time actually. So it's pretty warm here.

But technology has not been warm, you know that. These stocks have been trading down going into this earnings period Mike. What do you think about the fact that Amazon has rolled over, Google parent Alphabet, are the expectations coming down for these tech names?

MURPHY: I don't really think so Maria. So I see it more as a basing pattern. They had these huge run ups in the first six to nine months of the year where they were up 30 percent roughly a lot of the names.

So they've had this kind of basing or even a pullback of five percent. I'm really looking forward to these earnings because I think if they continue the momentum they had these stocks are going to move to new highs.

RYAN KNUTSON, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL'S TELECOM REPORTER: There's also a little bit more concern --

BARTIROMO: What do you think Ryan?

KNUTSON: There's also a little bit more regulatory concern.

BARTIROMO: Yes, sorry.

KNUTSON: I mean we've got an administration now that is being a lot tougher on Amazon and all the pressure that they're under from a lot of the fake accounts and Russia's ability to buy ads on these platforms and there's a lot of scrutiny in Washington over these companies that might create some long-term pressure for them.

MCDOWELL: May I add one thing Maria?

BARTIROMO: Actually yes. Yes, please.

MCDOWELL: In terms of pressure from Washington, again, Kevin Brady Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, they're writing this tax bill trying to put it together.

Front page of "The Wall Street Journal" today that House republicans are still considering 401K plan changes in this tax overhaul despite what President Trump said on Twitter on Monday. I just think that this is one of the most moronic things as an investor, as a saver, as an American taxpayer that I've ever heard come out of Washington and that's saying a lot.

BARTIROMO: What's the point Dagen? I mean is it significant money that they're trying to save? I know every penny counts here given the $20 trillion debt that we're talking about and getting our arms around spending.

What is the point of making changes to 401K at the time that most Americans have no savings?

MCDOWELL: I think that it's raising -- it's a way to raise revenue in this tax overhaul. I think that some of these republicans believe that it will go unnoticed. Well I think the financial markets will not ignore it and it could cause a market crash, that's my thinking on this.

But there's a lot of data on how many people actually if they cut that $18,000 limit which is this year to say $2,400 maximum contribution of 401K plan, more than half of employees making more than $50,000 a year would be affected by that $2,400 cutoff, more than half.

BARTIROMO: People are not going to save as much, they won't be able to. And obviously they're not getting the match from their company. And we know that very -- I mean, a small percentage of people actually have the appropriate money saved for retirement which is one of the earliest lessons learned in business and investments that you have to have a nest egg for retirement.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. I know that you're hot on this because you are a saver, saver, saver.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So --

BARTIROMO: I am. And 401K included. But so are you. The two of us have that same mentality. Yes. We'll see how this plays out and we'll talk about it today with all of our guests because this is really important and it affects a lot of people.

It's also obviously the busiest day yet for third quarter earnings, let's get into that Dagen because we're waiting to hear from Comcast any moment. Expectations for the third quarter, $0.51 a share, revenue expected at $21 billion.

As we also await Twitter, the company is expected to report its third quarter earnings in the next hour as soon as these numbers come out. Obviously we're going to bring them to you. Analyst expect the social media company to report earnings of $0.06 a share on revenue of $586.7 million.

So Ryan, let's get into this here, what are you expecting when Twitter reports what should we be looking at in terms of what's most important here?

KNUTSON: Well subscriber growth is always a really key metric for Twitter. They had a huge bump after the election. There was nine million subscribers were added in the first quarter and then it was flat the quarter after that.

So -- and there's various expectations about whether there's going to be a million or maybe four million subscribers on Twitter. But one of the things here is that they haven't really been able to prove that they can make money.

If they come in at what analysts are expecting for revenue, that would be the third straight year-over-year decline in revenue for this company. They have huge engagement on the platform, it's obviously hugely important in American Fabric of Society.

You've got the president making huge re-important statements on here and that they haven't really been able to figure out how to turn a significant profit. One thing that's sort of interesting is that Square, the other company that Twitter CEO, Jack Dorsey is the CEO of is on pace to surpass Twitter in market value especially if Twitter has a rough day.

BARTIROMO: That's interesting. Meanwhile Microsoft -- I mean probably going to see a bigger impact on markets from Microsoft and from Alphabet, right?

I mean, Mike Murphy, do you expect that that's going to impact the broader markets, what we see from Microsoft and Google?

MURPHY: For sure.

BARTIROMO: And Amazon obviously.

MURPHY: Absolutely. These are the names where you've been able to invest for growth and this is where all of the big funds are heavily invested in these names.

So highly unlikely a Twitter could come in and surprise the markets for the downside. I see that's highly unlikely Amazon or Google or Microsoft disappoints the market in a big way. I think these guys are hitting on all cylinders right now.

So I expect strong quarters from all of the big tech and I think as I said earlier, I think they start to move to new highs.

BARTIROMO: And, of course, these stocks are trading up fractionally this morning. In the premarket, those companies reporting after the bell tonight.

Back in Washington Dagen, House republicans have these tax reform squarely in their sight. The Chamber set to vote today on that $4 trillion budget measure. That, of course, paves the way for tax reform but the House's top tax writer, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady says he's leaving the door open to making those changes to the 401K retirement plan.

Listen to what the president has to say about this at the White House. We've got to continue this conversation, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: 401Ks to me very important and they're important because that's one of the great benefits to the middle class. I didn't want that to go too far that's why I ended it very quickly.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Kevin Brady who was the Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said this morning it could be on the table.

I do see humans and the people that are part of these industries elevating their skills; I do see technology like we make it uptake, making them even better at what they do. And I also see a new philosophy that there's going to be winners and losers, and that's part of admiration to crown prince and kingdom, which is there's a commitment to being at the forefront and leadership role as it relates to deploying predictive analytics into industry and smart cities -- which we talked about as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right. I mean, that's something that he's committed to, I know; he said that the other day on the panel. And this is going to be probably one of most innovative cities we've ever seen, by the way.

KEYWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: But Masa, from Softbank, also was on the panel on Tuesday, and he said at some point there will be more robots than humans, you don't think so? Even if it's the same amount, it's amazing.

KEYWELL: I don't envision the city with robots -- with more robots moving around the street than people. I do envision cities that have operating systems like Uptake that are optimizing every aspect of that city, that are more environmentally responsible.

BARTIROMO: That makes sense.

KEYWELL: That is more -- the traffic moves more fluidly, that everybody's life has improved based upon people being smarter deriving data from all the ambient activities.

BARTIROMO: Is it more cost-effective, Brad, with technology, yes?

KEYWELL: What we're seeing in actual deployments in some of these industries like aviation, and rail, and construction is that the return of investment when you buy uptake's products, you're talking three, five, seven, ten returns if you're the company buying our software. So, it's an extraordinary time in the world of technology. And as an entrepreneur, to find an ability to impact real industries the way we have, that's -- that's extraordinary.

BARTIROMO: Fascinating stuff, Brad, you'll have to come back and tell us all about it.

KEYWELL: Happy to.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

KEYWELL: OK. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Brad Keywell from Uptake. We'll be right back. Stay with us live from Riyadh this morning.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

BARTIROMO: Good Thursday morning, everybody!

END
