THEIL: Yes. So I went through '99, so a lot of people are very excited and that was dangerous. But if you ask what are the things where there's, you know, what's very charismatic and the people are not paying enough attention to, I think there are these pockets and biotech that I find like that. You know, the one other one that I've been looking at a lot more have been the cryptocurrencies and one skeptical of most of them, I do think people are a little bit -- are maybe underestimating Bitcoin specifically because it is like -- it's like a reserved form of money, it's like gold and it's just a store of value.

You don't actually need to use to make payments and it's been, you know, there's about $70 billion worth of Bitcoin in the world, there's nine trillion worth of gold. And if Bitcoin ends up being the cyberequivalent of gold, it has a -- it has a -- it has a great potential left. So that's -- and it's a very different kind of thing from what people in -- people in Silicon Valley normally focus on companies, not, you know, algorithms or protocols but to -- this may be -- this may be one exception that's very underestimated.

BARTIROMO: Will people question it and I know there has been much debate about Bitcoin but they question it because what is it based on. I mean, you see that the dollar is based on, you know, the trust of the treasury, the trust of U.S. government. What is Bitcoin based on?

THEIL: Well, you know, it's based on the security of the math which tells you that it can never be -- it can never be diluted by government. It can never -- it can never be -- it can't be hacked and it's a form of money that's absolutely -- that's secure in an absolute way. And, of course, you could ask the same question about gold. That's why I use the gold analogy, say, what is gold based on, why is gold valuable?

BARTIROMO: That's true. Yes. Well, it's a tangible asset, gold.

THEIL: It's a tangible asset, but it's also hard to mine. If it was easy to mine gold then it wouldn't be that valuable, so you would just have way more gold. So, Bitcoin is also it's mineable like gold, it's hard to mine, it's actually harder to mine than gold, and so in that sense, it's more constrained, and so, yes, there are a number of things that I think make it somewhat similar to gold, and then the question is just, does this become - - does this become more widely -- more widely used.

BARTIROMO: And it's anonymous, right? I mean, that's one of the beauties of it. You can be anonymous using Bitcoin.

THEIL: Yes, it's half anonymous, half not. So, it's -- again, this intermediate thing is a question whether that's right or not but it's a bearer instrument, so if you -- if you have the Bitcoin, if you know the key, you can -- you can go anywhere most of the time most securities are registered, not bearer security, so it's a very unusual kind of a security.

BARTIROMO: Peter Theil, thanks so much for your insights today.

THEIL: Awesome. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you, Peter Thiel. Thank you, ladies and gentlemen.

MCDOWELL: That was our very own Maria Bartiromo at the Future Investment Initiative interviewing Peter Thiel Bitcoin more constrained than gold is one comment from Peter Thiel in Saudi Arabia.

Earlier this morning, Maria interviewed SoftBank's investment adviser CEO, Rajeev Misra, and discussed the company's current dealings with Uber.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What's happening with Uber right now? I know they wanted $10 billion from you?

RAJEEV MISRA, INVESTMENT ADVISER, SOFTBANK: No, Uber is not looking to take 10 billion from us. They will get 1 billion or 1-1/2 billion as primary investment. There is potentially an opportunity to provide liquidity to shareholder and employees who are early investors to sell secondary shares to SoftBank, and we are in late-stage discussions to potentially buy some secondary shares from early investors.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Maria also got his take on Alibaba and finding value in these markets. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Obviously, Alibaba has been an incredible performer for you. But when you look elsewhere, is there another Alibaba out there?

MISRA: They may not be Alibabas but we make thousand times the return, but we invested in Nvidia nine months ago. We bought five percent of Nvidia, it was close to $3 billion. It's worth 6 billion in nine months. So, you don't have to find just Alibabas to make good investments.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Mike Murphy, I want to get your reaction to both of those comments from Rajeev.

MURPHY: So, the Uber is really interesting, because, you know, so many people are talking about when is Uber going to go public? They have to go public. Well, he talks about giving the company 1 billion to 1-1/2 billion, and taking existing shareholders and employees out of their stocks, so tendering stock from people who currently own it. Sounds like kind of a public-type transaction where without going public. So, I think that's really interesting and could be the future for Unicorns. If you have these large like SoftBank raising another $100 billion funds now. If they're looking to go out to Unicorns, provide liquidity to people, that will 100 percent give Unicorns less reasons to go public.

KNUTSON: And it will take a lot of pressure off of those companies, too, because as you see when they have an IPO, suddenly they're out in the open, you can see how much money they're losing like we've seen with Snap. It might, in Uber's case, take a lot of pressure off of them so they can try to turn the company around and get their culture in place without having to have the spotlight of the public markets.

MCDOWELL: And they've got a -- they still have a fairly long road to go on that. Meantime, pretty busy morning for earnings, but is Washington really driving the market? Joining me now is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Mr. Stuart Varney. What say you, Mr. Varney?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: What say I? I'd be intrigued to hear Mike Murphy's Unicorn hunting stories. I wonder if he's ever come across a stock that he invest 3 billion into and nine months later, it's worth 6 billion. Just asking, Mike. Just asking.

MURPHY: I haven't yet, but if I do, Stuart, I'm calling you first.

VARNEY: You're a good man. I don't care what they say. All right. Onward and upward, I've been watching these earnings reports that's coming out this morning. Overall, they look pretty good, in line, with the pretty good report that we've seen so far. That's why this market is up 61 points, the Dow is going higher first thing this morning. I'm paying attention more closely to the budget vote. I expect it to be a "yes". If it's a "no," catastrophe. I'm paying attention to tonight, Amazon, Google, Microsoft, 4:00, they get their results out there. I think that's absolutely crucial to the future of the market because if any of them disappoints significantly, I think we've got a real problem here. So, it's a real high-stakes game today with the budget and the big techs, but so far, so good, we open higher.

MCDOWELL: Make it happen, Stuart.

VARNEY: Moi?

MCDOWELL: Yes. Yes.

VARNEY: Talk to Murphy. He's the one who makes things happen.

MCDOWELL: Oui, oui, Stuart, toi.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Stuart, "VARNEY & COMPANY," Monday through Friday. You can't miss him, not one minute of it in less than 10 minutes. 9:00 a.m. Eastern, "VARNEY & COMPANY." We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A well-known political analyst at NBC accused of sexual harassment. Cheryl Casone has more on this. Cheryl?

CASONE: And there's been some new developments in the story, Dagen. NBC has now suspended political analyst Mark Halperin, following accusations of sexual harassment. A number of women talked to CNN about alleged lewd behave from Halperin who co-authored the book, "Game Change." In a statement, Halperin says he pursued relationships with younger woman and he apologizes. Here is the statement, this is what he said, "During this period, I did pursue relationships with women that I worked with, including some junior to me. I now understand from these accounts that my behavior was inappropriate and caused others pain." So, we're just getting that statement in, and he continues to say, "For that, I am deeply sorry and I apologize under the circumstance, I'm going to take a step back from my day-to-day work while I properly deal with this situation." So, again, Mark Halperin has been suspended from NBC and MSNBC as well.

Well, talks between the Weinstein Company, Colony Capital have stumbled and the troubled studio may seek some other bidders. The Wall Street Journal reporting price is the main issue now despite its value falling sharply in the wake of the scandal, the board of the company is seeking more than Colony is willing to pay right now, Dagen. So those are a couple headlines we're following for you this morning. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl. And let's get right back to Maria Bartiromo at The Future Investment Initiative in Saudi Arabia. There's so much to cover from what you experienced in the last few days, Maria.

BARTIROMO: You're right, Dagen. And you know, I guess my big -- sort of, my big feeling or thought here is the fact that there is something going on here that it feels like seismic. I mean, there's a change in culture, the Crown Prince, who of course, is the future king has drawn line in the sand and basically said, look, we want to open this country, we want -- we want to live normal lives. You know, he was talking the other day onstage basically saying, we used to live normal lines before 1979 when Iran really took over. And I think that's why the Saudis and the U.S. have become friendly, and are aligned because their common enemy is Iran.

And so, I think that the Crown Prince recognizes that the world is looking at Saudi Arabia differently than he sees it, and skeptically, frankly, obviously. And so, he's trying to change that perception. We'll see if it works. There is some pushback to his plans. They're saying, look, he's moving way you too fast, some people don't want to change, they want to have women covered up, they want this -- their history to continue, he doesn't. He's 32 years old, he's the future king, and he's trying to make tremendous change. That was one thought here.

The other thought is the fact that they are using technology in incredible ways, they want autonomous cars, they want machine learning, they are putting all of the things that we talked about every day into practice here. So, we'll see, it's an experiment. We'll obviously be watching it, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: It really -- and I think the attendance there and the biggest names in investing, the heaviest hitters from around the globe, the fact that they are there kind of also spotlights on change that's happening.

BARTIROMO: For sure. And, of course, there's Saudi Aramco deal. It's going to be the largest IPO ever. It's going to be a $100-billion deal. Just to put that in perspective, Alibaba was the biggest, that was 25 billion. Saudi Aramco is going to be 100 billion, so that's why you see all of these private equity guys and investors. They want a piece of that action. We'll take a short break. When we come back, live from Riyadh and New York. Stay with Fox Business.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: That'll do it for us from Saudi Arabia. My thanks to Mike Murphy, Ryan Knutson, Dagen McDowell, we'll see you tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: Yes, come back soon, Maria, we miss you. (INAUDIBLE) were here. All right. Now --

BARTIROMO: I'm on my way. Thanks, Stu.

END

urn:contentItem:5PTC-R8K1-DXH2-6296-00000-00Tax Reform Push; Dunkin ADJ EPS Miss Estimates: $0.61 (ACT) VS $0.63 (EST); Big Tech Earnings; WSJ: House GOP Still Considering 401K Changes in Tax Overhaul; House GOP Moves to Pass Budget and Begin Debate on Tax Reform; House of GOP Considering 401K Changes in Tax Overhaul; Clinton Dossier Drama; United Upping the Ante; Paddock's Hard Drive Lost; Anti- Trump Dossier; Astros Win Dramatic Game 2; Author Harassment Claims; DOW Chemical CEO on NAFTA; UPS Earnings; Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Plans to Launch NEOM by 2030; Solving the Opioid Crisis; Halperin Harassment Charge2017-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTAndrew Liveris, Brendan Bechtel, Brad KeywellNEWSFinancial102601cb.231Tax Reform Push; Dunkin ADJ EPS Miss Estimates: $0.61 (ACT) VS $0.63 (EST); Big Tech Earnings; WSJ: House GOP Still Considering 401K Changes in Tax Overhaul; House GOP Moves to Pass Budget and Begin Debate on Tax Reform; House of GOP Considering 401K Changes in Tax Overhaul; Clinton Dossier Drama; United Upping the Ante; Paddock's Hard Drive Lost; Anti- Trump Dossier; Astros Win Dramatic Game 2; Author Harassment Claims; DOW Chemical CEO on NAFTA; UPS Earnings; Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Plans to Launch NEOM by 2030; Solving the Opioid Crisis; Halperin Harassment ChargeMaria Bartiromo; Dagen McDowell; Mike Murphy; Ryan Knutson; Cheryl Casone

ANNOUNCER (voice-over): Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of "Mornings With Maria."

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Thursday morning everybody. It is Thursday, October 26th. Thanks so much for joining us, happy Thursday. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

An earnings extravaganza today in business, among the top names reporting before the bell, Twitter, Ford Motor, UPS, and Comcast. It does not stop there, we got a big night tonight. We are expected to hear from Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet parent of Google.

Of course tech stocks have been trading down ahead of these numbers, we will have all of the numbers and analysis as they hit the tapes. Stay with us on this, that will likely set the tone for markets.

Take a look at Futures right now ahead of all of that, unchanged on the DOW Jones Industrial Average, very fractional moves for the S&P500 down not even a point. Nasdaq Composite up not even a point.

Checking the action in Europe this morning, stocks are higher in the European zone. FTSE100 up a third of a percent as the CAC Krones is in Paris and the DAX Index in Germany as well up about 38 points in Germany.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher, take a look at the indices there with the exception of Hong Kong and Korea. The Shanghai Composite was up a third of a percent, Nikkei Average also squeaking out a gain.

Meanwhile, back in the U.S., budget battle is brewing. The House expected to vote on the Senate's version of the fiscal 2018 budget later today. This move is critical as you know for the party as they move forward what the White House's call to get tax reform passed this year.

President Trump telling Lou Dobbs last night he expects the GOP to come together to get this passed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well I think we're going to get it. I think the senators are going to come together, I think the House is looking really good. They're passing this bill along very rapidly.

In fact, that's going to happen hopefully today and I did make a couple of calls. I said, "Fellows, please no changes. Just pass it along."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It may not be all smooth sailing though after all the growing controversy as lawmakers leave the door open to making changes to 401K retirement plans included in the tax bill. We're also taking a look at the deductions and the fight going on there.

President Trump blasting the democrats meanwhile, the commander-in-chief calling the funding of a dirty dossier by the Clinton campaign and DNC "disgraceful." Why he says the tables have now turned on the dems.

Meanwhile, "NBC News" analyst and author Mark Halperin is apologizing this morning after sexual assault accusations. The details after five women have come forward with harassment claims against him.

Travelers take notice, a new airport security measure is insight on all U.S. bound flight that's going into effect. One airline is making it a little easier though for you to fly. What you need to know before headed to the terminal coming up this morning.

I'm live here once again at day three of the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia this morning. We got a big panel coming up. I will be sitting down with Peter Thiel, founder of Palantier, the technology firm.

We're going to ask Peter Thiel about AI, about technology. It's another big day of exclusive news making interviews right here on the program. Among the big names I'll be speaking with, Venture Capitalist as I mentioned, Peter Thiel.

Plus, DOW Chemical CEO, Andrew Liveris is with us this morning. Bechtel Group CEO, Brendan Bechtel is here. And the CEO and President of Evercore, Ralph Schlosstein is with us. And the New York Stock Exchange President, Tom Farley as we all look to that Saudi Aramco deal with so many Wall Street want a piece of that action.

We'll talk about all of that coming up. Joining me from New York this morning, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Rosecliff CEO Managing Partner, Mike Murphy. And "The Wall Street Journal's Telecom" Reporter this morning, Ryan Knutson with us. Good morning everybody.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Maria.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER: Good morning. Nice to see you. How's the weather over there?

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, look, I want to talk about tech. The weather is gorgeous, it feels like it's all -- it's summer all the time actually. So it's pretty warm here.

But technology has not been warm, you know that. These stocks have been trading down going into this earnings period Mike. What do you think about the fact that Amazon has rolled over, Google parent Alphabet, are the expectations coming down for these tech names?

MURPHY: I don't really think so Maria. So I see it more as a basing pattern. They had these huge run ups in the first six to nine months of the year where they were up 30 percent roughly a lot of the names.

So they've had this kind of basing or even a pullback of five percent. I'm really looking forward to these earnings because I think if they continue the momentum they had these stocks are going to move to new highs.

RYAN KNUTSON, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL'S TELECOM REPORTER: There's also a little bit more concern --

BARTIROMO: What do you think Ryan?

KNUTSON: There's also a little bit more regulatory concern.

BARTIROMO: Yes, sorry.

KNUTSON: I mean we've got an administration now that is being a lot tougher on Amazon and all the pressure that they're under from a lot of the fake accounts and Russia's ability to buy ads on these platforms and there's a lot of scrutiny in Washington over these companies that might create some long-term pressure for them.

MCDOWELL: May I add one thing Maria?

BARTIROMO: Actually yes. Yes, please.

MCDOWELL: In terms of pressure from Washington, again, Kevin Brady Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, they're writing this tax bill trying to put it together.

Front page of "The Wall Street Journal" today that House republicans are still considering 401K plan changes in this tax overhaul despite what President Trump said on Twitter on Monday. I just think that this is one of the most moronic things as an investor, as a saver, as an American taxpayer that I've ever heard come out of Washington and that's saying a lot.

BARTIROMO: What's the point Dagen? I mean is it significant money that they're trying to save? I know every penny counts here given the $20 trillion debt that we're talking about and getting our arms around spending.

What is the point of making changes to 401K at the time that most Americans have no savings?

MCDOWELL: I think that it's raising -- it's a way to raise revenue in this tax overhaul. I think that some of these republicans believe that it will go unnoticed. Well I think the financial markets will not ignore it and it could cause a market crash, that's my thinking on this.

But there's a lot of data on how many people actually if they cut that $18,000 limit which is this year to say $2,400 maximum contribution of 401K plan, more than half of employees making more than $50,000 a year would be affected by that $2,400 cutoff, more than half.

BARTIROMO: People are not going to save as much, they won't be able to. And obviously they're not getting the match from their company. And we know that very -- I mean, a small percentage of people actually have the appropriate money saved for retirement which is one of the earliest lessons learned in business and investments that you have to have a nest egg for retirement.

MCDOWELL: Thank you. I know that you're hot on this because you are a saver, saver, saver.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So --

BARTIROMO: I am. And 401K included. But so are you. The two of us have that same mentality. Yes. We'll see how this plays out and we'll talk about it today with all of our guests because this is really important and it affects a lot of people.

It's also obviously the busiest day yet for third quarter earnings, let's get into that Dagen because we're waiting to hear from Comcast any moment. Expectations for the third quarter, $0.51 a share, revenue expected at $21 billion.

As we also await Twitter, the company is expected to report its third quarter earnings in the next hour as soon as these numbers come out. Obviously we're going to bring them to you. Analyst expect the social media company to report earnings of $0.06 a share on revenue of $586.7 million.

So Ryan, let's get into this here, what are you expecting when Twitter reports what should we be looking at in terms of what's most important here?

KNUTSON: Well subscriber growth is always a really key metric for Twitter. They had a huge bump after the election. There was nine million subscribers were added in the first quarter and then it was flat the quarter after that.

So -- and there's various expectations about whether there's going to be a million or maybe four million subscribers on Twitter. But one of the things here is that they haven't really been able to prove that they can make money.

If they come in at what analysts are expecting for revenue, that would be the third straight year-over-year decline in revenue for this company. They have huge engagement on the platform, it's obviously hugely important in American Fabric of Society.

You've got the president making huge re-important statements on here and that they haven't really been able to figure out how to turn a significant profit. One thing that's sort of interesting is that Square, the other company that Twitter CEO, Jack Dorsey is the CEO of is on pace to surpass Twitter in market value especially if Twitter has a rough day.

BARTIROMO: That's interesting. Meanwhile Microsoft -- I mean probably going to see a bigger impact on markets from Microsoft and from Alphabet, right?

I mean, Mike Murphy, do you expect that that's going to impact the broader markets, what we see from Microsoft and Google?

MURPHY: For sure.

BARTIROMO: And Amazon obviously.

MURPHY: Absolutely. These are the names where you've been able to invest for growth and this is where all of the big funds are heavily invested in these names.

So highly unlikely a Twitter could come in and surprise the markets for the downside. I see that's highly unlikely Amazon or Google or Microsoft disappoints the market in a big way. I think these guys are hitting on all cylinders right now.

So I expect strong quarters from all of the big tech and I think as I said earlier, I think they start to move to new highs.

BARTIROMO: And, of course, these stocks are trading up fractionally this morning. In the premarket, those companies reporting after the bell tonight.

Back in Washington Dagen, House republicans have these tax reform squarely in their sight. The Chamber set to vote today on that $4 trillion budget measure. That, of course, paves the way for tax reform but the House's top tax writer, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady says he's leaving the door open to making those changes to the 401K retirement plan.

Listen to what the president has to say about this at the White House. We've got to continue this conversation, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

I do see humans and the people that are part of these industries elevating their skills; I do see technology like we make it uptake, making them even better at what they do. And I also see a new philosophy that there's going to be winners and losers, and that's part of admiration to crown prince and kingdom, which is there's a commitment to being at the forefront and leadership role as it relates to deploying predictive analytics into industry and smart cities -- which we talked about as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right. I mean, that's something that he's committed to, I know; he said that the other day on the panel. And this is going to be probably one of most innovative cities we've ever seen, by the way.

KEYWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: But Masa, from Softbank, also was on the panel on Tuesday, and he said at some point there will be more robots than humans, you don't think so? Even if it's the same amount, it's amazing.

KEYWELL: I don't envision the city with robots -- with more robots moving around the street than people. I do envision cities that have operating systems like Uptake that are optimizing every aspect of that city, that are more environmentally responsible.

BARTIROMO: That makes sense.

KEYWELL: That is more -- the traffic moves more fluidly, that everybody's life has improved based upon people being smarter deriving data from all the ambient activities.

BARTIROMO: Is it more cost-effective, Brad, with technology, yes?

KEYWELL: What we're seeing in actual deployments in some of these industries like aviation, and rail, and construction is that the return of investment when you buy uptake's products, you're talking three, five, seven, ten returns if you're the company buying our software. So, it's an extraordinary time in the world of technology. And as an entrepreneur, to find an ability to impact real industries the way we have, that's -- that's extraordinary.

BARTIROMO: Fascinating stuff, Brad, you'll have to come back and tell us all about it.

KEYWELL: Happy to.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

KEYWELL: OK. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Brad Keywell from Uptake. We'll be right back. Stay with us live from Riyadh this morning.

ANNOUNCER: Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

BARTIROMO: Good Thursday morning, everybody!

urn:contentItem:5DTC-CYD1-JDPT-T2D4-00000-00TAYLOR RHODES, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, RACKSPACE HOSTING IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING BUSINESS2014-12-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisTAYLOR RHODES, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, RACKSPACE HOSTING IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING BUSINESS

December 9, 2014

NEWS PROGRAM

TAYLOR RHODES, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, RACKSPACE HOSTING

GUY JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Let's carry on talking about tech. Let's carry on talking about cloud. The race for control of the cloud very much on at the moment. Big tech companies getting into the space, driving down prices. As ever, it's the survival of the fittest. Will the lesser known names manage to stay competitive and in business?

Rackspace Hosting has had a challenging couple years, but with shares up last night, investors a little bit more upbeat about this cloud computing company. So how did the company weather the storm and what happens next? Its CEO is a gentleman called Taylor Rhodes, and he's sitting next to me. Good morning.

TAYLOR RHODES, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, RACKSPACE HOSTING: Good morning, Guy.

JOHNSON: Tough to be small in a - in an increasing big world?

RHODES: Well I think you can look at examples in industries that evolve over time. And you've always got the bulk players, the volume players, and you've got the specialists who are in profitable niches. You've got lots of news this morning about Tescos, but at the same time Waitrose is doing quite well. So in any industry, there is the bulk volume and then there's the specialty play. And Rackspace has always been the specialist in the industry that adds value on top of commodity infrastructure.

JOHNSON: Nice line drawing there between one and the other. It's - it's a fair point to make, and in some ways if you were to go back to that Waitrose analogy, Waitrose is a more managed story.

RHODES: Absolutely.

JOHNSON: Tescos is a - some would say a less manage story in store. You just throw everything in there and - and hopefully people will buy it. Is this a divergence we're now going to see between managed cloud storage and unmanaged cloud storage? These are effectively two different businesses.

RHODES: They are, and I think that's the takeaway. The first five years of cloud - cloud really got started in 2008 and '09 because global financial crisis meant people had to shed costs. Risk tolerance for trying new models was on, but the early five years of cloud were really driven by developers, software engineers who said, the CIO, he's too slow. I want to solve a problem a new way. Here's something where I can buy it on a utility basis. It's available now. I can go develop. But really those developers, the early adopters are very technologically savvy. They want to play with the technology.

But now the mainstream market, as it always does, is starting to say cloud is compelling. Different economics. It makes infrastructure available. How am I going to use it? I may not have all of those tech skills on my payroll. So you're going to see this unmanaged model where you have technically savvy people who want to control more, and you're going to see the mainstream market prefer a managed cloud model that infrastructure is a component, but how do you manage it?

The other interesting thing is as commodity continues to creep into cloud and prices get cheaper for the inputs, that's software and that's hardware, what's going to proliferate are tools and software that take advantage of the ubiquity of cheap infrastructure which creates complexity for mainstream companies. They have a hard time keeping up with the tech skills required to manage the cloud themselves. So we'll see this transition from early adoption, which was unmanaged cloud, to mainstream adoption, which is managed cloud.

JOHNSON: Shall I think about this as hardware and software? I -

RHODES: And service.

JOHNSON: Yeah. So it's a kind of a service. You are the service option. They - they are the kind of - they are the hardware option, and - and - and how different do those two markets become?

RHODES: I think that if you - if you think about a traditional software company, let's just talk about SaaS or cloud-delivered software. You think about a Microsoft or a VMWare. They used to sell you a license. You bought it as a - as a thing that you paid a price for (inaudible) paid a perpetual maintenance license on.

And now because the cloud has said, well we're going to tip that model over, we don't like that model anymore, it doesn't fit the cost structure that we want to drive in our businesses, we want to make technology utility or usage-based pricing. Software is going to be monetized more and more in cloud service models. So we take inputs from Microsoft, VMWare and other providers of hardware and software. We build a cloud service model around them and we deliver that technology in a service context to our customers.

JOHNSON: So you're more IBM?

RHODES: Well, I think it's a - it's a good model for the free cloud era. I think in the cloud era our model looks more like IBM from a service management perspective delivering value on top of commodity infrastructure.

JOHNSON: When you look at the - sort of the potential for your business further down the road, how different is it in the United States and how different is it here in Europe? We were talking to our last guest from Google about the differences that exist between the adoption of cloud, the concern surrounding cloud, and the regulatory story surrounding cloud here in Europe versus the United States. How different is it?

RHODES: It's quite different, and I think Barack (ph) from Google made a great point, which is because Europe isn't one homogenous thing, it is lots of different countries together, you naturally have the friction and complexity of those different models looking at data privacy, looking at the consumer, and trying to plan the right policy.

But inevitably, because it's a more complex environment, it will move more slowly. There will be frictions built in, versus more - pardon me. I meant to say it is more of a heterogeneous market where the US is more of a homogenous market. There's a common policy and framework. And so you always see the US markets 18 to 24 months ahead of - of the European market in terms of technology adoption, and I think that's one of the reasons why.

JOHNSON: Is that just a structural impediment that we're just - we're going to have to get used to in Europe, or is it something that we can deal with, find a way around and move on from?

RHODES: I think as with anything, if you think about ecommerce years ago, people were very hesitant to buy online. They were afraid someone was going to steal their - their credit card number. But it's matured. It's evolved, and now it's a very accepted business model. Cloud will do the same thing. I think it will just develop at pace. As things like compliancy and standards get addressed in cloud models, that will accelerate adoption.

My hope is that governments here take a very technology and business-friendly approach to cloud because cloud really does speed the innovation of business.

JOHNSON: Is that hope over expectation? Do you - over reality? What do you think is really going to happen? That's your hope. What do you think is going to happen?

RHODES: Well I don't have a crystal ball on Brussels, but I do think it will take - it'll take longer. But if you look at cloud adoption, the US is arguably a couple of years ahead further into this. But I moved to London in 2010, spent three years here, and I can tell you that the inflection curve started to catch up. So as the economics of cloud get more and more compelling, you're going to see a larger and larger din from the business marketplace to treat it with fair policies.

JOHNSON: Just one final question on security. Security seems to be a bigger issue over here as well, though arguably that shouldn't be the case. Do you think businesses understand the cloud yet? Do you think that we fully have grasped what we're doing in terms of what effectively is the - the crown jewels of our business, data? Every company now, its data is everything. We're handing it over to you. Do I as a - as a CEO understand what I'm giving you do you think at this stage?

RHODES: I think that markets go through hype and then wisdom, and the cloud market has gone through tremendous hype. Even the word cloud has been so overhyped. It's become shorthand for buying computing as a service essentially, but there's - underneath the covers there's lots of different ways. The market is evolving with a preference for what's called hybrid cloud. That means some things will be in a private cloud context which you can manage with a partner or yourself for solely your environment.

You don't share the tin (ph) or the computing or networking with anybody else. And then there's also public cloud, which is generally the model that a Google would field which is it's shared pools of compute and networking and storage spread over many customers. So what's happening in the market as it goes from hype to wisdom, it's saying private clouds have a real role where data security and privacy and performance of high - hard-hitting databases, but then also the ability to use public cloud right along side for things that are highly variable matter.

I'll give you a good example. Our customer in the UK, Domino's Pizza, every Tuesday night for the football they run an offer. And they used to have build out physical infrastructure every time they had a very high spike in volume, right? Now that they can use the cloud, they say, right, I'm concerned about data privacy for my consumer's credit cards. I'm going to run that in a private cloud. I'm going to connect that into a public cloud for burstability. Therefore I don't have to buy the peak. I can pay for the base of the business. I can rent the peak, pay for what I use and then turn it off. So that's a very good example of a mainstream market application of hybrid cloud.

JOHNSON: Using pizzas as the - as the story. Nice to see you, Taylor. Thank you very much indeed for stopping by.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Hello. Yes. Okay. All right. So good afternoon, again, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Annual Capital Markets Day of TBC Bank. My name is Zoltan Szalai, I'm the Director of International Media and Investor Relations of the bank. So we're very delighted that all of you could join us on this somewhat strange sunny and rainy day here in London. We also welcome the -- those who are joining through the webcast.

As you can see, we have a very packed schedule for this afternoon. But the good news is we'll have a break in about 2 hours' time. And then we'll carry on until about 6:00 p.m. And after 6:00 p.m., there'll be traditional and always very much appreciated and successful Georgian wine tasting. But now I think let's turn to business. I'd like to invite to the stage the Chairman of TBC Bank and one of the Founders, Mamuka Khazaradze, to make his sort of introduction.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Thank you, Mamuka. Now I would like to invite our Deputy Chairman and the other Co-Founder of the bank, Badri Japaridze.

BADRI JAPARIDZE, DEPUTY CHAIRMAN, TBC BANK GROUP PLC: Thank you. Good afternoon. So I'm happy to be again with you after 1 year of having -- announcing some of the -- and I'm glad to report that the country is performing as well as it was performing before, and I will highlight some of the new trends and new achievements Georgia has -- can be proud of.

So in order to understand the reasons of success of TBC Bank, we need to understand better operating environment we are operating in last 25 years and dynamics and improvements of this environment, which has resulted in the achievements of our institution. First of all, of course, the country has made a long way in its development. And there is still long way to go, but we can say that Georgia can be proud to be one of the most attractive destinations, investment destinations in the region and beyond. So Georgia continues its remarkable progress towards being one of the most attractive investment destination, and we are among the highest-ranking countries in many regards. Today, Georgia ranks #6 in ease of doing business globally, up from #9 in 2018. This is a reflection of being #2 in ease of starting business, #4 in ease of registering property, #2 in protecting minority investors, also countries among top performance in several other key rankings.

What is I think quite a good achievement that features upgraded country recently to BB level. And so we are pretty close to the investment-grade ranking. On Open Budget Index globally, we are #5; Economic Freedom Index, #16. And Georgia always was one of the most compared to the countries in regard of success and regime and remains as most competitive. And we are -- basically, after the last tax reform when we invested profit been -- related on taxes, we can say that success and regime got even more liberal. Another positive dynamics is Georgia's continuously improving credit rating, as I have mentioned. Improving risk perception of the country reflects proven resilience of the economy towards unfavorable external developments, which, unfortunately, taking place in our neighborhood. But what is important that we are less and less dependent on those negative developments in the neighborhood and this is because of the diversified character of Georgian economy. Good news is also narrowing current account deficit. And overall, Georgia was always famous recent -- especially last 10 to 15 years by prudent monitor and fiscal stance. Georgian lari is free float in currency. We can say that Georgian lari is among the best-performing emerging countries' currencies. Last 1 year, National Bank also improved. It was buying more reserves and has increased foreign currency reserves by 18%.

Towards this constant inflow of FDI last 10 to 15 years, we see the same trend despite of the fact that big infrastructure project, British Petroleum, has completed. Still, we see the growth of FDI.

Good news is on the GDP growth. So in April, 5.1% growth was reported. So in average, from the beginning of this year, GDP grew by 4.8%. It is very much likely that by end of the year, GDP will grow by 5%.

As I mentioned, business trend environment is one of the explanations why Georgian economy remains resilient, and it also drives FDI growth -- FDI flow in Georgia. And what is important that, of course, our neighborhood is not easy. But I think Georgia was, as a country, smart enough to consider this neighborhood as more opportunity than as difficult and to benefit from this not easy environment. We, as a country, are operating in -- are located. We can say that Georgian economy is more aligned with the Central and Eastern European countries while having higher growth rates. According to IMF, Georgian economy is expected to outperform CE and neighboring countries over the next 5 years.

Overall, we can witness increasing diversification and shift towards EU as a trend. And what is important that despite more integration into EU, Georgia is very open to increase its trade with new markets, especially with Middle East and China. And that's also -- is reflected in increasing FDI from those countries. We can see that the traditional drivers of Georgian -- growth of Georgian economy, traditional industries, especially tourists, which, every year, is beating new highs, new record highs. Just recently was published a number that year-on-year basis, tourists grew by 18%. And it looks like that Georgia is becoming one of the most popular destinations. And the 10 million number for tourists per year looks like it's easy to achieve in nearest future. So also, we have seen the growth on remittances side. And overall, we can say the inflows grew by 18.7%.

We need to highlight that when inflows to GDP ratio stands at around 70% and the natural level of loan dollarization should not be 0. While dollarization is a priority and the -- we are in a process to dedollarize economy in the banking sector high share of external inflows and therefore -- actually, therefore, FX income stream always has to be taken into account. And because of the new regulations and the steps taken by the National Bank of Georgia, we have seen that dollarization level is gradually going down. You see that there is a steady growth of remittances in the tourists, and what is important trend is quite a significant growth on export side.

Because we remain as one of the most attractive investment destination, we see FDI inflow not going down but is increasing. If we take out the impact of the year, infrastructure project completed by the British Petroleum, there are new infrastructure projects coming in. We need to mention, of course, deep sea and -- we have deep sea port Anaklia project, which is in the process of active development. There is a high ratio -- meaning to say that Georgian tradition maintains one of the highest FDI to GDP ratio when compared to the peer countries. This demonstrates the preference of investors and their long-term commitments to the economy of Georgia. Important to mention that FDI inflows are invested across wide range of sectors and more than half of the foreign investments comes from EU. And also here, we need to speak about diversified character of FDI inflow. And of course, there are more popular destinations like tourism, hospitality business, energy sector, but we see more and more investments in other directions as well. In the -- I think quite long time ago, some Georgian politicians were comparing Georgia to Singapore. And it looks like that this comparison has some ground because if you look at the similarities between Singapore and Georgia, there are certain similarities, especially having large neighbors. I think it's important to mention then that Singapore was taking advantage of this, being surrounded by large neighbors. And Georgia, we see, it is trying to repeat this experience. But if you look at doing business rankings, also there's a similarity between Georgia and Singapore. And also, if you look at the role of FDI inflows and the current account deficit, there is also similarity. As you might know, in '70s and '80s, Singapore had high FDI inflows coupled with high current account deficit. If a country receives high inflows, the only way to avoid a current account deficit is to reinvest those inflows abroad. According to the Chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore in 1970s and 1980s when Asia was rising, Singapore and South Korea had large and sustainable current account deficit -- deficits as global financiers saw that there were investment opportunities created. So Georgia -- and I was saying it during previous -- my presentations that Georgia is increasingly playing the role of the hub, regional hub in many regards: as a transit hub, and looks like the dysfunction will be enhanced by the new infrastructure projects, which are put in place; as a financial hub, because of the strong and very resilient banking industry; as educational hub, and government is committing to invest significant amount in educational system in coming years, which will more enhance and make it -- will make Georgian education system more attractive for foreign students, and we see that there is also significant increase of the foreign students coming to Georgia for education; and health care hub, and we can say that there is lot of investment going on -- going into the health care system as well; and Georgia, because of location, is logistical hub, and we'll enhance this role in the future.

Let me speak about Georgian banking industry in a few words. I think we went through this. That's again coming back to Georgia's role as a regional hub in all this respect, which I just mentioned. So Georgian banking sector, I think not many much larger countries can be proud having 2 leading backs -- banks listed in the Premium Listing, the London Stock Exchange. And not many, many banking industries navigated through so many challenges Georgian banking industry has navigated. And there was no any single bailout. We can say, therefore, that banking sector in Georgia is one of the most developed in the broader region, taking into account corporate governance, risk management, capital and liquidity levels as well as digitalization. And the Georgian banking sector is appealing industry to be an -- and generates high profitability and sustainable growth.

Of course, we need to mention the sector is conservatively regulated by National Bank of Georgia and has sound asset quality. On the asset quality side, we can say that the level of NPLs to growth loan is pretty low. It's 2.7% as of quarter 1 2018. One of the lowest level in comparison to CE and other peer countries. Prudent capital level. Together with sound asset quality, prudently regulated banking sector in Georgia results in high ratio of capital to total assets in the region, which ensures the stable and lower-risk banking environments in the country. Solid profitability. And solid profitability is emphasizing an attractiveness in Georgian banking sector. TBC Bank is delivering close totally more than 20% return on equity.

And to summarize the presentation -- as a concluding remark, let me say that while business-friendly environment and high growth rates have already been the features of Georgia, the resilience demonstrated towards the external shocks proved doing business in Georgia to be sustainable as well. This provides solid operational environment for the financial services. Thank you for your attention.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Thank you, Badri. Our next speaker is our CEO, Vakhtang Butskhrikidze, who will give you an overview of our strategic initiatives.

VAKHTANG BUTSKHRIKIDZE, CEO & EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, TBC BANK GROUP PLC: Thank you, Zoltan. Once again, thank you for attending this event.

During my presentation, I will discuss major events over the past year, give an update on our medium-term financial guidance and present our new initiatives and our vision going forward. I'd like to begin today's presentation with a recap of our financial guidance and our performance during the last 2 years. I'm happy to say that we achieved and even outperformed all our targets that we announced after our Premium Listing in 2018 was an especially successful year. Our loan book growth reached 21.3% against our target of approximately 15%. We delivered high full year return of equity, 22.8%, against our target of 20%. Our underlying cost-to-income ratio was 37.8% against our target of below 40%. And we continue to distribute 25% of our net profit as dividends.

Now I'd like to briefly review our bank's important achievements for the last year. We further improved our outstanding digital capabilities and achieved offloading ratio of 90.6%. We continue to increase on our fee income. Our payment business is an important area of our focus. And at the end of the first quarter of 2019, 80% of all transactions we have conducted in POS, terminals and ATMs. TBC Insurance has maintained its #1 position on the retail market with 38% market share, an increase of 9 percentage points from last year. Our first fully digital bank, Space, launched in May 2018. And we already have approximately 115,000 active customers. We launched the first ecosystems in Georgia with e-commerce marketplace and real estate platform. We have achieved further progress on our international expansion plans by signing shareholder agreement with Nikoil Bank in Azerbaijan. And finally, we also -- in line with our international expansion plans, we acquired the leading payment service provider, PayMe, in Uzbekistan, now serving approximately 1.3 million customers in this market.

During the last year, we also maintained our leadership in digital channels with our best-in-class multichannel distribution platform. As you can see on this slide, we have continued to increase mobile banking penetration impressively past 2 years. We achieved particularly authentic results in mobile banking in 2018. We see the number of mobile banking transactions increasing more over than 70%. And as I have mentioned, offloading ratio continue to increase impressively. And as you see on the right-hand side of this slide, only less than 10% of the transactions we are doing in the branches.

Payment business is a strategic initiative that has key importance for our group. As an example of our achievement in that area, we had more than 60 million contactless transactions during 2018, which is around 95% of total POS transactions. And additionally, as you can see, we also introduced contactless withdrawals from ATMs, which is a novelty on the Georgian market and also in the region. And today, around 30% all the ATM transactions we are doing through -- by the contactless transactions.

As you know, about 2 years ago, we decided to enter underpenetrated insurance business in Georgia. And after 2 years of the operations, TBC Insurance has grown impressively. We continue to dominate retail market with 38 -- almost 38% market share at the end of the last year and around 40% market share at the end of the first quarter.

As you know, Space is our new full-scale digital bank. With this project, we are successfully challenging and redefining the daily banking experience. As you can see from this slide, over the past year, we have already achieved impressive growth in the number of downloads and registered customers and also -- as well as the good growth in the portfolio. Today, we have application downloads around 300,000, around 115,000 active customers and more than GEL 16 million lari portfolio.

Now I'd like to present our new vision, which is to make life easier for our customers. We plan to achieve this through 5 key strategic initiatives: core financial products, big data analytics, ecosystems, becoming an agile organization and international expansion in Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan. By implementing this, we plan to have 10 million users by 2022. I will describe these key strategic directions briefly in my presentation and will elaborate further on each front later today.

To achieve these challenging strategic initiatives, we need more changes and we decided to start agile transformation in November of the last year. And additionally, we believe that it is important to become agile because first, the environment is changing very fast and we have to adapt. Second, we are very fast changing and growing organization. Third, we need to be quick in responding to our customer needs. Fourth, we need to put our customer needs at the center of our work. And finally, with the agile transformation project, we want to create an exceptional work environment for our employees to increase engagement and to attract the best talent.

Now I'd like to show a brief video about how we are transferring our organization to the agile.

(presentation)
