TORNIKE GOGICHAISHVILI, DEPUTY CEO, COO & MEMBER OF MANAGEMENT BOARD, JSC TBC BANK: Thank you, everyone, for coming.

Today, I'll be talking about our ecosystem strategy, why it is actually in our agenda and how we're going to take advantage of it going forward. So I'll cover payment business and how we're going to play with the new perspective on the payment business in the context of the ecosystem and our new initiative on the housing sector.

But before I start, I would like set this context briefly. It is super exciting time to be alive. The environment around us is changing rapidly and, as Vakh already mentioned, we need to adapt fast. The incumbent players are becoming super competitive. They are changing the current linear business models to exponential growth models. And the recently clear boundaries among different industries are disappearing. And we see a play of examples like the eco going into the payments using the -- and leveraging on the brand and the ecosystem it has. The same attempts from the Facebook and many, many others, like telcos buying the digital content providers. So on the back office furthermost of the transformation, which is mostly driven by data and connectivity expanding the boundaries, the customers are also becoming super sophisticated. They are valuing simplicity like frictionless transactions, the control over their accounts, the transparency and so on and so forth. That's exactly why we think that ecosystem perspective is the best way to address growing consumer needs and that will enable us to come up with a holistic end-to-end customer journeys. We are actually already in the daily lives of our customers, but we need to connect more deeply to be more responsive and to be more fast in terms of the time-to-market. And also, one important aspects I really want to mention and the key differentiator perhaps that the banks and financial institutions have is a trust. Trust, especially when it comes to making a financial transaction. So that's why we believe we're going to be successful in building the ecosystems.

Now let's talk about the payments. The payment business have always been a significant part of our banking, and we're now -- not talking about something really new. But as I already mentioned, just a new perspective on it and how we're going to play with it. So according to the figures, by the end of 2018, the net revenues from the payment business contributed to 10% to our overall gross net revenues. So as you see, it's quite a significant number. In terms of the growth rates, we also have quite impressive growth rates, both in terms of the number of payments and number of volumes. As you see from the slide, we have double-digit growth rates in both cases. And in this business, TBC is a long-established market leader. Like in e-commerce and POS transaction volumes, we are 84% more than our closest competitor. We have the largest acquiring network, which, of course, brings revenues for us in terms of the fee and commissions, but also is a very important source of our liquidity. And of course, the mobile and Internet banking transactions. We are 44% more than our closest competitor. Did you know that banks are on the second place after social media in terms of the average number of touch points? It was quite surprising for us as well in data statistic. So but more importantly, the 90% of these touch points are payment-related. That's why we feel that we're -- we may be missing something, and we need to build up on an ecosystem perspective and take a full advantage of it to be more close to the customers and be responsive, as I already mentioned.

So now to give you the idea of where is the growth coming from and why we think that we will be able to grow the revenues in the multiple directions, let's discuss the 3 core pillars: the first one is the infrastructure; the second one is the market potential; and the third one is the opportunity for us to change the customer behavior.

So in terms of the payment business physical infrastructure, Georgia is at par with most of the CE countries. As you see, the infrastructure has been growing over the years. However, in terms of the average transaction frequency and the average transaction value, Georgia still falls short of its peer countries in CE. But apparently, it is also a good news because we anticipate a growth potential here as well, especially by focusing on changing our customer behavior from using the ATM cash withdrawals heavily to moving them to more sophisticated payment solutions where we could earn more revenues. And now to continue the topic on the growth potentials from the TBC perspective, let's discuss it on our case, right?

So on a comparative scale in a country with population of 3.5 million people, TBC has unique and active clients over 1 million users. It is quite significant. And on top of it, 0.5 million unregistered customers, which mostly are using our network of self-service terminals, so called kiosks, right, to make the small ticket size transactions like mobile top-ups, small loan repayments, utility payments and so on and so forth. So we see a unique opportunity to get more engaged with those -- our registered customers and offer our digital payment solutions, which are of course more handy and an opportunity for us to earn more money as well.

So in terms of the average transaction frequency and the average transaction value, TBC figures are basically way above the country average figures. Although -- and they are growing quite fast as you see the 40% growth on the year over and the 25% respectively, right? But the interesting part is that more than 50% of these transactions are ATM cash withdrawals, which are attributable to the TBC retail banking payroll-related customers. So as you see, the customers withdraw their money from the very first week as long as they get salary. So we see a huge opportunity again to switch it with behavior. And of course, this behavior is naturally changing over the time.

This is our Georgia part in terms of the opportunities, but of course we are not going to stop here, and our aspiration is to become the regional payments provider rather than just a local bank. And in that regard, we already made a first step and we acquired the payment company in Uzbekistan country, which population is 33 million people and my colleague, Giorgi Shagidze, will cover this topic in detail later on.

Yet another ecosystems that we're tapping -- sorry, let me sum up the payments. So basically, the high-level numbers and the key targets that Vakhtang already shared with you, we're going to double our net revenues from the payment business by 2022, and that will be more than GEL 200 million, with an average growth rate of 20% annually, and we decided to, as you already understood, we decided to put the payment business to our strategic priority. And in terms of the actions, this strategy translated into established dedicated business structure, dedicated business line, with the consolidation of all the management, all the talent and leadership into one vertical. They're putting the sales directed end-to-end teams into this vertical, which are going to be responsible for each of our segments like corporate, MSME and retail business. Of course, the innovation factor, which is actually very much embedded in our culture, and we believe is one of the key factors to success especially when we talk about the payment business. And in that regard, TBC has been first on the market to introduce many innovative products, like P2P payments, voice transfers, contactless cash withdrawals. And these are not just innovations, these innovations are actually bringing the money. And, of course, we have a very long pipeline. And of course, our aspiration is to become the regional payment provider.

Well, now I'm certainly done with the payment part, and let me now switch to yet another ecosystem, the other initiative is housing. So why housing platform and how it's related to our strategy? Well, basically, the logic is same, right? So we need to be closer with our customers. And the real estate marketplace is offering huge opportunities and all the services it needs associated with it to get more engaged with it -- with the users and create the end-to-end journeys, basically to pool all off-line and online assets on one platform and create multiple combinations of the business models that would add value, right? Because in an environment where the digitization and connectivity expanding -- the old ways are no more working in terms of the value creation, so the new ways are really working to create value without any barriers.

So in terms of the scale, definitely scale is there. According to some forecast, by 2025, real estate marketplace is expected to generate around $3.8 trillion in terms of the turnover globally. By that time Georgia's estimate is $10 billion, whereas the current figure is trending around $3 billion. In terms of the market, for the Georgia realty at least, the market is quite fragmented, as Vakhtang mentioned. So of course, there are other players: the real estate developers, the buyers, sellers, brokers and many others, but they are disconnected. And the customer journey is very complicated. Our business model, our value proposition is totally different. So we are placing in the middle of our proposition data, and the building blocks around the data are the services, unique services, again, for the Georgia realty and we already launched [thousand] like the certified valuation service, first time ever available for the retail customers at a very accessible price, which they can have -- get in 24 hours and then use for multiple purposes like going into bank and asking for the financing right or the mortgage or for the tax purposes and so on and so forth.

The other one is Lead Generation. So this platform is already generating leads for the financial institutions, for the banks, for the real estate companies, and we're actually selling those leads. The public services, the insurance, again, the financing, we already have connected to banks apart from the TBC. And, of course, the sale, the most important layer of this value proposition of our business model, if you like, is the -- are the participants or stakeholders of this platform, right, who actually co-create the value together with us.

So in the pursuit of these challenge, early this year, we already made an acquisition of well-positioned startup company with a very promising management team. And since then, we did a rebranding, as you can see it's a new logo of the platform, Livo. We liked it quite. We already managed to do a new platform with a new design with an exceptional UI and UX, which is running at the BP Towers, and we just recently launched this platform. And we managed to set up a totally agile organization, self-directed teams for the each of the segments, which these parts are going to cover.

And in conclusion, let me share you our key targets. So by 2021, we plan to generate around $7.5 million in terms of the revenues by not investing more than $2 million over the 2-, 3-year period. But the revenues are not really the key factor that we are going after the housing ecosystem. The key is the data, right? The key is the customer patterns and behaviors that we're going to be able to aggregate and then use our data analytic capabilities to leverage on them further. Thank you very much.

AMIRAN SHEROZIA, HEAD OF IT, JSC TBC BANK: Thank you, everyone, for joining us on this event. My name is Amiran Sherozia. I am in charge of technology at TBC. However, today, I am not here to present how outstanding technological capabilities we have at the bank, but rather I am going to tell you amazing story of TBC venturing into e-commerce and what is the idea behind, what is the vision and what strategic aspirations we have for that particular venture.

So it started back in 2017 when I was thinking about financial inclusion, about open banking, open APIs and technology capabilities which we have at the bank. And I was thinking about how we can make financial services more accessible to our customers, how to leverage on our technologies and find innovative ways of being competitive on the market.

And then I realized that the -- we had to reimagine the way of providing services to the market and act not as a traditional bank, but rather as a big tech company who are disrupting the market and to provide the platform, which would connect different players on the market, providing different services and combining those services in order to make more integrated experience and services to end customers. And I approached Vakhtang with that idea, and Vakhtang financed this project, and now we have a new brand, Vendoo, which is on the market starting from May 2019.

So what is the business model behind? So it is a marketplace. This is the asset-light approach of moving to that business, and we are acting as an intermediary between different service providers and enabling the small and medium enterprises to sell their goods on the market and then provide the services across the country, throughout whole Georgia. And this strategy nicely fits to our strategic objectives to have 10 million users by 2022 and to act as a digital player on the market, to have many touch points with customers, to get more insights of customer behavior, their needs and leverage on these insights in different ways to our ecosystems.

So before moving to that, the project, before financing, we, of course, did the analysis of the market. So the GDP of Georgia is GEL 41 billion, and the retail spending of the -- in the economy is about GEL 10 billion. And our estimate is that about GEL 200 million should be the online potential of retail spending. And this was important for us to understand that the size of the market is enough to justify investment behind it, and I'll talk about that later.

But what is also interesting is another aspect which is specific to Georgia, the market -- the online market is not well developed. And the most of the Georgian citizens, they do shopping abroad. That means that they would buy things on global platforms, on Amazons, on eBays and the other kind of players and go to -- got those goods delivered, we are different [forward this] to Georgia. This is costly. It's timely. So it takes time to get the goods delivered and it also have barriers of language for customers. And we want to change that realty and change the ratio of online shopping abroad versus shopping in Georgia. And then what is also important that the market size is growing very fast. We see that it's approximately 45% on the yearly growth rate across different segments.

Also we did an analysis of local players who are on the market. Unfortunately for the market, but fortunately for us, there are no big players present in Georgia doing the same business, and there are small niche players who don't have either technology capabilities or some capital or resources to really change the market and then provide the services which is common elsewhere. And respectively, we see potential in doing that. However, our objective is not just to focus on local market after successful launch and then getting the knowledge and experience of doing this project in Georgia. We plan to move to other markets and replicate our technology capabilities and our expertise elsewhere.

So what does it mean to be an ecosystem player on the market? So we are providing to merchants e-commerce platform, it's a technology platform for them to upload their information on their products, on their catalogs and provide also services of digital marketing and provide traffic. And we are doing this through connecting different players. So this platform is not to act as a player on the market but to facilitate and interconnect different businesses so that they can enhance each other and provide these marketplace services. So we are partnering with different delivery companies, we are partnering with digital agencies and other companies who can provide these services to small and medium enterprises and enable them to scale up their sales online.

On the other hand, also we are focusing on retail customers, and we would love to provide the best-in-class services not available in Georgia due to the specifics of the market and to provide the best customer experience, very convenient services, ability to return goods back to the sellers, which is very complicated right now because you would need to move these goods back to different countries and then also breaking the barriers of language and, basically, changing the experience and changing the -- shopping habits in the market. And our vision is to make shopping and selling easy in Georgia and then do the same in similar other markets.

Now why it's interesting from a banking perspective? Why would a bank move into such a venture? Because we see big synergies in banking, between banking and marketplace. And particularly, we see that we are going to share quite a huge number of customers on both sides, on corporate and then small enterprises as well as on retail. And we are going to leverage our financial capabilities to credit ourselves through end customers to also understand better what customer needs are, what is their behavior and also incorporate that information into us calling and into better tailoring the offerings to end customers through making products and services really tailor-made and then personalized for each and every customer.

On the merchant side, we are going to leverage on our trade finance or our ethics capabilities, also provide our POS services, also let them participate in our loyalty system, which is very successful on the market, and then we see lots of synergies on both sides of the market.

So why do we think we are going to be competitive on the market? This is because we are going to compete on price-quality ratio. That means that we are going to eliminate delivery costs of getting goods delivered from overseas. We are going to eliminate the time of delivery of goods to Georgia because with the services we have already after 1 month of launch is that we are delivering goods in same day in Tbilisi and next day across all cities, all villages in Georgia, and we are working on that to make it even faster and to move to same-day delivery across the country.

Apart from that, also we would -- the Georgian citizens would benefit from different things like product return and Georgian language support, which are barriers for many of them, unfortunately, right now. On the merchant side, we are attracting merchants and providing them the good customer base, the good traffic and then we are establishing a strong brand on the market. We are providing out of box marketing, logistics, warehousing and other services. And also we are providing some advanced analytics capabilities for them to better manage their stocks and the deliveries and pricing and so on and so forth. So we believe it's going to be demanded on the market, and we already have more than 200 merchants on the platform right now and more than 6,000 SKUs already sold on the market.

And initially, to get started, we decided to acquire a discount coupons player on the market and use that company as a platform to then build on. And we also recruited best talent on the market and none of them are from banking industry. These are people from different online industries, from logistics and other areas of expertise. And I'm very proud that we have best talent right now. We started with 25 people acquiring this company, and right now we have about 100 people working day and night to make this venture success. And it is fully agile. It is -- we are adopting lean startup approaches. We are adopting cloud technologies and capabilities to be able to be fast and scalable and to provide best-in-class services for our customers.

This is about the distribution of spending, our retail spending in Georgia. This is our estimate. And you will see that about 45% is on food and grocery, and the rest is on other categories. And our strategy is to cover all categories except for grocery. And we started this year with electronics and personal care products, which accounts for 12% of the total market we are targeting. And right now we are also adding new categories on a daily basis. We are adding more than 200 products on the market. And by the end of this year, we are going to cover all key categories, and next years, we are going to move to apparel and shoes.

So what are the KPIs for this company, and how much it's cost us to invest in this venture? So we are investing $3 million over a 2.5-year period. We expect breakeven to be in 2020, and we expect a number of sales to be about 0.5 million by the end of the term and to reach 40 million gross merchandise volume.

And for next steps, this year, we are planning to add new categories, the gardening, home, toys, et cetera. And by the end of this year, also launching mobile application, which is very important for customers to shop because the behavior is that most of people, they would search products via mobile and then do the transaction on laptops and computers. And next year, we are also launching some innovation application, innovative applications, and also we would decide whether to move to other countries and in which countries to target and how to replicate our success in other places.

This is all about this ecosystem. Thank you very much.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Thank you, gentlemen. The next presenter is Nikoloz Kurdiani, Head of our MSME Banking, and he will talk about our full digital bank space.

NIKOLOZ KURDIANI, DEPUTY CEO OF MSME BANKING, TBC BANK GROUP PLC: Hello, everybody. Thanks for coming and listening to this very interesting presentation. I'm happy to present an update on Space, which is one of those projects which positions TBC as one of the best innovator and technology companies in our region. We presented Space last year as an idea basically, and now I will show you a bit more after 1 year of its operations, almost 1 year. I have a special slide on age.

So the first question is what is Space? And basically, the next slide will be about why Space is, in our opinion, successful and well positioned. It's a fully cloud-based solution. Everything we've developed is basically on cloud, on Amazon Web Services. We created Space so that it supports our international expansion and basically helps us in entering new markets. It had to be very easy to integrate because, basically, how we operate in Georgia, as you may know, is we integrated ourselves with TBC core banking system. So if we enter a new market, we also have to integrate ourselves easily into other core banking solutions or other partner companies. It is a fully in-house solution and very flexible. What I call flexible is that it is modular and fully API-based. I have a special slide on the architecture. And one of the core requirements, basically, was time-to-market, and I will show you later on what we achieved in that regard.

Basically, the next question is why we think basically -- why do we need Space and why we created Space? And the main thing is that we wanted to create a challenger for ourselves. Basically, we, in Georgia, as you know, already are one of the biggest players, and we have the leading position in retail market. And we just wanted to challenge the processes and customer journeys which we have, and maybe to come up with another alternative way of doing the same but easier or maybe more simpler. And so we are basically competing with ourselves in this regard. Also what we wanted to do, as we are a big institution and with lots of -- I cannot call it legacy because we are, altogether, almost 30 years old, not that old. But legacy systems, we wanted to alternate the IT architecture to see something which may be operating with a different logic and to create a platform for international expansion.

On this slide, yes, I mean this slide basically shows very simply the architecture logic. What we used from TBC Group, TBC Bank, basically, was the core banking, but to its minimum extent. Basically, we just took the general ledger functional, the account holding functional and reporting to the National Bank, and all the rest is built around in the middleware. So all the products, their core functional, core features are in the middleware. All the third-party solutions are connected to that middleware. So whatever we want to change and change it quickly because the customers require the changes quickly, we would do this in the middleware. So we will not touch the core banking solution, which is a monolith. So changing the core banking solution, as you may have heard already, is quite difficult. This is what exactly is called the legacy systems, and nobody wants to touch them basically. So that's why in Space, we just keep very minimum from the core and all the rest is in the layers around. So basically, everything is autonomous and modular and fully based on APIs.

Yes, moving on. There are 3 main things, which in our opinion makes Space different or unique in our market. And as we're expanding to the neighboring markets also on those, it's the quick time-to-market, and I will show you what I mean in that a bit later on.

UX and UI, so this is very important. I mean in reality, we know many different products, which basically sell themselves because they are better designed or they have a better customer journey. I won't mention famous names and brands, but we all know what I'm talking about. And instant service delivery. Instant, the word instant becomes very important nowadays because people do not want to spend more time on various processes. It's not only about banking, right? In everything, people would want things to be quick right away, instant, and this is also applied massively to banking and we know many examples in U.K. or in other markets where this thing is becoming very, very important.

I will show you now 2 very small demos, very quick ones. The first one is how we do the payment, a P2P transfer; and the second one is about loan. And this is -- we just recorded it very simply on the screen, and this is a reality, how quickly one would do those. Yes, this is a payment. Choosing the card from which we want to transfer, choosing the card to which we want to transfer, taking the amount, checking list, and that's it. This is how quickly you transfer the money basically from any cards to any card. And this is the confirmation SMS, basically, we received that the transaction was done.

And this is how we take a loan. Loan amount; repayment date; payment amount, so that it would calculate the maturity afterwards; checking into the revenue service, so that we estimate the salary; we receive the unique code, the allowance to check; terms, the contract basically; card we want to transfer the loan to. It can be also a non-Space or non-TBC card. We could directly transfer to our competitors' cards; and that's it, the loan is disbursed. So everything is done instantly. And this is exactly what I say, basically, when I say instant because the customer should not be spending time on getting the loan. The loan amount is up to GEL 25,000 at this point, and which is something about $9,000. And yes, I'll show you the figures afterwards.

This is the slide about the age. Space is 8 months old. So what I call 8 months old is from the moment we closed the beta. We said that now we are not a beta application anymore. And basically, this is the time line. So in February 2017, we had the idea. In July, we approved -- in June, we approved it. In January, we had the prototype in 2018. And in March, we had an app testing. We called it Friends and Family. Beta was launched in May and in September, early October, we closed it. So afterwards, basically, this is where (inaudible) and these are the results.

So ever since the moment of the launch, basically, we had 397,000 downloads, so the app downloads. We have, for today, I just checked, it's almost 130,000 registered customers, so this slides represents an earlier date. We have 15,000 daily active customers. We have 64,000 issued cards, 572,000 transactions performed ever since, 9,000 borrowers and the loan portfolio is of -- I mean these days, is a bit more than GEL 20 million already.

So I would say the results are quite impressive for 8 months, for a younger baby basically. And the next steps -- the only purpose of this slide is to show this. The next steps are Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan. So what we -- Giorgi will be telling you more about the Uzbekistani project, where we use Space as a banking -- as a service platform. In Azerbaijan, we want to enter with Space the way we entered Georgia basically with Space, using Nikoil as the core banking solution provider.

Thanks a lot. This was the update.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Thanks, Niko. So after our digital initiatives, we are now turning towards our international plans. First up is Azerbaijan. So I'd like to invite the CEO of Nikoil Bank, Nikoloz Shurgaia.

NIKOLOZ N. SHURGAIA, CHAIRMAN OF THE MANAGEMENT BOARD, NIKOIL INVESTMENT COMMERCIAL BANK OJSC: So hello, everybody. I'm Nikoloz Shurgaia. I thank Mamuka for the presentation earlier. A few more words is I'm a Georgian and British banker, International. And Azerbaijan has attracted me with its fascinating opportunities, and has never failed to keep me fascinated. I'm here to tell you about Azerbaijan as the country, which I love; about Nikoil Bank, partner of TBC; and our joint plans to expand in Azerbaijan.

This slide is somewhat loaded with data. I will not bore you with the specs. Three key points. First is we are small but fast-growing. We take governance, management, good practices very seriously, and we have high ambitions. We've been hiring 30, 40 people every month. And sorry -- 30, 40 people every month, and this resulted in over 50% of our staff working with us less than a year, so this is a very young and dynamic energetic team. Very good graduates, I'm proud to see them, meet them every month and be part of the introduction program and see how good talent is coming. I'm thinking as a younger banker of myself, representing minority, less than 10% of people who are over 45 years old. So this is a very highly energetic bank and happy to drive forward and actually, we gel together very well.

And we are very much like the country where we operate. Azerbaijan is a young country. It has been I think, 1 million population every decade. So it has reached last year, 10 million. And the economy is solid, $45 billion GDP, 3.4% growth, and a lot of good macroeconomic indicators, huge reserves in the oil fund and so on. And the country had gone through a crisis in 2015-2017, which was a very good, very healthy wakeup call. So the country -- the leadership, political leadership, has started a lot of very strong initiative to drive growth. The country is already on 25th place in ease of doing business, and it's advancing fast. The country introduced a new tax system, reduced significantly the rates applicable to salaries and improved tremendously the administration.

Recently returned significant amount of taxes paid earlier and just paid back. This was inconceivable 5, 6 years ago. We see very good improvements in the judiciary, many new judges appointed, reshuffled. Their pay has increased so there is a very strong moral upper ground to keep things clean. Then we see a lot of very competent, young people coming, going to the West, returning, and many competent technocrats taking positions in state-owned enterprises and in the cabinet, and they are driving further reforms.

We are very fortunate to be in the environment, which is -- which has low credit penetration. Loans to GDP ratio is 16%. And by any dimension result, Azerbaijan has actually deliveries even though never has reached huge levels throughout the crisis years. So we have a fantastic opportunity to grow credit. And the economy needs it and household needs it and expect it from the banking sector.

There are 30 banks in the country. We have identified this -- broken down this into 3 groups. First is 3 larger banks, which are between 11% to 16% market share. Then we've identified 5 peer banks to us which are closest competitors, all have -- all but 1 have foreign capital. And 22 other banks. These 22 are varying lots, not to be neglected. But these 5 are the closest competitors at the moment. They have bigger customer base, they started earlier, digital initiatives and so on, better brands. But we are, by far, not intimidated. We are full of energy and enthusiasm and we feel that we have so many strong initiatives that we will surpass very soon. Our ambition, I set quite high, is today the largest privately owned bank in the country with foreign capital. This is approximately being fourth-largest, and we want to be the most profitable.

What drives us? This is the key. As I said, we take governance and good management very seriously. We want to build digital ecosystems very much like TBC, and this TBC's partnership is huge, help and inspiration. Our vision is to be the brand of choice of Azerbaijani people who aspire better -- who are looking for better banking and services. And what our values are: put the customer first; serve with a heart; find solutions; keep it simple; and work with a smile. And the distinguishing factors are, we are focusing on micro SME and people of Azerbaijan. Three factors which will distinguish us are: firstly, good governance and the inspired team; important is -- second is technology, where we are applying most modern technologies; and third is best-in-class customer experience, which we build using the best international practice.

What are our preferred sales channels? Digital, of course. However, digital is, at the moment, not a huge earner. We started relatively late. We invest a lot now and we will be catching up, I'm very confident. However, at the moment, key is the branch network. We are keen not to expand bricks-and-mortar investments to shut it down later. So our strategy is to keep our branches rather small size, 12 branches across the country, 8 of them in Baku. The governance. Every layer of the bank's governance is very efficient. I do appreciate this, and my team appreciates this. This is a very, very good collaboration of hearts and minds.

This is the team. 8 people -- 9, I'm sorry, 8 apart from me, and very diverse. Although this is all male but we have Marina as head, a female, and the bank has 36% plus female employees, and there is more kind of diversity. 4 of this strong executives are Georgian, 4 Azerbaijani. Liquidity and capital base. In terms of liquidity ratios, we continue to operate on very high liquidity numbers. I mean in fact, the average liquidity numbers have been much higher than the numbers that are shown at the end of the reporting period. In fact, about 10 basis point from the decreasing NIM is related to higher than usual liquidity. Our liquidity coverage ratio for the quarter end was at 117%. Our net funding -- net stable funding ratio was 124%. We did check it couple of times, this is not mistake. It happens to be 124% across all the reporting period.

Capital, we have good buffer or comfortable buffer on top of the minimum capital requirement. Our minimum requirement for Tier 1 is 11.9%, we were at 13.8%. Most of you remember that there is a minimum capital adequacy ratio increasing requirement per NBG that increases year-on-year, but given the fact that we do accrue capital each year and we have good buffer, we will meet this requirement through internal sources. We might explore diversification going forward though.

Most of you might have heard that we did mandate UBS, J.P. Morgan and Renaissance Capital along with TBC Capital for potential bond issuance, potential euro bond issuance. They will be -- they are arranging the meetings with respective investors. If -- and then the size -- it will be U.S. denominated bond, REG S and 144 A, the size will be index inclusive and subject to market condition and the pricing, we might issue bonds. So that's one more initiative that we can share.

To summarize, our profitability drivers continue to be solid net interest margin, increasing net fee and commission income, prudent risk management and again improving cost efficiency, with the strong balance sheet of sustainable loan book growth as 10%, 15%, sound asset quality, strong liquidity and capital buffers. So I will be happy to answer your questions after the session is over.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: I'd like to invite our Chief Economist, Otar Nadaraia. Otar, over to you.

OTAR NADARAIA, CHIEF ECONOMIST, TBC BANK GROUP PLC: Thank you. Thank you, Zoltan. So macro overview. I will briefly discuss Georgian economy and the exchange rate and also the credit growth predominantly from sustainability perspective. So as you probably know that 2018 was probably the year of proving the resilience because despite unfavorable developments in the region, also really tied fiscal policy domestically, the 4.7% growth in 2018 was really an achievement. Maybe a good question is, what would happen with exchange rate if the deficit -- if there was not really surplus fiscal, but deficit? But again the answer is that also NBG is buying reserves and was buying reserves also in 2018, and I will come back to reserves, but of course that means that inflows were sufficient even for higher growth.

As Deputy Chairman mentioned, our credit rating continues to improve. Also it may be argued that while looking at Georgian eurobonds and comparing with risk-free yields, so probably risk perception I would argue is improving even more as compared to what is it reflected in the credit rating.

I think very valuable information for all of us that in the very short-term -- if we think of U.S. dollar GEL and U.S. dollar euro, in very short-term GEL, in very short term when it's 1 day, 1 week or 1 month, GEL is more stable with dollar rather than euro. But if you go for 1 year, 2 years and medium to long-term, GEL is more stable with euro rather than dollar for many reasons, including higher inflows from EU, et cetera, et cetera. Those are described -- discussed in more details in our recently published TBC economic review, if you had a chance to look at it. Furthermore, what is also important, it's not only about exchange rate, but if you think of growth, the growth also is stable in euro rather than dollar. Of course, growth is mostly stable in GEL in Georgia, but then it's more stable in euro. The second chart shows euro dollar exchange rate and the GDP growth in Georgia. And you see that whenever euro is stronger, also growth is stronger in Georgia.

So briefly about our exposure to oil prices. As you probably know, it may be argued that Georgia's exposure is reasonably balanced from direct exposure, of course, we are petroleum importers, but we also receive inflows in form of exports, remittances, FDIs and tourism inflows from oil exporting countries. And of course, in case of inflows, the impact is not that proportional in case of lower oil prices as compared with oil imports, where you should expect more proportional impact on imports. At the moment, however, we believe that probably Georgia is benefiting probably more with relatively lower oil prices, why because unlike 2014, '15, '16, at the moment it appears that our oil exporting economic partners are better preferred -- prepared for oil's ups and downs because they have significant buffers in their budgets, so that they don't spend all when oil price is high.

Okay. So current account deficit. As Deputy Chairman mentioned, often current account deficit may reflect strengths and opportunity rather than weakness. Of course, it's always dangerous when you have higher consumption, higher inflation over the trend GDP growth, very high and unsustainable credit growth and you have wider and wider current account deficit, and in this case you might expect the ending of cycle in very dangerous way, and certainly this is not the case for Georgia. Even when you exclude the impact of South Caucasus Pipeline project, which had very large import component, even excluding that, current account deficit is improving. Also current account deficit adjusted -- as you can see from the right chart, adjusted for reinvested earnings, stood at 6%, so if you exclude also in 2018 imports related to South Caucasus Pipeline project. So projects are underlying -- what you might call underlying current account deficit is somewhere below -- even below 6%.

So next chart on external debt. It may be argued that Georgia's external debt has reasonably low-risk profile. Of course, if country is attractive, it's not about FDI only, but it's also debt financing. By the way, often debt is linked to LTIs when it's intercompany debt, especially in countries where you don't have so-called same capitalization rule, it's a taxation rule. Many companies prefer to lend to their subsidiaries rather than invest in equity. And as you can see, the FDI-related debt is quite high. Also the next chart is breakdown of long-term debt of nonfinancial corporates, and most of it -- or 45% is again intercompany debt, also around 30% is, what you can call, trade credit. So you can judge that overall it's -- the risk profile is reasonably low.

So reserves -- international reserves. As I said, NBG is building reserves. And by the way, NBG is building reserves in a countercyclical way. So as you can see from first chart, the green one is change in inflows as percent of GDP. The blue one is GDP growth and -- the light blue one, and the dark blue one is changing reserves as percent of GDP, so net buying. And as you can see whenever inflows growth is not that strong, NBG sometimes sells reserves or sometimes is not buying reserves, but whenever inflows are strong, NBG continues to build up reserves. At the moment, if you think of so-called ARA metric, so the adequacy of the reserves is something like close to 100%. If you think of short-term targets, so according to our estimates, NBG central bank already exceeds the short-term target by around USD 200 million, which is quite comfortable buffer. And by the way, NBG made a statement that in the short-term, they bought much more reserves and it is necessary and this also provides additional room for exchange rate to appreciate. We're going to discuss exchange rate also later.

So very briefly on fiscal. As you know, fiscal is very prudent in Georgia. In general, the fiscal burden is low, but furthermore the current spending is low. So current spending to GDP is only 23.2%. And according to the budget, the current spending share will be reasonably stable or even declining a bit, while capital spending is up. Also on cost of debt, so most of Georgia's debt is concessional from donor financing and is long-term, and weighted average cost of debt is only 2%. I think on new debt, they borrowed from one of the IFIs. I think they are paying 0.8%, even that. And overall debt level, the next chart provides information on FX adjusted debt to GDP and actual one. And as you can see, the FX adjusted so to exclude the depreciation effect, the debt to GDP level is even declining a bit.

So growth projections, I think it's really consensus that close or maybe above 5% growth rate for Georgia is so-called trend growth rate. As for 2019, probably it will depend on credit growth. So if credit growth is something like maybe 12%, we projected 4.7% for 2019; and if credit growth is close to 15%, so growth would be close to 5.4%. So if you think of first 4 months, I have to say that the growth is a bit higher than we were projecting around 2 months ago.

Some more details on our projections, so -- and you can see also this in TBC economic review in one of the insights. So if you project inflows, if you project credit growth and if you project fiscal, so you have quite good estimates for overall GDP growth, historical and also going forward.

So real effective exchange rate. So this is daily estimates of real effective exchange rate. The deviation from the period average, so if you update this up to today, still it looks more undervalued rather than overvalued exchange rate. And by the way, this exchange rate has very strong and pretty stable relationship with inflation. It's very difficult to say exact number, but on average 3% change in effective exchange rate, may lead to around 1% higher inflation in very short term. And also NBG is paying more attention to exchange rate. You can see also historically, that's the red cycle -- red cycles are tightening of policy rates -- those often coincide with weaker exchange rate and vice versa. Going forward, also we believe that together with being bullish on GEL, we believe that exchange rate is likely to be less volatile, again for 2 reasons, first is that probably seasonal pattern is -- will be less because of market perception. Some of the market participants are -- have started to buy GEL in winter times and sell in summer times. And also I think more important, I think NBG is willing to smooth some, what one would call -- what one may call, some unnecessary volatility.

So why real effective exchange rate and why not nominal effective exchange rate? As you know, maybe also in many textbooks, when we look at very short-term, people always look at nominal effective exchange rate rather than real effective exchange rate because real effective is probably more long-term, it has more long-term dynamics. But kindly note that in some of Georgia's economic partners, inflation is quite volatile often, like Turkey, this is example of Turkey. So Turkish lira has weakened a lot in nominal terms, but not really in real terms because inflation, both CPI and also PPI inflation has been very high in Turkey. So what we would suggest and what we would really argue even in short-term, it makes sense to look at real effective exchange rate rather than nominal effective using various techniques, whether you want to look -- whether it is above or below medium-term average, et cetera, et cetera, okay?

So now on long-term. So thanks to high GDP growth and also high productivity growth, our real effective exchange rate has long-term appreciating trend. And coupled with lower and lower inflation target, we believe that in medium- to long-term, it will be more reflected in nominal appreciation rather than appreciation via prices. So in other words, if real appreciation trend will continue, and probably that's the case, historical if inflation target was 6%, then it became 5%, then 4% and then 3%, meaning that there is more room for nominal appreciation. So to compare, to think of euro and dollar, of course, this is not exact thing, you can't say exactly, but if you have, let's say, productivity growth differential with [euro] area of 2% per year and your inflation differential is 1%, so 2% there and 1% in Georgia, your average long-term appreciation, nominal appreciation would be something like 1% per year.

I mentioned productivity, of course, productivity is very difficult to measure. But historically productivity was very high in Georgia. So quality of growth was high and is high, so it's not about overall growth only, but the quality is high, measured as contribution of productivity. Going forward, we believe that for many reasons, productivity should be -- maybe not as high as it used to be historically, but should stay high for many reasons, again, one reason is that in Georgia, you have private sector-led growth rather than government sector-led growth with many -- unfortunately, in many cases losing efficiencies, et cetera. Also if you look at employment, I think, one of the problems in Georgia is very high share of self employees. But I think at the same time, it's an opportunity because the share of hired employees is increasing as you can see from the second chart and also more jobs are getting -- are created not by government, but rather by the private sector.

In our projection, what we call a bit more than random walk, the exchange rate projection is very difficult to project, especially in the very short-term. But assuming reasonable stability of exchange rates and economic partners against dollar, and first of all, euro, also assuming inflation close to 3%, I mean this year should be somewhat higher, maybe 4.5% -- maybe 4%, 4.5%, including one-offs because if you exclude excise tax on tobacco, so inflation is pretty close to central bank's target. Also probably reasonable stability of commodity prices, some of them go up, some of them go down, so we project something like 2.67 as a period average for 2019 and also it appears to be the same for the end of 2019. So if euro strengthens, I would say my personal view, based on many assumptions, when euro strengthens, again based on medium-term logic, difficult to say exactly, but normally -- let's say, if euro strengthens against dollar by 10%, so you should expect GEL to strengthen against dollar maybe by 7%, maybe 8%, but I would say maybe 7%.

So if -- so in this projection in 2020, besides GEL having the appreciation in trend, in 2020 also you have assumption on stronger euro and consequently, much stronger GEL against dollar. So now on credit growth. So when people talk about credit growth sustainability, of course, there are many measures. But one used by Basel committee, also Central Banks, also IMF, is so called credit-to-GDP gap, so credit to GDP deviation from this trend. If you look at Georgia, so first one is credit-to-GDP gap at current exchange rate and second one is at constant exchange rate, so excluding exchange rate depreciation effect. This includes, by the way, bank credit, also microfinance organizations and also domestically issued corporate bonds.

So in Georgia's case like in many other emerging market cases was partially dollarized economy and banking systems and also with high level of inflows as the Deputy Chairman mentioned, because when you have 70% of GDP as inflow, so your target should not be at -- is not 100% local currency portfolio, yes? So you should have something like maybe in Georgian case something like 30%, what you can call natural level of dollarization. So it's now new fancy term introduced by IMF. So in our context, it's always better to look at credit-to-GDP gap at constant exchange rate, rather than current one. And I'll try very briefly to explain why. So first, when deviation from trend is, let's say, dangerous and leads to unsustainable growth, this credit growth often, if not always, maybe even always, it often coincides with asset price bubbles, yes? The high growth in consumption in small and open economies, growth in current account deficit and of course, again, above trend growth in GDP, and of course, all this can happen on the constant exchange rate under what you can call the real growth of credit. So real here means not inflation adjusted but just exchange rate adjusted and cannot happen under current exchange rate. Furthermore, from sustainability perspective, especially in the small and open economies, so you have unsustainable GDP and credit growth often with very high levels of inflows and often, exchange rate depreciates. And in that case, basically, credit-to-GDP gap at current exchange rate may even mask the unsustainable credit growth because if exchange rate appreciates at current one, you have lower growth as compared to what it is in reality.

So again to sum up, based on this very popular indicator, as the gap at constant exchange rate is certainly more important and more informative, and as you can see, in Georgia's case, the gap is close to 0. If you're following our publications, if you're subscribed to our website, the new one for Q1 at constant exchange turned even a bit negative, a bit negative, as a gap. It's not included here, just was published a few days ago. Also whenever you have unsustainable credit growth, one of the indicator is asset price bubbles. And asset price bubbles in Georgian constant is probably fair to say the housing, housing bubble. And it's good question whether we have bubble or not. And frankly, there are even no signs of bubble. If you look at quite standard assessment tools like real growth of house price in local currency inflation adjusted, so it's quite stable and flat. If you look at -- if you look like -- if you look at measures like price-to-rent ratio, so as you know, during bubbles, the price-to-rent ratio tend to increase because you have higher growth in prices rather than yields. Also many compare the housing yield with conventional savings, probably conventional and most popular comparable saving in Georgia probably is U.S. dollar deposit rate, which is around -- which is much lower at the moment as compared to housing yield, so housing yield is something like 8% to 8.5%. Also might be useful to look at GDP per capita and also house price across Central and Eastern European countries. And as you can see, we are somewhere below trend. So in long term, the housing price, sustainable housing price increases something like 2%, 3% in real term. Plus inflation in GEL, it should be like 5%, 6% and in long term, it's pretty same in dollars and euros.

So again, no signs of housing bubble. As you know, when you look at -- when you Google like unsustainable credit growth or banking distress, so it often -- you often see housing, which is rather than banking, which because house price bubble is very important indicator. So similar trend is for household debt. This is again at current exchange rate and at constant exchange rate. Unfortunately, we were unable to exclude loans to individual entrepreneurs from here because we don't have sufficient long-term data. But in terms of trend, this is still informative maybe not in terms of level because in terms of level, the household debt is much lower in Georgia. So when you exclude loans to individual entrepreneurs and also when you exclude credit to nonresidents, at the moment, there are -- I think that more than 10% of mortgage debt is debt to nonresident. So household debt to household income is quite stable in 2018. So you already have the impact of regulations. By the way, for simplicity, many compare household debt to GDP or credit to GDP across countries, but of course, from analytical perspective, it's better to compare household debt with household income. In Georgia's case, the share of household disposable income -- as a share of GDP, the household disposable income is higher as compared to the other countries. And there are several reasons like lower taxation and also remittances, remittances which are part of household income but not the GDP. On the next chart, you can see the household debt service to household income so what households pay on principal and interest during 1 year on a debt service. And there, you can see historically, despite high increase -- and by the way, that chart includes exchange rate effect also and that one also includes nonresidents and also individual entrepreneurs. Because unfortunately, we don't have so far system-wide data to look at system-wide all those indicators -- at this indicator. So if you exclude the individual entrepreneurs and also if you exclude nonresidents or further if you adjust for FX effects, so the debt service ratio is maybe even declining. Of course here, you should not exclude the FX effect because in case of debt service, certainly the current exchange rate certainly matters.

Okay. Just to compare with some countries -- by the way, I find it very difficult to compare penetration because not often, penetration is strongly linked to this GDP per capita level. And you can see household debt to household income like in Singapore is 2.5, so 250%. In Denmark and Northern Europe, it's very high. And by the way, European Systemic Risk Board -- they are talking about some vulnerabilities in northern Europe, chattering always about combination of high credit growth and the housing bubble and asset price bubbles.

One interesting comparison should be with Czech Republic. So again, household debt to household income, if you look at mortgage debt, still Georgia has much lower debt. Nonmortgage debt is a bit higher, excluding -- even excluding loans to individual entrepreneurs. However again, difficult to judge because normally in relatively lower-income countries and lower-income groups within countries, you have more nonmortgage debt rather than mortgage debt. Also unlike Georgia, like also in my view, penetration is difficult to compare. But unlike Georgia, you have -- in many countries, you have quite large share of unregulated markets like real estate developers issuing their own, call it, quality internal installments, which is basically -- which is not -- what is not reflected in bank lending, et cetera, et cetera. So all those should be -- yes, all those should be taken into account. So again, on business, business lending also when looking at penetrations, we have to look at bond market, again, FDI-related debt, intercompany lending, et cetera. And the last slide, as you probably know, the loan quality in very small loan segment has been an issue in Georgia. So some even were referring to overindebtedness. However, I'll note that in bank sector, in banking sectors, the quality of loan portfolio was stable. So this is quality of loan portfolio measured as number of loans. So even when you look at number of loans, the quality of loans in banking sector in retail was stable. And you can see this jump as a -- as a green -- sorry, as a green line, which was predominantly almost fully closed by sub-prime lending in nonbank sector and, of course, recently introduced 50% cap of effective interest rate already addresses this problem because this type of lending is not more -- not anymore sustainable. And I'll also note that most of those problem loans were very small loans like around half of them were less than $200 equivalent.

So I guess, this was the last slide. Please find more on our website, tbcresearch.ge. This is the joint website of TBC Bank's economic team and also TBC Capital's research team. They focus more on sectors and George will talk about this later in more details. You can subscribe to our website very easily. Just enter in your e-mail and you can choose which publication you would like to receive. And as always, you can e-mail us if you have further questions or suggestions. So that should be thank you. No disclaimer. Okay. So with that, thank you very much.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Thank you, Otar. Thank you very much there. I'm sure there will be many questions at the end on the macro. So the next presenter is David Chkonia who will talk about risk management.

DAVID CHKONIA, DEPUTY CEO, CHIEF RISK OFFICER & MEMBER OF MANAGEMENT BOARD, JSC TBC BANK: Hello, everyone, and welcome to risk management. Thank you for sticking around those of you that stayed, and I'll try to make it quick, hit the highlights and then I'll be looking forward to your questions after this session. So I would like to talk -- first, I would like to talk about our risk management framework and approach like we've done before. And I think this is important because if you get this right and you have this right, then you can sort of build and expand into different directions then you can build on it. And as you can see, we're building a lot currently. And in the second part, I'll talk about the portfolio structure, hit the highlights of the performance again and look at some benchmarking also.

So just to recap, we focused a lot on our -- on the philosophy of risk management in TBC, which is to have a strong independent control function but at the same time have a business-minded and oriented function that works with business units with various counterparts across the organization to find solutions to problems or cases, whether it's structuring transactions or designing new processes and products. And then the agile organization contacts, which is where we have transitioned, as you have heard, we are significantly increasing the engagement of risk with the agile teams.

Our framework for risk management has most of the components -- all of the components that we think we need to identify and manage risk across the organization. I like to highlight the risk culture here as something that is entrenched throughout the organization and that really shapes how employees of the group make risk-based decisions. Management and managers obviously have a key role in promoting and communicating risk culture throughout the organization. And we have a reward system that incentivizes people to take risk decisions in line with the risk appetite of the bank.

Risk is part of the governance structure at all levels of the group. So the Board is involved in risk management on a regular and a quarterly basis as well as on ad hoc basis for various topics. It signs off on large exposure as in the corporate clients, on related party transactions. It approves risk appetite and various other sort of principle risk management methodologies and approaches. At the management Board level, we talk about risk more often on a regular basis. The key here is to ensure that risk objectives and expectations are integrated into bank -- aligned with bank strategy and integrated into overall business planning of the group. And there is a centralized risk management function that reports to the CRO and creates sort of a clearly defined path of accountability and communication for risk. One of the principal sort of governance tools that we have is our risk appetite. Some of you are familiar with this. We sort of assign our targets to various key parameters that we measure and monitor at the bank. There's some high-level parameters and then this cascades down to sort of segment and product level as well. And this is reviewed on a regular basis at the Board level, at the management Board level. Here, you can see an example of our NPL ratio being comfortably within our target zone. There are a number of things that we did -- development that we did in risk in the past year. We -- 2018 was the first full year of IFRS 9 reporting, as you know, and the provision level sort of came out as expected, together with our external auditors who worked on it. We did validation and backtesting of our models, and all came out within the target sort of thresholds that we had. I would just add, importantly, that we set up over the last couple of years big infrastructure or IT data models to cover for this. And it has proven to be stable and fairly robust over this last year, and that was very important from the operational perspective.

Something that we spent most of our time on in the last 12 months is implementing the new methodologies and technically implementing the regulations, the new lending regulations. And what I mean is -- and not just obvious is to be in compliance with regulation but then designing, redesigning the credit process so that we are efficient in how we sort of comply with certain requirements. In particular, income verification requirements and we'll talk a little bit more about this, and this took a lot of direct work with the regulator as well. Last year, we set out on an ambitious capital optimization program and have saved a significant amount of RWA, which you can see sort of our RWA-to-loans density ratio has come down several percentage points, and it has impacted capital adequacy by about close to 100 basis points, which is particularly helpful and impactful in the new capital -- regulatory capital framework where we see capital requirement increase every year over a 5-year period.

We invested quite a bit in the retail sort of collection infrastructure and environment last year. We invested in more sophisticated and smart communication and telephony systems and that has enabled us to increase efficiency of our operators by 40%. And then that sort of directly drove recoveries because we had capacity to have broader reach to -- with our borrowers and our customers at sort of segmented more granularly, which we also do based on statistical analysis, et cetera. And over the coming period, our focus is going to be to sort of significantly redefine the credit cycle in some of our key products. So as you know, in the consumer products, we have a highly automated process. The majority -- a big majority of our consumer products are approved and instantaneously decision is provided to customers -- to borrowers on their applications. This has now slightly changed because of the regulation and operational component of income verification has been added. But we're trying to sort of maintain that process there. But we're working on creating an instantaneous sort of decision in principal process, what we call straight-through processing for the majority of mortgage applications that we receive. And in fact, last week was when we started to launch this process already in their mortgages in customers that receive instant decisions, subject to certain operational checks again to be aligned with the regulation. But they should significantly -- that's something relatively new on the Georgian market and should increase -- have a good impact with our customers. And at the end of the year or closer to the end of the year, we are trying to do the same with small ticket business loans in SME as well -- in MSME as well.

I want to mention a few things about regulation obviously which after a lot of discussion and debate came January 1 of this year. It covers loans to individuals and to summarize key aspects of it are PTI and LTV caps, which are a lot more conservative for foreign currency loans, shorter -- fixed terms are defined for secured and unsecured loans. And there is a requirement to do income verification of borrowers. Obviously, this is pretty straightforward in cases where there is official income. But for all other cases, for self-employed population and we've just heard that there is a big portion of it in Georgia, it is more challenging. And then also to worth mentioning here that in September of last year, there was new law that required that all loans under GEL 200,000 equivalent be issued in lari. So that threshold has increased to promote larization. I think what's really important here also is that this regulation now covers all lenders in the country, including nonbanks and the microfinance organizations so that -- which is really good because the discrepancy that Otar just showed us in terms of performance, that's what the regulator wanted to address. Now in terms of impact, on the next few slides in terms of portfolio structure and performance, we'll come back to this and talk about the impact. But in terms of disbursements, initially, there was quite significant impact obviously in the banking sector and in January before banks started to adjust to the new reality and figure out ways and work with the regulator, come up with solutions on how to continue disbursing where disbursement was good to do and the regulator also agreed with it. But having said that, there is obviously a population of borrower segments and product types that have become unbankable under this -- under the new regulation.

So one principal change is that -- is related to portfolio structure. Giorgi mentioned earlier that the share of the consumer products has decreased now in our portfolio, in our retail portfolio and the share of mortgages has increased. Consumer products are higher NIM, higher cost of risk products and they are decreased in the weight of the portfolio means that overall NIM has adjusted downwards and cost of risk has also decreased by about 30 basis points, we estimate. We'll talk about this portfolio structure impact across other slides as well. But this is our overall portfolio structure. You will see that the retail portfolio is now 44% of our total portfolio. And this is impact of regulation in 2018 when some preliminary regulation started as well has come down. There is a small one-off resegmentation effect, but we are at 44% now. And we're expecting that this level will stay this year and going forward. And then obviously, our corporate business is now about a third of the portfolio in MSME. This is broadly in line with our business strategy and objective. And we think this is a pretty well-diversified portfolio. Looking at industry sectors, you will see that energy and utilities is still the biggest sector in our portfolio at 8% of it. But as I've noted before, the segment is made up of sort of 3 distinct subsectors from risk perspective. So there is utilities, which is a regulated business. You have retail, petroleum products, trading and then you have renewable hydropower plants, which is a big important sector in Georgia and TBC is one of the leaders in this sector. Hospitality and leisure has become a bigger -- taken bigger share in the portfolio. And again, this is in line with the growth and importance that the sector has taken in the Georgian economy especially in the last 12 to 18 months. On the retail side, you will see that mortgages is now more than half. It's actually about 60% of the portfolio -- of the retail portfolio and has increased since 1 year ago.

So portfolio concentration is -- we look at the right-hand chart here. The top 10 borrowers at about 10%, which is where our sort of target is and our comfort level lies. It has increased in 2018 because of some successful new corporate client acquisitions that we did during the year. As a result of that and from that, we've looked at being more active in syndicating some of these loans and have had success especially in Q1. Some of our big corporate clients also did successful capital markets transactions both on local markets and on international markets, and we have used some of these proceeds to repay local bank exposure but very good validation of the strength of the corporate client base that TBC has.

The next one is on -- yes, so this is on collateralization. And you know that we have strongly collateralized portfolio. 72% now is secured with cash, gold, real estate. And it's really -- we leverage this in recovery work that we do with certain clients obviously. Our unsecured portfolio is 11%. 1 year ago, this was 17%. So this has come down. And again, it's resulting from the change in the portfolio structure and the consumer products, reducing the share of the portfolio.

Yes. So this is obviously something that we look at closely, the foreign currency share of the portfolio total is 60%. It hasn't really come down in Q1 and/or 2018. And regulations in the portfolio structure had -- has had impact on this as well. Because if we look at it segment by segment, we'll see that corporate has decreased, business borrowers have decreased. But in retail, it has actually increased, and it's increased because mortgages now represent a bigger share of the total portfolio, and mortgages at this point is a more dollarized portfolio than consumer.

Now having said that, we look at disbursements in quarter 1 in mortgages, and a significantly bigger portion of mortgages is now being disbursed in Georgian lari than what it was 1 year ago. So about 50% now versus 20% 1 year ago. So over time, we expect to see that mortgage portfolio will start to sort of dedollarize, so to say, and that will sort of drive overall dedollarization in the portfolio.

So very quickly on this because we mentioned earlier, we had stable performance. Again, 2018 in terms of NPL were 3.1%, which is historically lowest in recent years and 3.3% in Q1, cost of risk at 1.4% on an FX-adjusted basis, lower than 1.7% in the quarter in the prior period.
