We understood what type of package they would need, and now we are actively onboarding them into this subscription service. Basically, we launched B Com. B Com is kind of a club where people would buy a subscription and join the club. In this subscription, they would have a certain product set which would come for free, for instance, ATM withdrawal for free and some other transfers like several transfers for free per month and per period. And this is like B Fix. It is for generic use. Then we have our agro-specific subscription and then for premium customers. And this is all based on heavily on data analytics. We already have -- we launched a couple of weeks ago. We already have something around 1,000 customers onboarded. And I mean we will massively push on it because we do believe that the customers should not be spending their energy and time on understanding how much fees they pay or when they pay them, which fee it was and so on and so on. They should just pay one fee, and that's it. The model is quite innovative because there are not many examples within Eastern Europe which would bring SME and business customers to subscription base because in banking, basically, we still charge basically different fees, right? All these neobanks and Space type of banks, right, they would do the subscription. But the traditional retail banking and the business banking model would still differentiate per fees. And we think that this trial will give us better consumer experience and more trust with the customers.

Yes. Just a quick summary on this. This is our traditional business support, nonfinancial services. We do a lot in this regard because we believe that being the best business supporter is something which positions us very well with the customers. With business education, we already have almost 15,000 trained businesses, trained 1,300 startups. We perform this business award, which is kind of Oscars, for best businesses in Georgia, and we already had 1,500 participants. And in the education -- no, it's a mistake, it should be startup program. We have already 24,000 startups participating in our startup program. And we granted loan to 490, which is the amount of GEL 102 million loan portfolio, and these are different things. We finance, for instance -- as the tourism industry grows, we finance hotels, we finance smaller companies and many others. We have special dedicated programs for this.

This is something interesting we launched last year. And last year, I just mentioned it, and here, we already have results. The purpose here was to understand if there are any technology solutions for businesses in Georgia. And if there are not many, somehow to promote it, basically to create a platform, a classified platform where customers' businesses could compare different solutions, would it be accounting, invoicing or others, payroll or expense management solutions and compare them with each other and choose the one and then approach the provider and basically contract. So basically, we already have 53 vendors and then 60 tools, and we definitely saw the increase of the platform in terms of numbers because we basically promote this platform within our 130,000 customer base so that they go on the platform and choose the best service for their use. And this, again, serves a better experience for the customers and more digitalization in their businesses.

One of the last slides. Yes, this is quite a heavy, heavy, heavy visual. However, what I wanted to show here is -- this was also presented last year is the ecosystem view we have for our customers. So in the middle, we have the customer. Around the first layer is the segments we serve, right, agro business, micro startups, mature businesses. Then the next layer is the channels we use to serve the customers, then are the products basically -- no, the service model basically how we serve them, relationship management or the call center or digital self-service and so on. And the last layer is exactly the ecosystem layer where we would think about different solutions, how to basically surround the customer with those solutions and make him maximally happy with us so that the stickiness will grow, the loyalty will grow and the churn will decrease.

And in this regard, we are doing some exercises. For this year -- and this is just a quick summary of the whole presentation, where basically the whole accent this year in 2019, and of course, this will flow over to the next years, is to make sure that we are properly positioned. And everything I told you, properly positioned means that we are now trying to create a web platform where we will have everything on the same platform for the customer. Just a good example would be in Google, right? On the Google page, you have on the right side the click, and you have all the solutions of Google, right, Google Docs, Google PowerPoint and all the stuff. So something like this. So we want all our solutions to be on one portal so the customer can go there and onboard on any of them and find it easy to onboard.

Distribution channel mix. So what we are improving and renewing and reshuffling is the Internet mobile banking, and we are working now on the business financial management tool basically, which will help the customers to analyze their expense structure better. The next one is the processes where we invest a lot of time in web sales. So we target to build a web sales engine where we will be selling online with the online lending pages, which is not the practice now in the country, but we will pilot it this year. Now lending automation, David also was mentioning this, we target to be very fast in lending, to improve the reaction time to cash and to build special document flow and process flow systems for this. And the front-end optimization. Front-end optimization basically is directly hitting this 3 to 5 minutes onboarding process and all the same type of things. Why? Because if the process which the operator or the banking employee runs through the computer is heavy, then how can we imagine him or her serving the customer easily, right? Because we have to have the same UX and UI on the both ends, on the customer end and on the banking end.

And the last one is exactly from the ecosystem slide. We are currently working on the accounting and invoicing solutions where we would facilitate the interaction of our customers with these solutions. Basically, we will build an accounting platform and an invoicing platform. Just a figure for invoicing, we -- by analyzing, we understood that 50% of our customers would invoice each other within TBC basically. But now they are doing it from outer sources, right? So the invoice would go out, per e-mail, per whatever Excel simple format, and then it will land again into the TBC accounts. What we want, we want to connect the network, and this is exactly called the network effects, right? If we create value within the network, the customers will stick to the network, and they will churn less.

This is in natural the strategy and the key points for MSME. And of course, on the questions and answers, I'll be happy to answer. Thank you.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Thank you, Niko. So last but not least, we will now talk about our relatively young but dynamically developing insurance business. So I hand it over to Paata Gadzadze.

PAATA GADZADZE, CEO OF TBC INSURANCE, TBC BANK GROUP PLC: Good evening, sir, and ladies and gentlemen. I'll do my best to be shorter and to take care about your time, and then we take care -- I'll do my best to make life easier to our investors as well, not only our customers.

So very brief about the performance of last year and some indications about the current situation in insurance business. As you see, the penetration of total insurance market is -- the insurance activities in the GDP is still very low, and it's promising because it's growing very rapidly. And the dynamic is shown here is that the portion of health and nonhealth is -- the health insurance is more or less the same. But in absolute amount, the property and casualty in nonhealth insurance is quite -- has increased quite rapidly.

As for the breakdown by products, health is -- remains around 40%. Motor Casco is about 24%, and the next one is property. And in life and property -- in life and personal accident, mostly the biggest driver is still banking sector and its credit-linked related products.

Totally, in Georgia, there are 17 insurance companies. Last year, personally, I remember that I promised to become the #1 insurance companies. And usually, TBC keeps its words and promise, and I'll tell you that out of these 17 companies, the TBC became the biggest growing company and really marketing maker in retail insurers. And we will see it in the next slides, this -- how we are keeping these promises.

So here we are. Market share in retail, we are almost 38%, and in total market share, we are second biggest maintaining 20%. Still we have challenges in business and corporate and SME part. But we should underline here that TBC Insurance is not at all focused on state- and government-related insurance. And therefore, we don't have here the biggest market share, and we have a very conservative approach on corporate side. And still we will maintain -- I mean our strategy is more focused on nonstate insurance part.

Here, we have updated version. It's even more market share in almost 40% of quarter 1 in retail and around 22% in total market share. So even within quarter base, it's changed quite rapidly.

Here, we've shown the second -- I mean our main competitor who has more than 35 -- 32 years history in insurance activity in Georgia. And we are quite young, like 2.5 years ago, we established our new brand insurance. And so you can see here the gap, how the gap decreased in -- between us and how the gap increased in retail market with our peer competitor.

As for our TBC Insurance breakdown by products and channels, thanks to Nino and she's very -- quite a good -- I mean the engagement in starting the designing the very comprehensive Bancassurance platform. And thanks to all these efforts, we maintained a very good platform, IT and including the staff -- that includes staff training and so on. Still we have a 48% in Bancassurance, the true Bancassurance, which is not at all related to the mandatory sales, but it's only Bancassurance. We will see how the mandatory credit-related portion is decreasing year-by-year and even quarter-by-quarter. So still we have a -- and the retail portion is 1 quarter, and the business, including corporate and SME, is 1 quarter.

As for the products, here, the domination is -- has motor. Life and personal accident is increasing, and even noncredit related also is increasing portion. Here is the composition.

This slide shows the performance for last year, so you can see the premium for last 2.5 years and quarter-by-quarter. And in both, I mentioned, in growing -- how we are growing our business, and in profitability as well is quite significant. And we are proud that we keep all these financial targets and risk targets also. And keeping these targets and maintaining the highest profitability is pretty much impressive.

Here, we can see that which channels are used for each direction of products. I would say that TBC Insurance, leveraging all these IT technologies and the competence in digitalization, we are the leaders in insurance market. All others are mostly using all the traditional approaches in both side, in risk scoring and in sales. And TBC is -- right now is doing a lot -- investing a lot in technologies, and we are very proud that the second bot, B Bot, we call it, sells almost 100% of small-ticket insurance like including travel insurance, I mean where we are -- where we don't pay any commission, which is not a usual case in -- not only in our case but in -- globally. So it's very simplified procedures, and all the digitalization is on place here.

And here, I would mention that the last slide was very impressive that -- oop, sorry. Too much again. Offloading ratio. For last year, we managed to reach 43% of all policies sold, offloading ratio, mostly in Casco and small-ticket insurance. Mostly this is Casco, personal insurance and travel insurance. So it's very high even to the local -- even to the Western standards, especially in insurance.

These are our midterm targets. Still we have biggest ambitions to maintain in total market share, not only in retail but in total market share, more than 30% and then keeping combined ratio less than 80%. Offloading, even more than 50%. And for sure, as we are the service company as the TBC has a strategic focus on NPS, more than 65%.

And the last -- the second part and the last slides are focused on health insurance. Year -- a month ago, we launched health insurance focused only on private, high, well-paid individuals, not in retail but it's B2B. Again, our target is to make -- to create a 5-star health insurance companies. We are focused on this 5 -- I mentioned that the #1 market share on premium segment in sizable -- I mean by numbers of insured this year, 50,000 more. Best customer experience, innovation in services, including those digitalization, of course, in claims service, which is very important in health insurance as well. And keeping also the financial effectiveness and -- targets of financial effectiveness, including loss ratios and combined ratios. Thank you so much.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Now the wine tasting.

Questions and Answers

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Not just yet. Not just yet. All right. This is the last presentation. We'd like to open the floor again for questions. Yes, Mikha in the back there.

MIKHAIL SHLEMOV: I wanted to ask about the consumer lending regulations, especially the part which was related to the income verification. I think it was said in the risk management part that some part of the bankable -- previous bankable population was left out of in euros. Perhaps if you could provide an estimate of what part of the population you think is coming from bankable. This is the first part.

And the second part is relating actually to the micro segment where I would assume the majority of borrowers are also similar individual persons. However, I guess -- and whatever, you are now also obliged to make an income verification in the segment as well. And depending on answer, on whatever you have seen basically, immigration of the clients between the consumer -- between the retail lending and the micro lending.

DAVID CHKONIA: So on the first question, there are a number of -- there are some customer groups that are -- will just be unable to prove -- to provide verification. There will be customer groups -- there will be product types as well that will not be able to be done and be underwritten, and so we have changed sort of some of the products in the bank as well. But those types of products just will not be -- will not work under new regulation. So it's things like this that's on the fringes.

And then I would say that on micro -- in micro, actually, we have been doing sort of verification of income of borrowers. So in fact, the regulator has used the approaches that banks have in micro as the potential role model for how things can be done on the retail side as well.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Andrew? Andreas (inaudible)?

ANDREAS MARKOU, ANALYST, JOH. BERENBERG, GOSSLER & CO. KG, RESEARCH DIVISION: It's Andreas from Berenberg. One question for David to start off. So to -- but maybe we can go to Giorgi. Okay. So to what extent can you use the big data you will be collecting from the ecosystems to improve your scoring models? How much do you think you can actually improve your cost of risk through this extra data? And then 2 questions for Giorgi. First one, what is the potential impact of the bond issuance on your margins? And second, on regulation, so we've seen a lot of regulation in Georgia this year. What is left to come?

DAVID CHKONIA: I think definitely, we'll be -- we want to use and we will be using data. Let's start collecting the data. Let's start to look at what kind of data we collect. We're definitely going to be using it. And then maybe next time around, we'll have something more specific on the impact from the financial side of that thing.

GIORGI SHAGIDZE: Yes. On the margins, I think we need to say kind of -- initially -- the first quarter when we held the bonds and in the medium-term impact, initially it's going to be 10, 20 basis points. And then over time, it's -- the impact will diminish. It won't be very material. And obviously we see lots of benefits there from the perspective of diversifying our funding source and improving the -- net stable funding ratio, which is good, but still.

With regards to the second part, I mean I think the other regulation we are hearing which will happen is about the net stable funding ratio introduction. We did do internal assessment, and based on the assessment, we don't see any material impact on TBC. Also we are hearing -- and this is also reasonable to expect that over time, when we see how the regulation impacted the book, we might see fine-tuning, especially specific areas such as, I don't know, mortgages. There are 60,000 mortgages in the country. And we might see fine-tuning and improvement within certain groups.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Okay. Next question, gentleman in the middle.

OWEN CALLAN, HEAD OF FINANCIALS RESEARCH & BANKING ANALYST, INVESTEC BANK PLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Owen Callan from Investec. I know earlier you spoke about Uzbekistan and Azerbaijan specifically as markets you're entering by the retail bank mainly both from the Insurance division or the CIB division. Is there plans to go outside Georgia as well over maybe medium term into those countries or other countries neighboring Georgia? And then a second question is on regulation. I was wondering, is there any sort of -- obviously, U.S. and European banks would -- EU banks would be stress tested and part of stress testing cycle. Is there a similar kind of cycle that the Georgian authorities have? And just maybe if you could explain that to us or if there is anything like that.

GIORGI SHAGIDZE: Maybe I can answer on Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan. I think our target in both countries of Uzbekistan and Azerbaijan is, firstly, digital as much asset light as possible. And secondly, our target customer base is retail and SME. So we are not or we will not be targeting the corporate customers. And that's regarding on both.

Within the financial offering and, again, digital offering, you never exclude insurance offering across those countries. And in fact, a lot of ecosystems that we discussed today are scalable, and it's very easy that these ecosystems should deploy on -- across other countries. And for sure, as we progress, we see more offering across these countries.

DAVID CHKONIA: On stress testing, so our regulator, the National Bank of Georgia, has an annual sort of comprehensive stress testing program of banks. It's been -- there had been 2 years, 2 iterations of the stress tests, so last year and the year before. And it's a holistic stress test that all banks have to do and submit to the regulators. So that would be the equivalent. And the stress test going forward will also be linked the new capital setting -- capital framework that we have in there. There's a specific stress test buffer in the framework. Yes.

I just wanted to add one thing on the data question as well, actually. Just one sort of example, sound bite. Even though right now our scorecards are working with 1,300 data points in our spending data, credit history data, et cetera, et cetera. But we always look -- so for example, just now there's a process ongoing in Space where we have potentially -- are thinking that the number of taps that a customer is doing on the phone could potentially be predictive of certain types of behaviors. So we're testing that type of data right now to see if it can be a useful addition to the analysis. So it always -- it's an ongoing process all the time. And so we'll see what we get. I imagine we're going to be getting a wealth of data from ecosystems. Yes.

GIORGI SHAGIDZE: Maybe a little remark on stress test. Firstly, we are very well capitalized, I mean in terms of equity-to-asset ratio. So we are about 15% as the banking sector. And secondly, there was a statement that reminded me by NBG just stating that the -- after the stress test result, NBG sees that the system is worth lending the stress tests that they defined. And usually, they do define quite conservative stress tests and approaches.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Andrew? Andrew, yes.

ANDREW KEELEY: Yes. Just a brief follow-up on the PTI. We basically saw retail lending contracting for you guys quite strongly and I think for the sector as a whole. I mean is there a risk of a real kind of slowdown, kind of credit crunch in retail lending because of the introduction of PTI? And do you think kind of having had this for a little while now, that the threshold the National Bank has kind of got it right? Or really, the thresholds are too strict and that there is this risk of a major slowdown basically?

NINO MASURASHVILI: So since we already have 200,000 thresholds and all consumer loans mainly are withdrawn in general. So PTI for consumer lending, it is not right way like it's major preventer. The main thing here is income verification because just imagine, when we're issuing, let's say 1,000 credit card or 1,000 POS loan in -- out of the branches, and it's becoming really very difficult to go and to check and verify the income by the physical, which was previously done by the preapproving loan lending and this (inaudible), et cetera. So we think that at some point, I guess that the NBG will be ready in the future because there is such a type of talk that they will be using some income verification models, et cetera. So we are like adopting -- the banks, all the banks on the market adopting to find a different method of verification to income compared to what we had today. But PTI, in general, it is quite normal and it is not that we can prevent. In the USD dollar, where we are dispersing the mortgage loan, then PTI is really preventing the mortgage lending in dollars term. But for consumer loans, it is not a big preventer.

ANDREW KEELEY: Okay. And this is -- unplugs our space (inaudible) for quick loan approval. Was that including income verification?

GIORGI SHAGIDZE: Yes.

DAVID CHKONIA: Yes.

NINO MASURASHVILI: It's payable.

DAVID CHKONIA: It is the same thing we just use the process, which is fully automated.

PAATA GADZADZE: If I may to add on credit crunch, so I think the appetite of Central Bank is pretty similar, pretty same word to what's described as the guidelines, so up to 15% credit growth. And again, NBG stated several times that they stand ready to amend regulations if they see credit slowing more than what was expected. Also you see same statements from IMF. They continue to say that the dynamics should be monitored carefully, et cetera. And as Giorgi mentioned, there was already first message on mortgages. The last statement was not only that they are monitoring, but they are monitoring specifically also mortgage segment. So I would say the probability of credit crunch is very low.

ZOLTAN SZALAI: Any more questions? Okay. Well, then this is I guess the end of the formal part of the afternoon. So now we can proceed to Georgian winetasting. And again, we thank you very much for coming.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5P25-V3C1-F00X-J4T6-00000-00TD Ameritrade CEO: Here's How Love for Big Tech Stocks Like Apple Just Helped Us2017-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:10ZLexisNexisTD Ameritrade CEO: Here's How Love for Big Tech Stocks Like Apple Just Helped UsJames Langford

TD Ameritrade CEO Tim Hockey talks with TheStreet post earnings.

Investors liked what they saw from TD Ameritrade .

Shares of the financial services provider rose 4.3% to $46.72 on Tuesday following better than expected fiscal third quarter earnings. TD Ameritrade's bottom line came in at 44 cents a share, above Wall Street estimates for 41 cents a share, despite lower trading commissions. The company was boosted by new account growth and asset-based revenue -- total revenue rose 11% from the prior year to $931 million, eclipsing forecasts for $899.5 million. 

TheStreet talked with TD Ameritrade CEO Tim Hockey about the quarter and overall trading environment. What follows is a condensed and edited version of our conversation.


Question: The Scottrade acquisition closes soon - do you anticipate a need to get even larger?


A: The closing is still on track: We said Sept. 30, and we're hoping to advance that by a month or so. We literally only have the Federal Reserve and the Canadian bank regulator left to opine. In terms of additional M&A, we've got pretty enormous scale post Scottrade, over $1 trillion in assets and over 10 million in client accounts. Scale used to be an incredibly important thing in any business, but my general philosophy is that scale past a certain size tends to be less important than it used to be: A) because it drives you to be slower just because you're a larger firm and speed is very important, and B) because smaller players can now almost mimic scale at a very early stage in their development.

The examples everybody likes to talk about are Airbnb having more hotel rooms and actually not having a hotel at all and Uber being [one of the world's largest car companies] yet they don't actually have any cars. These are companies that have [amassed] global scale very quickly. To me, speed in the last number of years has become more important than sheer scale once you get past a certain size, and we've passed that size.


Q: We are seeing such a strong appetite by investors for top tech names. How much is interest in tech stocks fueling Ameritrade?


A: Clearly, the traditional FANG (Facebook , Apple , Netflix and Google ) stocks are the ones that drive retail. We had a broader retail engagement, and retail clients, as you know, tend to trade those things that they know. They trade the brands that they know -- they trade Netflix , they trade Amazon , Nvidia was a big trader this particular quarter.

These are all brands, consumer brands that, notably, our millennial and active traders like to talk about because they know them.


Q: Your average trades per day surged to about 510,000 despite trading declines at some of the big Wall Street firms amid lower volatility. How did you pull that off?


A: It's a bit of a conundrum. If you look at how the numbers were mathematically generated, there was an uptick in net new accounts generated this [fiscal] year, and literally, in the first three quarters, we did more than we did in all of last year. That then led to a total of about 6% growth in the actual number of accounts, and on average, those accounts traded a little more than they did last year. It was the combination of those three trailing factors that we were up 10% year-over-year.

With a 30% reduction in [online stock and ETF trade commissions, from $9.99 to $6.95 in March], the impact was offset by larger account numbers times more trades, which means that it literally was only a one-cent year-over-year impact on commission revenue.

I wouldn't have thought lower pricing would drive more trading because we didn't think the pricing sensitivity of retail clients at these low levels was such that a lower price drives more activity, but there might be a factor in that.


Brian Sozzi contributed to this story.


Facebook, Apple, and Alphabet are holdings in Jim Cramer's Action Alerts PLUS Charitable Trust Portfolio . Want to be alerted before Cramer buys or sells FB, AAPL and GOOGL?   Learn more now.

urn:contentItem:5WDH-PXH1-JBSN-12JH-00000-00TDD: Big Tech = 19th Century RR; Tories' Brexit Fears2019-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:10ZLexisNexisTDD: Big Tech = 19th Century RR; Tories' Brexit Fearsby Ronald Fink

Happy Hump Day. Big Tech may seem to confuse the current crop of antitrust regulators, scratching their heads as they do over whether deals by Alphabet, Facebook and the like https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/14762280/index.dl|encourage or quash innovation. But   https://www.azquotes.com/author/14637-Henry_David_Thoreau/tag/simplicity|as Thoreau advised, Simplify, People! Simplify! To do that, simply check out an FT column in which the author draws a   https://www.ft.com/content/ec3cbe78-8dc7-11e9-a1c1-51bf8f989972|historical parallel between tech and the railroads of the 19th century. Today's monopoly problem isn't really that different, writes Rana Foroohar.

Brexit? Talk about cutting your own nose off to spite your face, a Yougov poll finds https://bit.ly/2ZvJtac|the Tories worry more that leaving the EU will make Jeremy Corbyn PM than that it will significantly damage the U.K. economy or destroy their own party. Then again, the LRB's David Runciman notes in the June 20 issue that for Boris Johnson at least,   https://www.lrb.co.uk/v41/n12/david-runciman/steely-women-in-a-world-of-wobbly-men|chaos would be a feature, not a bug.

Movers & Shakers: Irena Royzman is leaving Patterson Belknap to join Kramer Levin's patent litigation practice as a partner in New York. See the rest of the column for more people news.

urn:contentItem:5WP0-PCP1-JBSN-11XD-00000-00TDD: DOJ Confirms Big Tech Review; For-Profit Ed Looks to DeVos2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:10ZLexisNexisTDD: DOJ Confirms Big Tech Review; For-Profit Ed Looks to DeVosby Ronald Fink

Hello, Wednesday. https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/justice-department-reviewing-practices-market-leading-online-platforms|The DOJ's announcement that it has initiated a formal investigation into Big Tech confirms what's been apparent for months: The antitrust zeitgeist has shifted from deregulation to enforcement in the case of Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Google. That said, the DOJ inquiry seems to focus more on behavior than on dealmaking, as David Hatch pointed out to us this AM. The DOJ says it's reviewing "practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers." That's not to say the trustbusters won't challenge deals they fear will stifle innovation. What does that, however, is subject to dispute, as David has explained. DOJ antitrust chief Makan Delrahim himself has belittled some aggressive thinking on this question as   https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/14941958/index.dl|"hipster" antitrust." Meanwhile, the FTC announced   https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/24/tech/facebook-ftc-settlement/index.html|a settlement with Facebook over charges of mishandling user data that will see the company pay a $5B fine. That's by far a record fine but only a month of Facebook revenue.

Speaking of regulation, the for-profit school industry https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/23/us/politics/dream-center.html|was betting that EdSec Betsy DeVos would give them a break, but two cases in the news today suggest they'll need more than that. A NYT report shows LA-based Dream Center Education Holdings was counting on the department to   https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/14639813/index.dl|keep it on life support even though it was accused of enrolling new students and taking federal aid after some campuses lost their accreditation. No such luck, evidently. And states are filling at least part of the gap DeVos may have created: Oklahoma officials are going after Epic Youth Services for allegedly   https://oklahomawatch.org/2019/07/16/search-warrant-alleges-embezzlement-use-of-ghost-students-by-epic-schools/|faking enrollment numbers in order to receive state aid.

Movers & Shakers: Healthcare banker David Laufer has moved from RBC to Wells Fargo. See the rest of the column for more people news.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VTG-2771-DY7P-R3NW-00000-00TDD: Trade, Taxes and Big Tech2019-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisTDD: Trade, Taxes and Big Techby Ronald Fink

Happy Monday. The trade deficit may have more to do with taxes than with anything else, according to Brad Setser of the Council of Foreign Relations. Setser points out that U.S. pharmaceutical companies' efforts to shift manufacturing to low-tax jurisdictions drives a significant proportion of the trade deficit in goods, https://www.cfr.org/blog/when-tax-drives-trade-data|exceeding as it does the surplus in civil aircraft (at least before   https://edition.cnn.com/2019/03/27/perspectives/boeing-737-max-8-dennis-muilenburg/index.html|Boeing's troubles). And as Setser has explained elsewhere, the recent changes in the tax law   https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/06/opinion/business-economics/trump-tax-reform-state-of-the-union-2019.html?module=inline|have done little to bring off-shored operations in any industry back to the U.S. That would take the closing of loopholes, not just a reduction in the top corporate rate. After all, why pay the new U.S. corporate rate of 21% when you can pay the new global minimum of 10%? Other recent research shows that corporate profit shifting to tax havens puts   https://www.nber.org/papers/w23324|a significant dent in U.S. GDP.

Regulation Nation? When even Harvard econ prof Ken Rogoff endorses Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren's plans for breaking up Big Tech, calling government merger policy in the past few decades https://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/elizabeth-warren-tech-regulation-proposals-by-kenneth-rogoff-2019-04|"exceptionally permissive," you know we've seen a shift in public opinion. David Hatch has more on antitrust below.

Movers & Shakers: Today's Rising Star is Houston attorney Nick Dhesi, who was elevated to partner at Latham & Watkins after eight years as an associate. See the mini-profiles of the other 20 M&A partners we've identified as the most promising of 2019 in http://www.thedeal.com/tdp/DealmakerQuarterly_MiddleMarketDealmaking.pdf|the Q1 issue of The Dealmaker Quarterly. And see the rest of the column and check out our BoardEx scan for more people news.

-- Ronald Fink, Deputy Managing Editor

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YT5-CGN1-JD6R-T0HR-00000-00'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decide2020-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexis'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decideCrikeyABSTRACT

When the media become cheerleaders for measures that curb privacy, they undermine any defence against further government encroachments and fail the basic role of journalism: to hold the powerful to account.

FULL TEXT

Many journalists have been happy to tweet that they've downloaded the government's COVID-19 app, effectively offering a public endorsement for software developed by a government that has raided and surveilled them to stop whistleblowing and silence sources revealing information in the public interest. It's their personal information, of course, so they can do with it whatever they like, but it makes it more difficult for them to assure those sources who wish to remain anonymous that they are doing everything they can to keep their communications confidential -- unless they avoid using their phones for any interaction with sources, which is the best-practice method. Phones, after all, are just a surveillance device that you can use for phone calls. Indeed a phone with bluetooth on and the screen permanently unlocked -- which the COVID-19 app needs to function effectively -- is a spy or a hacker's wet dream. Some in the media have gone further. They have compared people with privacy concerns to terrorists, to   anti-vaxxers, or called them   "Twitter cranks and contrarians". One   senior journalist described the app as a "test" for Australians. Even those deeply concerned about the threat of government surveillance   have argued that big tech companies are worse than any government app. Many outlets have reported with an air of triumph about the rapid take-up of the app, although there's been less of that in the past 24 hours as the initial surge has faded. The view of app advocates in the media is, perhaps, understandable: they want to play their part in getting Australia through this unprecedented -- at least in the lifetime of anyone under 100 -- crisis. They're working for "Team Australia" because "we're all in this together". A little cheerleading for the government, if it helps improve uptake of the app, is worth it -- after all "the life you save could be your own", etc. Journalists are being pandemic patriots rather than crisis curmudgeons. One problem with this is that it essentially destroys the media's argument against further extensions of government powers of surveillance and control in relation to national security matters. There is very little difference between public health and national security: in both cases the media must take the government's word about the nature of the public threat, and in both cases governments claim the right to infringe basic freedoms and hide from scrutiny (remember the refusal to release modelling because it might frighten people?) on the basis of public interest. Next time the government wants to give itself new powers to collect information, or surveil the population, or undermine cybersecurity, the mainstream media cannot object. Haven't they led the way in urging the population to surrender some privacy for the public benefit against an insidious threat the government wants to protect us against? Indeed, hasn't the media compared privacy advocates to terrorists -- a practice normally reserved for politicians who like to argue anyone resistant to the loss of basic freedoms is on the side of terrorists or pedophiles -- and suggested they're as delusional as anti-vaxxers? Aren't the tech giants much much worse anyway? The next extension of surveillance powers so the government can better track down journalists' sources will be a test for the media: whose side are they really on? The broader problem is that it's not the media's role to be pandemic patriots. It is the job of the media to hold the powerful -- and particularly governments -- to account. At a time when governments are handing themselves truly extraordinary powers of coercion and withdrawing basic freedoms from the population, this is more the case than at any time in recent decades. When it proposes to place a surveillance app on the phone of -- it hopes -- the entire population, the case for vigorous interrogation of its proposal is especially strong. Some ABC journalists, to their credit, have done their job.   Linton Besser and Dylan Welch have exposed the fact that data from the app was within reach of US security agencies courtesy of far-reaching US laws that presume to override those of other countries. In doing so they also exposed the distressing fact that Australian politicians and bureaucrats knew much less about US laws  and their extraterritorial intent than journalists did. This has been something of an exception at the ABC which has enthusiastically adopted a "Team Australia" approach to its coverage, including senior journalists criticising Australians for failing to rigidly adhere to the often absurdly draconian lockdown laws imposed by state governments. It's not merely the nature of the powers governments are arrogating during the crisis that necessitates journalists being watchdogs rather than cheerleaders. The media itself, enduring an existential crisis that is smashing its beleaguered business model, faces a future in which it will be more dependent on government favours -- via grants programs and regulatory relief -- than at any time in its history. The Australian commercial media's future may very well depend on continued government support. This will be a dangerous time for accountability. Will media outlets balk at standing up for press freedom or challenging failed policy or corruption if they perceive it might endanger their success in the next grant round? The times call for public interest journalism and vigorous watchdogs, not "Team Australia" and cheerleader journalists. And that call will only grow stronger as media revenue crumbles.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YV1-8891-JD6R-T0P8-00000-00'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decide2020-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:10ZLexisNexis'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decideCrikeyABSTRACT

When the media become cheerleaders for measures that curb privacy, they undermine any defence against further government encroachments and fail the basic role of journalism: to hold the powerful to account.

FULL TEXT

Many journalists have been happy to tweet that they've downloaded the government's COVID-19 app, effectively offering a public endorsement for software developed by a government that has raided and surveilled them to stop whistleblowing and silence sources revealing information in the public interest. It's their personal information, of course, so they can do with it whatever they like, but it makes it more difficult for them to assure those sources who wish to remain anonymous that they are doing everything they can to keep their communications confidential -- unless they avoid using their phones for any interaction with sources, which is the best-practice method. Phones, after all, are just a surveillance device that you can use for phone calls. Indeed a phone with bluetooth on and the screen permanently unlocked -- which the COVID-19 app needs to function effectively -- is a spy or a hacker's wet dream. Some in the media have gone further. They have compared people with privacy concerns to terrorists, to   anti-vaxxers, or called them   "Twitter cranks and contrarians". One   senior journalist described the app as a "test" for Australians. Even those deeply concerned about the threat of government surveillance   have argued that big tech companies are worse than any government app. Many outlets have reported with an air of triumph about the rapid take-up of the app, although there's been less of that in the past 24 hours as the initial surge has faded. The view of app advocates in the media is, perhaps, understandable: they want to play their part in getting Australia through this unprecedented -- at least in the lifetime of anyone under 100 -- crisis. They're working for "Team Australia" because "we're all in this together". A little cheerleading for the government, if it helps improve uptake of the app, is worth it -- after all "the life you save could be your own", etc. Journalists are being pandemic patriots rather than crisis curmudgeons. One problem with this is that it essentially destroys the media's argument against further extensions of government powers of surveillance and control in relation to national security matters. There is very little difference between public health and national security: in both cases the media must take the government's word about the nature of the public threat, and in both cases governments claim the right to infringe basic freedoms and hide from scrutiny (remember the refusal to release modelling because it might frighten people?) on the basis of public interest. Next time the government wants to give itself new powers to collect information, or surveil the population, or undermine cybersecurity, the mainstream media cannot object. Haven't they led the way in urging the population to surrender some privacy for the public benefit against an insidious threat the government wants to protect us against? Indeed, hasn't the media compared privacy advocates to terrorists -- a practice normally reserved for politicians who like to argue anyone resistant to the loss of basic freedoms is on the side of terrorists or pedophiles -- and suggested they're as delusional as anti-vaxxers? Aren't the tech giants much much worse anyway? The next extension of surveillance powers so the government can better track down journalists' sources will be a test for the media: whose side are they really on? The broader problem is that it's not the media's role to be pandemic patriots. It is the job of the media to hold the powerful -- and particularly governments -- to account. At a time when governments are handing themselves truly extraordinary powers of coercion and withdrawing basic freedoms from the population, this is more the case than at any time in recent decades. When it proposes to place a surveillance app on the phone of -- it hopes -- the entire population, the case for vigorous interrogation of its proposal is especially strong. Some ABC journalists, to their credit, have done their job.   Linton Besser and Dylan Welch have exposed the fact that data from the app was within reach of US security agencies courtesy of far-reaching US laws that presume to override those of other countries. In doing so they also exposed the distressing fact that Australian politicians and bureaucrats knew much less about US laws  and their extraterritorial intent than journalists did. This has been something of an exception at the ABC which has enthusiastically adopted a "Team Australia" approach to its coverage, including senior journalists criticising Australians for failing to rigidly adhere to the often absurdly draconian lockdown laws imposed by state governments. It's not merely the nature of the powers governments are arrogating during the crisis that necessitates journalists being watchdogs rather than cheerleaders. The media itself, enduring an existential crisis that is smashing its beleaguered business model, faces a future in which it will be more dependent on government favours -- via grants programs and regulatory relief -- than at any time in its history. The Australian commercial media's future may very well depend on continued government support. This will be a dangerous time for accountability. Will media outlets balk at standing up for press freedom or challenging failed policy or corruption if they perceive it might endanger their success in the next grant round? The times call for public interest journalism and vigorous watchdogs, not "Team Australia" and cheerleader journalists. And that call will only grow stronger as media revenue crumbles.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YV6-X6R1-F0NT-H1BK-00000-00'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decide2020-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexis'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decideCrikeyABSTRACT

When the media become cheerleaders for measures that curb privacy, they undermine any defence against further government encroachments and fail the basic role of journalism: to hold the powerful to account.

FULL TEXT

Many journalists have been happy to tweet that they've downloaded the government's COVID-19 app, effectively offering a public endorsement for software developed by a government that has raided and surveilled them to stop whistleblowing and silence sources revealing information in the public interest. It's their personal information, of course, so they can do with it whatever they like, but it makes it more difficult for them to assure those sources who wish to remain anonymous that they are doing everything they can to keep their communications confidential -- unless they avoid using their phones for any interaction with sources, which is the best-practice method. Phones, after all, are just a surveillance device that you can use for phone calls. Indeed a phone with bluetooth on and the screen permanently unlocked -- which the COVID-19 app needs to function effectively -- is a spy or a hacker's wet dream. Some in the media have gone further. They have compared people with privacy concerns to terrorists, to   anti-vaxxers, or called them   "Twitter cranks and contrarians". One   senior journalist described the app as a "test" for Australians. Even those deeply concerned about the threat of government surveillance   have argued that big tech companies are worse than any government app. Many outlets have reported with an air of triumph about the rapid take-up of the app, although there's been less of that in the past 24 hours as the initial surge has faded. The view of app advocates in the media is, perhaps, understandable: they want to play their part in getting Australia through this unprecedented -- at least in the lifetime of anyone under 100 -- crisis. They're working for "Team Australia" because "we're all in this together". A little cheerleading for the government, if it helps improve uptake of the app, is worth it -- after all "the life you save could be your own", etc. Journalists are being pandemic patriots rather than crisis curmudgeons. One problem with this is that it essentially destroys the media's argument against further extensions of government powers of surveillance and control in relation to national security matters. There is very little difference between public health and national security: in both cases the media must take the government's word about the nature of the public threat, and in both cases governments claim the right to infringe basic freedoms and hide from scrutiny (remember the refusal to release modelling because it might frighten people?) on the basis of public interest. Next time the government wants to give itself new powers to collect information, or surveil the population, or undermine cybersecurity, the mainstream media cannot object. Haven't they led the way in urging the population to surrender some privacy for the public benefit against an insidious threat the government wants to protect us against? Indeed, hasn't the media compared privacy advocates to terrorists -- a practice normally reserved for politicians who like to argue anyone resistant to the loss of basic freedoms is on the side of terrorists or pedophiles -- and suggested they're as delusional as anti-vaxxers? Aren't the tech giants much much worse anyway? The next extension of surveillance powers so the government can better track down journalists' sources will be a test for the media: whose side are they really on? The broader problem is that it's not the media's role to be pandemic patriots. It is the job of the media to hold the powerful -- and particularly governments -- to account. At a time when governments are handing themselves truly extraordinary powers of coercion and withdrawing basic freedoms from the population, this is more the case than at any time in recent decades. When it proposes to place a surveillance app on the phone of -- it hopes -- the entire population, the case for vigorous interrogation of its proposal is especially strong. Some ABC journalists, to their credit, have done their job.   Linton Besser and Dylan Welch have exposed the fact that data from the app was within reach of US security agencies courtesy of far-reaching US laws that presume to override those of other countries. In doing so they also exposed the distressing fact that Australian politicians and bureaucrats knew much less about US laws  and their extraterritorial intent than journalists did. This has been something of an exception at the ABC which has enthusiastically adopted a "Team Australia" approach to its coverage, including senior journalists criticising Australians for failing to rigidly adhere to the often absurdly draconian lockdown laws imposed by state governments. It's not merely the nature of the powers governments are arrogating during the crisis that necessitates journalists being watchdogs rather than cheerleaders. The media itself, enduring an existential crisis that is smashing its beleaguered business model, faces a future in which it will be more dependent on government favours -- via grants programs and regulatory relief -- than at any time in its history. The Australian commercial media's future may very well depend on continued government support. This will be a dangerous time for accountability. Will media outlets balk at standing up for press freedom or challenging failed policy or corruption if they perceive it might endanger their success in the next grant round? The times call for public interest journalism and vigorous watchdogs, not "Team Australia" and cheerleader journalists. And that call will only grow stronger as media revenue crumbles.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YSR-3WY1-F0NT-H530-00000-00'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decide2020-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexis'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decideCrikeyABSTRACT

When the media become cheerleaders for measures that curb privacy, they undermine any defence against further government encroachments and fail the basic role of journalism: to hold the powerful to account.

FULL TEXT

Many journalists have been happy to tweet that they've downloaded the government's COVID-19 app, effectively offering a public endorsement for software developed by a government that has raided and surveilled them to stop whistleblowing and silence sources revealing information in the public interest. It's their personal information, of course, so they can do with it whatever they like, but it makes it more difficult for them to assure those sources who wish to remain anonymous that they are doing everything they can to keep their communications confidential -- unless they avoid using their phones for any interaction with sources, which is the best-practice method. Phones, after all, are just a surveillance device that you can use for phone calls. Indeed a phone with bluetooth on and the screen permanently unlocked -- which the COVID-19 app needs to function effectively -- is a spy or a hacker's wet dream. Some in the media have gone further. They have compared people with privacy concerns to terrorists, to   anti-vaxxers, or called them   "Twitter cranks and contrarians". One   senior journalist described the app as a "test" for Australians. Even those deeply concerned about the threat of government surveillance   have argued that big tech companies are worse than any government app. Many outlets have reported with an air of triumph about the rapid take-up of the app, although there's been less of that in the past 24 hours as the initial surge has faded. The view of app advocates in the media is, perhaps, understandable: they want to play their part in getting Australia through this unprecedented -- at least in the lifetime of anyone under 100 -- crisis. They're working for "Team Australia" because "we're all in this together". A little cheerleading for the government, if it helps improve uptake of the app, is worth it -- after all "the life you save could be your own", etc. Journalists are being pandemic patriots rather than crisis curmudgeons. One problem with this is that it essentially destroys the media's argument against further extensions of government powers of surveillance and control in relation to national security matters. There is very little difference between public health and national security: in both cases the media must take the government's word about the nature of the public threat, and in both cases governments claim the right to infringe basic freedoms and hide from scrutiny (remember the refusal to release modelling because it might frighten people?) on the basis of public interest. Next time the government wants to give itself new powers to collect information, or surveil the population, or undermine cybersecurity, the mainstream media cannot object. Haven't they led the way in urging the population to surrender some privacy for the public benefit against an insidious threat the government wants to protect us against? Indeed, hasn't the media compared privacy advocates to terrorists -- a practice normally reserved for politicians who like to argue anyone resistant to the loss of basic freedoms is on the side of terrorists or pedophiles -- and suggested they're as delusional as anti-vaxxers? Aren't the tech giants much much worse anyway? The next extension of surveillance powers so the government can better track down journalists' sources will be a test for the media: whose side are they really on? The broader problem is that it's not the media's role to be pandemic patriots. It is the job of the media to hold the powerful -- and particularly governments -- to account. At a time when governments are handing themselves truly extraordinary powers of coercion and withdrawing basic freedoms from the population, this is more the case than at any time in recent decades. When it proposes to place a surveillance app on the phone of -- it hopes -- the entire population, the case for vigorous interrogation of its proposal is especially strong. Some ABC journalists, to their credit, have done their job.   Linton Besser and Dylan Welch have exposed the fact that data from the app was within reach of US security agencies courtesy of far-reaching US laws that presume to override those of other countries. In doing so they also exposed the distressing fact that Australian politicians and bureaucrats knew much less about US laws  and their extraterritorial intent than journalists did. This has been something of an exception at the ABC which has enthusiastically adopted a "Team Australia" approach to its coverage, including senior journalists criticising Australians for failing to rigidly adhere to the often absurdly draconian lockdown laws imposed by state governments. It's not merely the nature of the powers governments are arrogating during the crisis that necessitates journalists being watchdogs rather than cheerleaders. The media itself, enduring an existential crisis that is smashing its beleaguered business model, faces a future in which it will be more dependent on government favours -- via grants programs and regulatory relief -- than at any time in its history. The Australian commercial media's future may very well depend on continued government support. This will be a dangerous time for accountability. Will media outlets balk at standing up for press freedom or challenging failed policy or corruption if they perceive it might endanger their success in the next grant round? The times call for public interest journalism and vigorous watchdogs, not "Team Australia" and cheerleader journalists. And that call will only grow stronger as media revenue crumbles.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YTT-9051-F0NT-H0NV-00000-00'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decide2020-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexis'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decideCrikeyABSTRACT

When the media become cheerleaders for measures that curb privacy, they undermine any defence against further government encroachments and fail the basic role of journalism: to hold the powerful to account.

FULL TEXT

Many journalists have been happy to tweet that they've downloaded the government's COVID-19 app, effectively offering a public endorsement for software developed by a government that has raided and surveilled them to stop whistleblowing and silence sources revealing information in the public interest. It's their personal information, of course, so they can do with it whatever they like, but it makes it more difficult for them to assure those sources who wish to remain anonymous that they are doing everything they can to keep their communications confidential -- unless they avoid using their phones for any interaction with sources, which is the best-practice method. Phones, after all, are just a surveillance device that you can use for phone calls. Indeed a phone with bluetooth on and the screen permanently unlocked -- which the COVID-19 app needs to function effectively -- is a spy or a hacker's wet dream. Some in the media have gone further. They have compared people with privacy concerns to terrorists, to   anti-vaxxers, or called them   "Twitter cranks and contrarians". One   senior journalist described the app as a "test" for Australians. Even those deeply concerned about the threat of government surveillance   have argued that big tech companies are worse than any government app. Many outlets have reported with an air of triumph about the rapid take-up of the app, although there's been less of that in the past 24 hours as the initial surge has faded. The view of app advocates in the media is, perhaps, understandable: they want to play their part in getting Australia through this unprecedented -- at least in the lifetime of anyone under 100 -- crisis. They're working for "Team Australia" because "we're all in this together". A little cheerleading for the government, if it helps improve uptake of the app, is worth it -- after all "the life you save could be your own", etc. Journalists are being pandemic patriots rather than crisis curmudgeons. One problem with this is that it essentially destroys the media's argument against further extensions of government powers of surveillance and control in relation to national security matters. There is very little difference between public health and national security: in both cases the media must take the government's word about the nature of the public threat, and in both cases governments claim the right to infringe basic freedoms and hide from scrutiny (remember the refusal to release modelling because it might frighten people?) on the basis of public interest. Next time the government wants to give itself new powers to collect information, or surveil the population, or undermine cybersecurity, the mainstream media cannot object. Haven't they led the way in urging the population to surrender some privacy for the public benefit against an insidious threat the government wants to protect us against? Indeed, hasn't the media compared privacy advocates to terrorists -- a practice normally reserved for politicians who like to argue anyone resistant to the loss of basic freedoms is on the side of terrorists or pedophiles -- and suggested they're as delusional as anti-vaxxers? Aren't the tech giants much much worse anyway? The next extension of surveillance powers so the government can better track down journalists' sources will be a test for the media: whose side are they really on? The broader problem is that it's not the media's role to be pandemic patriots. It is the job of the media to hold the powerful -- and particularly governments -- to account. At a time when governments are handing themselves truly extraordinary powers of coercion and withdrawing basic freedoms from the population, this is more the case than at any time in recent decades. When it proposes to place a surveillance app on the phone of -- it hopes -- the entire population, the case for vigorous interrogation of its proposal is especially strong. Some ABC journalists, to their credit, have done their job.   Linton Besser and Dylan Welch have exposed the fact that data from the app was within reach of US security agencies courtesy of far-reaching US laws that presume to override those of other countries. In doing so they also exposed the distressing fact that Australian politicians and bureaucrats knew much less about US laws  and their extraterritorial intent than journalists did. This has been something of an exception at the ABC which has enthusiastically adopted a "Team Australia" approach to its coverage, including senior journalists criticising Australians for failing to rigidly adhere to the often absurdly draconian lockdown laws imposed by state governments. It's not merely the nature of the powers governments are arrogating during the crisis that necessitates journalists being watchdogs rather than cheerleaders. The media itself, enduring an existential crisis that is smashing its beleaguered business model, faces a future in which it will be more dependent on government favours -- via grants programs and regulatory relief -- than at any time in its history. The Australian commercial media's future may very well depend on continued government support. This will be a dangerous time for accountability. Will media outlets balk at standing up for press freedom or challenging failed policy or corruption if they perceive it might endanger their success in the next grant round? The times call for public interest journalism and vigorous watchdogs, not "Team Australia" and cheerleader journalists. And that call will only grow stronger as media revenue crumbles.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YSY-34D1-JD6R-T4FR-00000-00'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decide2020-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexis'Team Australia' or watchdogs of the powerful? A struggling media can't decideCrikeyABSTRACT

When the media become cheerleaders for measures that curb privacy, they undermine any defence against further government encroachments and fail the basic role of journalism: to hold the powerful to account.

FULL TEXT

Many journalists have been happy to tweet that they've downloaded the government's COVID-19 app, effectively offering a public endorsement for software developed by a government that has raided and surveilled them to stop whistleblowing and silence sources revealing information in the public interest. It's their personal information, of course, so they can do with it whatever they like, but it makes it more difficult for them to assure those sources who wish to remain anonymous that they are doing everything they can to keep their communications confidential -- unless they avoid using their phones for any interaction with sources, which is the best-practice method. Phones, after all, are just a surveillance device that you can use for phone calls. Indeed a phone with bluetooth on and the screen permanently unlocked -- which the COVID-19 app needs to function effectively -- is a spy or a hacker's wet dream. Some in the media have gone further. They have compared people with privacy concerns to terrorists, to   anti-vaxxers, or called them   "Twitter cranks and contrarians". One   senior journalist described the app as a "test" for Australians. Even those deeply concerned about the threat of government surveillance   have argued that big tech companies are worse than any government app. Many outlets have reported with an air of triumph about the rapid take-up of the app, although there's been less of that in the past 24 hours as the initial surge has faded. The view of app advocates in the media is, perhaps, understandable: they want to play their part in getting Australia through this unprecedented -- at least in the lifetime of anyone under 100 -- crisis. They're working for "Team Australia" because "we're all in this together". A little cheerleading for the government, if it helps improve uptake of the app, is worth it -- after all "the life you save could be your own", etc. Journalists are being pandemic patriots rather than crisis curmudgeons. One problem with this is that it essentially destroys the media's argument against further extensions of government powers of surveillance and control in relation to national security matters. There is very little difference between public health and national security: in both cases the media must take the government's word about the nature of the public threat, and in both cases governments claim the right to infringe basic freedoms and hide from scrutiny (remember the refusal to release modelling because it might frighten people?) on the basis of public interest. Next time the government wants to give itself new powers to collect information, or surveil the population, or undermine cybersecurity, the mainstream media cannot object. Haven't they led the way in urging the population to surrender some privacy for the public benefit against an insidious threat the government wants to protect us against? Indeed, hasn't the media compared privacy advocates to terrorists -- a practice normally reserved for politicians who like to argue anyone resistant to the loss of basic freedoms is on the side of terrorists or pedophiles -- and suggested they're as delusional as anti-vaxxers? Aren't the tech giants much much worse anyway? The next extension of surveillance powers so the government can better track down journalists' sources will be a test for the media: whose side are they really on? The broader problem is that it's not the media's role to be pandemic patriots. It is the job of the media to hold the powerful -- and particularly governments -- to account. At a time when governments are handing themselves truly extraordinary powers of coercion and withdrawing basic freedoms from the population, this is more the case than at any time in recent decades. When it proposes to place a surveillance app on the phone of -- it hopes -- the entire population, the case for vigorous interrogation of its proposal is especially strong. Some ABC journalists, to their credit, have done their job.   Linton Besser and Dylan Welch have exposed the fact that data from the app was within reach of US security agencies courtesy of far-reaching US laws that presume to override those of other countries. In doing so they also exposed the distressing fact that Australian politicians and bureaucrats knew much less about US laws  and their extraterritorial intent than journalists did. This has been something of an exception at the ABC which has enthusiastically adopted a "Team Australia" approach to its coverage, including senior journalists criticising Australians for failing to rigidly adhere to the often absurdly draconian lockdown laws imposed by state governments. It's not merely the nature of the powers governments are arrogating during the crisis that necessitates journalists being watchdogs rather than cheerleaders. The media itself, enduring an existential crisis that is smashing its beleaguered business model, faces a future in which it will be more dependent on government favours -- via grants programs and regulatory relief -- than at any time in its history. The Australian commercial media's future may very well depend on continued government support. This will be a dangerous time for accountability. Will media outlets balk at standing up for press freedom or challenging failed policy or corruption if they perceive it might endanger their success in the next grant round? The times call for public interest journalism and vigorous watchdogs, not "Team Australia" and cheerleader journalists. And that call will only grow stronger as media revenue crumbles.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XGK-TXV1-DXY4-X10M-00000-00Tech2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:10ZLexisNexisSection FColumn 0SpecialSectionsPg. 14TechBy Alina Tugend

The time is now.

Government regulation, public pressure, worker action -- all these and more are needed to rein in the big tech companies, which have been allowed to operate largely unhindered for too long.

That was the view of most participants at The New York Times DealBook conference task force -- made up of eight technology experts in the public and private sectors -- looking at the question of ''How Big Should Big Tech Be?''

''I think we have lived for decades now with no regulation, so to speak, of tech,'' said Chris Hughes, a co-founder of Facebook and now the co-chair of the nonprofit Economic Security Project. ''And the time's come due for regulation, for structural solutions and for a general cultural rethinking of how to ensure that these platforms are working for us rather than us working for the platforms.''

The challenges include increasing concerns about how private data is collected and used; the spreading of false information that could influence the 2020 election, by both foreign and domestic actors on social media; and whether behemoths like Facebook, Google and Amazon should be split up.

''I definitely think we need market regulation,'' said Gabriel Weinberg, the founder and chief executive of the search engine DuckDuckGo. ''I think it's the only way to correct systemic market failures.''

But addressing the myriad issues is not a one-time affair. ''I'm worried Congress is thinking that we're going to pass one privacy bill and be done for 20 years,'' he added.

And one tool will not resolve all the different and complex issues, said Noah Phillips, commissioner of the Federal Trade Commission. First, ''we need to ask what is the harm that we're solving and how does the remedy address that harm?''

If the question is competition, he said, then that's what antitrust laws are for. Privacy, on the other hand, will require other approaches. And therein, he and others have said, lies the crux of the dilemma.

For there to be any change in how the big technology companies are operating, most agreed that there must be a confluence of several factors: a strong congressional mandate, leadership to address long-term needs, more resources for agencies like the Federal Trade Commission and a public willingness to lose some of the ease and convenience people now get through companies like Amazon.

Steve Huffman, the chief executive of Reddit and the only head of a social media company in the room, said: ''When it comes to regulation it's the detail that matters. I don't want to see regulation that's knee-jerk or comes from a position of fear.''

But he acknowledged, ''The state of our political discourse is as toxic as it's ever been in my lifetime.''

Mr. Huffman said Reddit was not following Twitter's lead in banning political ads -- something Facebook has refused to do. He said he believes such an action favors incumbents, but Reddit is considering enabling comments on all political ads. Currently, those who buy the ads can decide whether or not they are open to comments.

Such discussion reflects ''a healthy debate about how we treat political ads in this country,'' Mr. Huffman said. ''While I don't agree with their decisions, I also don't really agree with the status quo.''

Some said, though, that the workers inside companies can make a bigger difference than government officials coming in from the outside.

''I've seen more regulation go bad in technology than produce good,'' said Craig Newmark, the founder of Craigslist and the head of Craig Newmark Foundations. ''I've been working with line workers, grunts, my fellow nerds in these tech companies who are now actively working to try to get their management to do the right thing, and that's beginning to bear fruit.''

For Kate Crawford, a co-founder of the AI Now Institute at New York University, which aims to understand the social implications of artificial intelligence, it isn't a matter of choosing between government intervention or worker and public action, but advocating for both.

''The question isn't whether regulation works or do we need it,'' Ms. Crawford said. ''I think we absolutely need it, but the question we have to ask is 'Is it going to be enough?'''

She said collective action by workers at companies like Google, investigations by the news media and institutions like hers were all shining a light on the workings of the major technology companies as never before.

On the question of whether the big tech companies should be broken up -- as Elizabeth Warren has advocated in her presidential campaign -- Mr. Hughes said it was now clear that a majority of Americans want that.

''In a time when Republicans and Democrats can't really agree on anything, there seems to be a pretty wide bipartisan consensus that we should be paying more attention to this,'' he said. ''Now the question is, where does that go, and how does that develop over the next year?''

But Ms. Crawford warned that breaking technology companies into smaller entities would not necessarily solve the problem.

''If we move from 10 major players to 100 but don't question the underlying business model, is that really going to address this very complex set of problems?'' she asked. ''Why are we not talking about, essentially, the sort of rapacious excavation of everybody's biometric information, location data, the use of everything that is available to train A.I. systems? Why are we not looking at labor practices in terms of contract work forces?''

Or as Alexa von Tobel, the founder and managing partner of Inspired Capital, noted, ''You can be a really small company with incredible A.I. and quantum computing and owning data of enough people and be very, very dangerous.''

While the challenges can seem overwhelming -- and at times the conversation steered toward the apocalyptic -- Mr. Hughes, for one, was optimistic.

''We can get regulation right. We do it with airlines. We do it with pharmaceuticals. We do it with the F.C.C.,'' he said. ''We have come to a cultural agreement in the United States that when private industry is crucially important in our lives, we have to ensure that it works for the people.''Task force moderator: Kara Swisher. Members: Ruzwana Bashir, chief executive, Peek.com; Kate Crawford, co-founder, AI Now; Steve Huffman, co-founder and chief executive, Reddit; Chris Hughes, co-chair, Economic Security Project, and co-founder, Facebook; Craig Newmark, founder, Craig Newmark Philanthropies and Craigslist; Noah Phillips, commissioner, Federal Trade Commission; Alexa von Tobel, founder and managing partner, Inspired Capital; Gabriel Weinberg, founder and chief executive, DuckDuckGo.

PHOTOS: KATE CRAWFORD: CO-FOUNDER OF THE AI NOW INSTITUTE

STEVE HUFFMAN: CO-FOUNDER OF REDDIT (PHOTOGRAPHS BY JEENAH MOON FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES) (F16)
