Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YJF-YTS1-DY0W-42MR-00000-00Tech 2030? 2 Predictions on Where Tech May Be Headed2020-01-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:10ZLexisNexisTECH TALKPg. 17Tech 2030? 2 Predictions on Where Tech May Be HeadedTrevor GilmoreRedwood CityFULL TEXT

With tech being a part of everyday life for most of the world, here is my attempt to make two predictions on where automation and data privacy will be in 2030.

No. 1: Automation

Of the three stages of automation-artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML) and robotic process automation (RPA)-the latter is the first widely adopted in the finance world, because it mimics human actions to perform a series of functions without intervention.

Based on rule and process, there is little room for judgement or thinking outside the box; risk in minimized and efficiencies are captured.

"Hey macro on steroids, run at 3 p.m. tomorrow." It does what it's asked and saves you a few hours of excel jockey time. Sweet!

RPA is widely thought of as the simplest form of AI and is used by most of the world's mid to large corporations in functions ranging from office management to the rote tasks of the back office.

The next phase, ML, introduces some judgement based on adaptation learned over time. Isn't it freaky how much Alexa knows about you? Full-blown AI is the ultimate step, and makes decisions based on ML, deep learning and other secret sauce, and is poised to make the biggest shift once widely adopted.

The three main RPA providers are Automation Anywhere, UI Path and Blue Prism. The first two offer free trials of their software. I recommend starting basic: Solve for something that needs to be done each month at a certain time, like bank reconciliations or something on the revenue cycle, such as invoicing or A/R.

There is an investment decision to be made, so be strategic and don't do a moonshot on your first integration. The ROI will come over time.

Prediction: AI will change the landscape of the profession-from audit to tax to accounting. The finance function of 2030 will be composed of a finance chief who has realtime information available to make decisions, and who relies on a small, but very competent, AI trained finance staff' that, in turn, are able to operate in real time. Accountants will become more like finance product managers.

Opportunities: In the short term, consider developing an RPA to maximize efficiencies at your own firm or help a client identify ways they can adopt RPA. In the long term, start understanding how you can leverage ML and AI. Caveat: Consider the country or domicile where data is routed through; some might rout through another country, which might subject you to the privacy requirements of that jurisdiction.

No. 2: Date Privacy

Countries and jurisdictions will continue their push for governance over data collected by the technology platforms. Examples include Europe's 2018 landmark General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and California's 2020 CCPA (California Consumer Protection Act). That's right, thanks to GDPR we now see the "click accept" box on every website. Just recently, Facebook delayed the launch of its dating app in Europe, which was planned for release before Valentine's Day. The reason? Ireland's privacy regulator, The Irish Data Protection Commission, raised concerns of the dating app's compliance with GDPR.

Under GDPR, companies must perform a data process impact assessment before launching a product in Europe. In Facebook's case, there apparently was not enough time between the notification to the Irish Data Protection Commission and the app's go-live date.

Ireland is tasked with greater privacy governance than other European countries since Dublin is the European corporate home to many technology companies, such as Facebook and Alphabet, the parent of Google. Many have domiciled their intellectual property in Ireland by way of a corporate inversion, due to the favorable Irish tax climate.

Prediction: In our geopolitical climate, where American technology companies make up a significant component of global equity markets and whose reach is borderless, we should expect to see more countries enforce privacy action and seek ways to boost their revenues via taxation and fees.

In 2030, countries will be even more keen to maintain their tax base via enforcement. There will be a decade-long game of tug-of-war between big tech and the governments.

Opportunities: Consulting opportunities include advisory as the privacy concerns relate to the finance function, and includes clients operating purely within the United States (given the emergence of states' own privacy rules, which may be stricter than the federal government) and with your international clients.

Most of the larger firms have these practice areas in place, but for smaller firms, there are some clear opportunities. As laws continue to change, so do the opportunities. If a client approaches you and asks how the CCPA might affect them, understanding and explaining the fundamentals and specific applicability conveys thought leadership. Our clients do look to us as their adviser in many areas, and these discussions come up.

Consider partnering with a privacy consultancy to understand scope and costs to comply (and to refer clients to), which will also help you understand potential costs related to legal and compliance and other contingencies that arise when dealing with new privacy rules.

One last thought: Opt for cyber coverage on your liability policy. It is cheap and worth it. Data breach requirements vary by state, so if you have clients in 50 states, then you potentially have 50 different notification requirements you need to comply with.

Of course, I have no way of predicting the future. But let's talk in 2030 and compare notes. Щ

urn:contentItem:5SKD-VMW1-JBRW-C005-00000-00Techâ€™s Military Dilemma2018-07-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:10ZLexisNexisPg. 14Techâ€™s Military DilemmaBy Jacob Silverman

Silicon Valleyâ€™s emerging role in Americaâ€™s forever war

On April 3, President Donald Trump sat down to a private dinner with some close associates, including Peter Thiel, his most loyal supporter in Silicon Valley. Thiel had brought Safra Catz, the co-CEO of Oracle, along to discuss a $10 billion Department of Defense contract to build the Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure, or JEDI, a cloud computing platform that will eventually run much of the Pentagonâ€™s digital infrastructure--from data storage to image analytics to the translation of intercepted phone calls. According toÂ Bloomberg News, Catz objected to the DODâ€™s plan to award the entire JEDI contract to a single organization, rather than parceling it out to multiple contractors. Oracle, Microsoft, and IBM were all bidding, but Amazon, Catz said, with its massive cloud services business, had an unfair advantage. (Trump, in a rare display of restraint, reportedly said he wanted to ensure a fair competition but went no further.)

JEDI plays a significant part in the Pentagonâ€™s strategy to ensure that its war-waging capabilities keep pace with technological change, and Amazon is probably best positioned to build it. The companyâ€™s web services division (AWS), officially founded in 2006, grew out of a project hatched by two of its employees, Benjamin Black and Chris Pinkham, to use Amazonâ€™s growing resources to provide technical infrastructure to anyone who might want it--whether a retailer selling their wares through Amazonâ€™s platform or someone starting a new company. The initial product, called EC2, helped Amazon launch an entirely new industry, broadly called cloud computing but encompassing a range of services, including data storage, analytics, machine learning, and other tools. While Amazonâ€™s vaunted retail business frequently lost money over the last decade, AWS has been one of its most reliably profitable divisions, bringing in $5.4 billion in revenue in the first quarter of 2018.

Microsoft, Google, and others eventually started their own cloud computing divisions. But as the competition over JEDI shows, the desire to challenge AWS has led major technology firms into the national security complex, with promises to analyze imagery for drone strikes and to run communications links for soldiers fighting in the Middle East and North Africa. As these companies move into military work, their claims about the benevolent role that technology can play in modern society--already damaged by scandals ranging from Uberâ€™s labor exploitation to Facebookâ€™s electoral mismanagement--are running squarely up against the realities of their profit motive.

Â 

In truth, government and the technology industry have always been partners. Some companies, like IBM, have relationships with the military that extend back to World War II. The development of the early internet owes much to resources provided by the Pentagonâ€™s advanced research division, an agency founded in 1958 to counter Soviet expansion into space. Later, during the Cold War, microchips developed by industry pioneers like Fairchild Semiconductor found their way into ballistic missiles. Even Stanford Universityâ€™s rise as an engineering and entrepreneurial powerhouse depended heavily on millions of dollars in government funding for high-tech research (a relationship that became controversial during the Vietnam War).

More recently, Edward Snowdenâ€™s 2013 leaks revealed the tech industryâ€™s complicity in the National Security Agencyâ€™s global surveillance operation. Major companies had complied with--and profited from--government demands for unwarranted data collection. In one telling detail made public by Snowden, Americans learned that even as the NSA was making secret deals with Yahoo and other companies to access customer information, the intelligence community was hacking into those same companies and collecting personal data.

With the exception of a few notable court challenges to government subpoenas, the Snowden leaks did little to change the industryâ€™s close relationship with the military. Silicon Valley executives like Eric Schmidt still sit on Pentagon advisory boards, and Amazonâ€™s Jeff Bezos entertains strategically important heads of state like Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. Despite Mark Zuckerbergâ€™s ritual shaming before a congressional committee this past spring, the quasi-governmental reach of these companies remains self-evident.

Take Palantir, perhaps this eraâ€™s paradigmatic tech company, if not also its most controversial. Established in 2004 by Peter Thiel--Trump dinner companion, PayPal co-founder, Facebook board member, and slayer of Gawker Media--Palantir organizes and parses vast amounts of data for corporate and government clients, particularly in the defense and intelligence communities. Considered one of the countryâ€™s most valuable privately held startups, Palantir was initially funded partly by In-Q-Tel, the CIAâ€™s venture capital arm. This government pedigree has ensured that its products are as popular in Washington as they are in Kabul, where theyâ€™re used to track the locations of improvised explosive devices.

Palantirâ€™s lucrative government contracting business is perhaps more overt than some of the other tech giantsâ€™, but itâ€™s far from an outlier. Amazon, whose AWS division provides the digital infrastructure for everything from NASA to Netflix, is already the official cloud-computing provider of the CIA. Even before it began competing for JEDI, the company provided similar services to the Defense Department and other government agencies as a subcontractor. Microsoftâ€™s operating systems power millions of DOD devices; in 2016, it earned a $927 million information technology and consulting contract from the department, and in May it announced a deal to provide its Azure Government cloud service to the 17 U.S. intelligence agencies. Google has dipped into government contracting, too, though not without internal resistance. This spring, more than 3,000 Google employees signed a letter of protest, and roughly a dozen resigned, in response to the companyâ€™s participation in Project Maven, which provides image analysis technology used in drone strikes to the Air Force. (Google announced in June that it would not renew the contract.)

Meanwhile, Amazon has attracted a great deal of scrutiny for its enduring march toward retail monopoly, but in reality, the companyâ€™s future now rests as much in securing the top-secret data of CIA activities as it does in delivering groceries--a spectacular broadening of its reach, which ought to bring up questions about whether Amazonâ€™s market share buys it the same leverage in the federal government as it does in the retail economy.

Â 

It should perhaps come as no surprise that the government, for its part, would seek out the data and expertise of Big Tech. (Former Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter held regular meetings with Silicon Valley VIPs while serving in the Obama administration.) Only the large firms have the capacity to build and manage the secure databases and sophisticated computer networks that governmental bureaucracies need to operate. And these companies, in collecting so much user data, present a tempting opportunity for intelligence agencies looking to expand the scope of their mass surveillance; the NSA and others want the same data these companies collect in the normal course of business. But that doesnâ€™t mean that the technology companies are obliged to respond to the call for government cooperation, nor do they necessarily need to rush willingly into the defense industry.

Much has changed since the first ties between the government and technology companies were forged during World War II. Todayâ€™s tech giants have immense influence over everything from social media to restaurant reviews, autonomous vehicles to health care. They are some of Americaâ€™s most valuable, and often most admired, companies, with interests deeply intertwined with the global economy. And while contracts like JEDI may comprise a growing share of their profits, the government probably needs tech firms more than they need the government. Because the DOD and others rely so heavily on their tools, they could, in theory, resist invasive data requests. They have the power, and the ethical obligation, to decide what kind of companies they want to be and, increasingly, to help decide what sort of country the United States should be.

That, ultimately, is why the fight to win the JEDI contract represents something larger than the profit margins and stock prices of Silicon Valley firms: It is a crossroads at which tech companies will be forced to choose whether they can feasibly continue to preach the values of liberal-minded innovation and independence from big government while serving as its well-paid and compliant partners. It may be unrealistic to expect large, profit-seeking corporations--the Everything Store exists to create loyal consumers, after all--to decline work thatâ€™s both wildly remunerative and earns them outsize influence with the very entities that wield the power to regulate them. But it is fair to expect that these companies would act with the ethical standards they so proudly claim to uphold. In recent years, monopolistic tech giants have reaped fantastic gains in efficiency and cost savings, often at the expense of individual privacy and labor rights. To add â€œwar profiteerâ€ to that list would only further diminish an industry that, with equal parts naÃ¯vetÃ© and swagger, has so often failed at trying to do good.

Â 

JACOB SILVERMANÂ is the author ofÂ Terms of Service: Social Media and the Price of Constant Connection.

urn:contentItem:5JNB-F901-JCM9-H26G-00000-00Tech Advocates, You Can Make a Difference. Find Out How2016-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisTech Advocates, You Can Make a Difference. Find Out How

Â Even before consumer tech ever hits the pavement, some regulators and legislators think of banning, restricting or delaying products and services. That's the case with ridesharing, driverless cars and drones. And in other instances, we are operating in a maze of outdated laws -" meant for the fax era -" that don't protect our ideas, online speech and digital footprint.

Â 

As so many facets of our lives now intersect with technology, it is important that business leaders and tech enthusiasts remain active advocates. We need these leaders to educatepolicymakers about the difference they can make to accelerate and protect the latest innovations, whether those come from well-established companies or entrepreneurs and startups.

Â 

That's why last week we brought more than 30 tech entrepreneurs to Capitol Hill for #CTATechWeek. Small business owners and tech CEOs from across the country spoke with members of Congress and their staffs about modernizing our immigration laws, cracking down on abusive patent trolls and approving the Trans Pacific Partnership.

Â 

In addition to these face-to-face meetings with policymakers, we use Consumer Technology Association (CTA) startup member Phone2Action's civic engagement platform year-round to ensure the government doesn't stop the next big tech innovation from ever happening. Phone2Action allows our member companies and tech advocates to connect to policymakers via email, phone and social media. By coordinating outreach across our platforms, we're able to amplify advocates' voices and have a greater effect on issues that matter on the state and the federal level.

Â 

Just last summer, our members urged California Governor Jerry Brown to veto a bill that threatened to inhibit drone innovation. The campaign garnered about 1,400 emails to Gov. Brown, and the bill was vetoed two weeks later. We have also influenced ridesharing laws in Virginia, Illinois and Nevada and stood up against Mississippi Attorney General Jim Hood's online censorship of Google search terms.

Â 

Over a nine-day span in 2015, we used Phone2Action's platform to rally a diverse coalition of businesses, industry associations and tech enthusiasts across the country to help end a work slowdown at the nation's West Coast ports. The result was more than 3,000 messages to every U.S. senator and almost every representative, as well as almost 900 emails directly to the White House. With the ensuing White House intervention, the crisis soon came to an end.

"Everywhere policymakers turned online, we were present with our messaging on the ports crisis -" they couldn't ignore our call to action,- said CTA President and CEO Gary Shapiro.

Â 

It's critical for policymakers to hear from innovators and tech enthusiasts to better understand how broad and overreaching policies can stifle America's entrepreneurial spirit. Any one person can become an extraordinary advocate -" and when the next fight breaks out, we'll need your help.

Â 

Make sure you join The Innovation Movement so that you stay on top of our policy alerts and make your voice heard.Â

urn:contentItem:5JNK-30W1-JCBF-S4J5-00000-00TECH ADVOCATES, YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE. FIND OUT HOW2016-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisTECH ADVOCATES, YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE. FIND OUT HOWStates News ServiceARLINGTON, VA

The following information was released by the Consumer Electronics Association (CEA):

By: Bronwyn Flores

Even before consumer tech ever hits the pavement, some regulators and legislators think of banning, restricting or delaying products and services. Thats the case with ridesharing, driverless cars and drones. And in other instances, we are operating in a maze of outdated laws meant for the fax era that dont protect our ideas, online speech and digital footprint.

As so many facets of our lives now intersect with technology, it is important that business leaders and tech enthusiasts remain active advocates. We need these leaders to educatepolicymakers about the difference they can make to accelerate and protect the latest innovations, whether those come from well-established companies or entrepreneurs and startups.

Thats why last week we brought more than 30 tech entrepreneurs to Capitol Hill for #CTATechWeek. Small business owners and tech CEOs from across the country spoke with members of Congress and their staffs about modernizing our immigration laws, cracking down on abusive patent trolls and approving the Trans Pacific Partnership.

In addition to these face-to-face meetings with policymakers, we use Consumer Technology Association (CTA) startup member Phone2Actions civic engagement platform year-round to ensure the government doesnt stop the next big tech innovation from ever happening. Phone2Action allows our member companies and tech advocates to connect to policymakers via email, phone and social media. By coordinating outreach across our platforms, were able to amplify advocates voices and have a greater effect on issues that matter on the state and the federal level.

Just last summer, our members urged California Governor Jerry Brown to veto a bill that threatened to inhibit drone innovation. The campaign garnered about 1,400 emails to Gov. Brown, and the bill was vetoed two weeks later. We have also influenced ridesharing laws in Virginia, Illinois and Nevada and stood up against Mississippi Attorney General Jim Hoods online censorship of Google search terms.

Over a nine-day span in 2015, we used Phone2Actions platform to rally a diverse coalition of businesses, industry associations and tech enthusiasts across the country to help end a work slowdown at the nations West Coast ports. The result was more than 3,000 messages to every U.S. senator and almost every representative, as well as almost 900 emails directly to the White House. With the ensuing White House intervention, the crisis soon came to an end.

Everywhere policymakers turned online, we were present with our messaging on the ports crisis they couldnt ignore our call to action, said CTA President and CEO Gary Shapiro.

Its critical for policymakers to hear from innovators and tech enthusiasts to better understand how broad and overreaching policies can stifle Americas entrepreneurial spirit. Any one person can become an extraordinary advocate and when the next fight breaks out, well need your help.

Make sure you join The Innovation Movement so that you stay on top of our policy alerts and make your voice heard.

urn:contentItem:59Y3-K351-JDVB-643K-00000-00Tech agenda: The Credit Suisse Technology Conference 20132013-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYTech agenda: The Credit SuisseTechnology Conference 2013

Coming up, Yahoo! and EA are among the big tech guns taking to the stage at this year's Credit SuisseTechnology Conference in Arizona.

The Credit Suisse Technology Conference 2013
December 2 - 5
Scottsdale, Arizona, USA
Now in its fourth year, the event attracts some of the biggest names in tech, including Yahoo!, Pandora, Motorola, EA and Xerox, all of whom will be speaking or presenting to attendees.
https://www.credit-suisse.com/us/en/

LeWeb'13 Paris
December 10-12
Paris, France

The theme of this year's event is ‘The next 10 Years'. What impact will today's innovators have on the future economy and development of the web?
http://paris.leweb.co/

Dell World 2013
December 11-13
Austin, Texas, USA

Covering all of the issues shaping the world of computing and in particular the products developed by Dell, once the world’s biggest computer maker, the event also promises the best in entertainment and education. And although this year’s keynote speaker list is yet to be published, last year’s special guests included former US president Bill Clinton.http://www.dellworld.com

2014 International CES
January 7-10
Las Vegas, Nevada, USA

OK, it might have lost some of its luster and it may not attract the world's most important tech companies -- i.e., Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon, but for everyone else in the industry, this is the place to be to showcase anything and everything that's new in terms of consumer electronics products.http://www.cesweb.org/Home.aspx


Imaging USA
January 12-14
Phoenix, Arizona, USA

Now the largest event of its kind, organized by professional photographers for professional photographers, Imaging USA attracts delegates from all four corners of the globe for workshops, business training, learning about new digital and analogue techniques and of course, networking.http://imagingusa.org/

Convergence India 2014
New Delhi, India
January 21-23

A showcase of the latest innovations and devices helping to kickstart e-development in the country and in doing so improve the digital lives of 1 billion people.
http://www.convergenceindia.org/


IBM Connect 2014
January 26-30
Orlando, Florida, USA

An opportunity for delegates to learn from market leaders and renowned speakers across all of the most crucial tech areas of business today, IBM connect promises new insights in everything from social media to the cloud and business analytics.http://www-01.ibm.com/software/collaboration/events/connect/

Cybertech 2014
January 27-29
Tel Aviv, Israel

The growing threats of cyber attacks and how to thwart them will be the prime focus of this event, attendees of which will include everyone from Symantec to IBM.
http://www.cybertechisrael.com/

Wearable Technologies Conference 2014 EuropeJanuary 27-28
Munich, Germany

It promises to be a showcase for cutting-edge wearable tech innovation, particularly in the areas of health, wellness, fitness, fashion and security. And there will also be sessions dedicated to the future of the smartwatch and smart glasses.http://www.wearable-technologies.com/events/wearable-technologies-conference-2014-i-europe/

DesignCon
January 28-31
Santa Clara, California, USA

Billed as the premier conference for system, chip and board design engineers, attendees can expect access to 120 cutting-edge technical tutorials, keynote speakers, an awards ceremony and a special showcase of over 150 exhibitors.
http://www.designcon.com/santaclara/

ITEXPO
January 28-31
Miami Beach, Florida, USA

Held in the rather glamorous surrounds of Miami Beach, the event is focused on understanding how people communicate and using that knowledge to help attendees build better businesses. Keynote speakers are yet to be finalized but its sister event held in Las Vegas attracted a number of top tech luminaries including Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak and top IBM and Microsoft executives.
http://itexpo.tmcnet.com/east/


Nano Tech 2014
January 29-31
Tokyo, Japan

Now in its 13th year, the event is a platform for businesses in the industry to come together to share and showcase ideas and work in tandem to push the boundaries of nanotechnology forward.
http://www.nanotechexpo.jp/outline.html

Apps World North America 2014
February 5-6
San Francisco, California, USA

With over 8000 developers expected, the two-day event will offer a mix of workshops, networking opportunities and an exhibition of what's new and different in one of the fastest-growing areas of consumer technology.http://www.apps-world.net/northamerica/

Connected World Conference
February 6-17
Chicago, Illinois, USA

Running alsongside the 2014 Chicago auto show, the conference will examine the internet of things and how it will come to manage not just cars, but everything from household items to areas of road infrastructure.
http://www.cvent.com/events/connected-world-conference/event-summary-ad967ffc183949df886994b3ab7eeef7.aspx

Mobile World Congress
February 24-27
Barcelona, Spain

The annual gathering of smartphone and tablet manufacturers, network operators and connected device innovators, the show has lost a little of its gleam in recent years as Samsung and Googlehave chosen to steer clear or keep attendance discreet, but nevertheless it is still one of the key dates on the calendar for everyone who's anyone in the world of mobile communication.http://www.mobileworldcongress.com/

CeBIT 2014
March 10-14
Hannover, Germany

One of several large-scale consumer electronics trade shows, exhibitions and conferences that claims to be the world's largest, CeBIT differs from some of its peers, such as the International CES, by partnering with a different country each year in order to promote its IT offerings. For 2014, the country of choice is the UK and Northern Ireland

http://www.cebit.de/home

Macworld/iWorld 2014
March 27 - 29
San Francisco, California, USA

The fact that Apple itself hasn't attended the conference for a number of years hasn't deterred thousands of iDevice obssessives from making the yearly pilgrimage to California to celebrate all things Apple.
http://www.macworldiworld.com/

Interop Las Vegas
March 31-April 4
Las Vegas, Nevada, USA

Billed as the leader in educating IT professionals about new technologies, the event series has now been running for 28 years with events on five continents.
http://www.interop.com/lasvegas/


NAB Show
April 5-10
Las Vegas, Nevada, USA

The event for anyone "passionate about content," the conference and expo is the largest electronic media show focused on filmed entertainment and the development, management and delivery of content across all mediums. As such, it attracts more than 93,000 attendees from 156 countries and 1,550+ exhibitors.http://www.nabshow.com/


Bluetooth World
8-9 April
San José, California, USA

Hosted by the Bluetooth SIG, the organization that regulates and verifies the wireless technology and all new Bluetooth-enabled devices, the event will be one of several scheduled throughout the year focusing on the role that Bluetooth is set to play in making the internet of things a consumer technology reality.http://bluetoothworldevent.com/

Smart Fabrics and Wearable Technology 2014
April 23-25
San Francisco, California, USA

Topics up for discussion will include interactive fashion, the future of nanotechnology and even the use of smart fabrics in baby diapers.http://www.smartfabricsconference.com/home.aspx

urn:contentItem:5S1D-N5F1-DY9P-N4TB-00000-00Tech and trade fears weigh on stocks2018-04-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 30Tech and trade fears weigh on stocks

EUROPEAN stocks retreated yesterday as investors began the second quarter in a fragile mood amid international trade tensions and mounting pressure on big technology companies.

The pan-European STOXX 600 ended the day down 0.5pc after falling more than 1pc earlier in the session. The index was supported in afternoon trading by a slight rebound on Wall Street.

Germany's DAX was a clear underperformer, losing about 0.8pc while industrials, financials and healthcare stocks weighed on European indexes.

The tech sector dropped 0.8pc, after an overnight report that Apple plans to replace Intel chips in Macs with its own.

The index has fallen about 7.5pc in the past three weeks as anxiety grew over big tech companies with the focus on Facebook's use of data, and regulation of Amazon. Reports of Apple increasingly going down the 'insourcing' route have dented shares in Apple suppliers around the world, most notably Europe's Dialog Semiconductor, down 3.5pc.

STMicro shed 2.9pc, while ams declined 2.3pc and Infineon fell 2.1pc.

Risk appetite was poor across the board, as European investors followed US and Asian investors to the exit after China retaliated against US tariffs.

"We believe that risk-reward for stocks has not turned medium-term negative, and would be adding at these levels," wrote JP Morgan strategists in a note.

Equities have again entered "oversold" territory, they said, adding, however, that headwinds for technology stocks were increasing.

Outside the tech sector, food services group Sodexo slumped 4.5pc after Goldman Sachs cut the stock to "neutral". Sodexo had already suffered a 15.7pc decline.

Helen Reid/Reuters

urn:contentItem:60MJ-8PG1-JCMN-Y3NW-00000-00Tech Anti-Trust Fight is More Than a Game2020-08-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:11ZLexisNexisTech Anti-Trust Fight is More Than a GameWomble Bond Dickinson

Aug 18, 2020( JD Supra: http://www.jdsupra.com Delivered by Newstex) Tim Sweeney, the Colossus of Cary, is fighting even bigger foes - Apple and Google. The multibillionaire chief executive of Epic Games has opened a multi-front war on the tribute that app developers are forced to pay to reach smartphone users.On the first front, Epic offered app users a less expensive way to pay for in-game weapons in its mega-popular game Fortnite, incurring the wrath of the giants who siphon money from these transactions. According[1] to the Wall Street Journal, 'Apple and Google pulled 'Fortnite' from their app stores Thursday after Mr. Sweeney's Epic rolled out a new way of making in-game purchases thatcircumvents the 30% cut[2]the tech giants take from digital transactions within apps—a percentage established in Apple's case more than a decade ago and some developers have called to reduce for years.'On the second front, Epic Games quickly filed a lawsuit against Apple, calling the smartphone/tablet manufacturer 'the behemoth seeking to control markets, block competition, and stifle innovation.'

Epic even illustrated it position in the conflict with a terrific parody[3] of Apple's famous 1984 commercial, where, in 2020 Apple is now the IBM Big Brother dominant oppressor.It doesn't help that Apple has truly become the IBM or Microsoft-style market presence Steve Jobs used to love fighting - a financial giant, making most of its money by leveraging long-established dominant market positions. In 2020, rather than inventing new insanely great products, Apple makes billions draining 30% of the revenue from developers operating through its app store.Apple requires that all apps for its phone customers be purchased through its Apple App Store, a policy decried by the U.S. Supreme Court[4] as a violation of anti-trust laws. According to the Wall Street Journal, Apple's 'Services revenue—which includes the App Store, plus Apple Music and AppleCare, among other businesses—jumped 15% to $13.16 billion last quarter.'Google yanked Epic's app from the Android stores as well. Epic reacted by immediately filing suit against Google, claiming the search company is'using its size to do evil upon competitors, innovators, customers, and users in a slew of markets it has grown to monopolize.'Sweeney is uniquely situated to fight these industry leaders as his games have massive consumer followings, Epic has several important income streams like the Unreal Engine for developing games, and the company is closely held and so less vulnerable to public and shareholder pressures.The other front in this war will be fought in new retail business models. Epic games opened its own digital computer game store in 2018, collecting 12% of sales revenue from developers. Currently this store deals primarily in console-based games, competing with online game markets Steam and itch.io[5]. Don't be surprised if Epic makes a move to smartphone apps as well, breaking the current duopoly, opening up a new revenue stream for Epic, and providing access to new markets at a lower price for game developers. Sweeney may need help from courts or Congress to achieve this goal.Epic Games has already forced important sandbox-busting changes in the gaming industry, leveraging its leading Fortnite game to force big game console manufacturers like Sony to open its formerly locked platform to cross device play. As Polygon wrote[6] about this battle, 'Sony has given in, becauseFortniteis now dominant. You can play it on Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, PC, iOS devices or on certain Android devices. And anyone can either play against the community on their device, or join the huge pool of players in cross-platform play. OnlyMinecraftrivals it in terms of games that have become part of the gaming monoculture.'With increasing calls for regulation of big tech and with Congress grilling the tech giant CEOs, Sweeney may have found the perfect time to play the anti-trust card against his rivals. All of Sweeney''s time playing strategy games may pay off if this war turns against Apple and Google.[View source[7].] [ 1]: https://www.wsj.com/articles/why-fortnites-founder-tim-sweeney-is-fighting-apple-google-11597447722 [ 2]: https://www.wsj.com/articles/fortnite-creator-aims-to-bypass-apple-google-fees-11597333613 [ 3]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=euiSHuaw6Q4 [ 4]: https://www.wsj.com/articles/supreme-court-allows-antitrust-suit-against-apple-to-proceed-11557757089 [ 5]: https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=http-3A__itch.io&d=DwMFaQ&c=L5E2d05je37i-dadkViuXA&r=UHeQQRzMW99vYypKbKl_Ffjcr8yrK-S859KioZ_cuG4&m=Zac5NjiTHwc3QpTTHYXNHo_-orAA8qcYp1zp2Qht8JQ&s=lDc3yjX81wNFh3KJK4CkqWXbQz8U-spJrpns-SwlhPM&e= [ 6]: https://www.polygon.com/2018/9/26/17905770/fortnite-cross-play-ps4-nintendo-switch-xbox [ 7]: https://heydatadata.com/2020/08/18/tech-anti-trust-fight-is-more-than-a-game/

Aug 18, 2020( National Law Review: https://www.natlawreview.com Delivered by Newstex) Article By Theodore F. Claypoole[1] Womble Bond Dickinson (US) LLP[2] HeyDataData[3] Tim Sweeney, the Colossus of Cary, is fighting even bigger foes - Apple and Google. The multibillionaire chief executive of Epic Games has opened a multi-front war on the tribute that app developers are forced to pay to reach smartphone users.On the first front, Epic offered app users a less expensive way to pay for in-game weapons in its mega-popular game Fortnite, incurring the wrath of the giants who siphon money from these transactions. According[4]to the Wall Street Journal, 'Apple and Google pulled 'Fortnite' from their app stores Thursday after Mr. Sweeney's Epic rolled out a new way of making in-game purchases thatcircumvent the 30% cut[5]the tech giants take from digital transactions within apps—a percentage established in Apple's case more than a decade ago and some developers have called to reduce for years.'On the second front, Epic Games quickly filed a lawsuit against Apple, calling the smartphone/tablet manufacturer 'the behemoth seeking to control markets, block competition, and stifle innovation.'

Epic even illustrated it position in the conflict with aterrific parody[6]of Apple's famous 1984 commercial, where, in 2020 Apple is now the IBM Big Brother dominant oppressor.It doesn't help that Apple has truly become the IBM or Microsoft-style market presence Steve Jobs used to love fighting - a financial giant, making most of its money by leveraging long-established dominant market positions. In 2020, rather than inventing new insanely great products, Apple makes billions draining 30% of the revenue from developers operating through its app store.Apple requires that all apps for its phone customers be purchased through its Apple App Store, a policy decried by theU.S. Supreme Court[7]as a violation of anti-trust laws. According to the Wall Street Journal, Apple's 'Services revenue—which includes the App Store, plus Apple Music and AppleCare, among other businesses—jumped 15% to $13.16 billion last quarter.'Google yanked Epic's app from the Android stores as well. Epic reacted by immediately filing suit against Google, claiming the search company is'using its size to do evil upon competitors, innovators, customers, and users in a slew of markets it has grown to monopolize.'Sweeney is uniquely situated to fight these industry leaders as his games have massive consumer followings, Epic has several important income streams like the Unreal Engine for developing games, and the company is closely held and so less vulnerable to public and shareholder pressures.The other front in this war will be fought in new retail business models. Epic Games opened its own digital computer game store in 2018, collecting 12% of sales revenue from developers. Currently, this store deals primarily in console-based games, competing with online game markets Steam anditch.io[8]. Don't be surprised if Epic makes a move to smartphone apps as well, breaking the current duopoly, opening up a new revenue stream for Epic, and providing access to new markets at a lower price for game developers. Sweeney may need help from courts or Congress to achieve this goal.Epic Games has already forced important sandbox-busting changes in the gaming industry, leveraging its leading Fortnite game to force big game console manufacturers like Sony to open its formerly locked platform to cross-device play. AsPolygon wrote[9]about this battle, 'Sony has given in, becauseFortniteis now dominant. You can play it on Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, PC, iOS devices, or on certain Android devices. And anyone can either play against the community on their device, or join the huge pool of players in cross-platform play. OnlyMinecraftrivals it in terms of games that have become part of the gaming monoculture.'With increasing calls for regulation of big tech and with Congress grilling the tech giant CEOs, Sweeney may have found the perfect time to play the anti-trust card against his rivals. All of Sweeney''s time playing strategy games may pay off if this war turns against Apple and Google.Copyright 2020 Womble Bond Dickinson (US) LLP All Rights Reserved.
